Somewhere between high concept and lowbrow humor, "Paul" hits the sweet spot of a genuine heart.

Despite some weaknesses as both a film and a parable, "In a Better World" is a potent provocation.
"There Be Dragons" tries to echo "For Whom the Bell Tolls," but this instrument is tinny and tarnished.

With its references to other properties in the Marvel universe and to classic tales of redemption, this no-surprises summer movie might appeal to those who've been bitten by radioactive spiders or the Shakespeare bug.

This is something more than a movie; it's a testament - and re-creation - of rapture.

Instead of entertaining us, director Robert Redford offers us a handsome history lesson that's as dry as a hardtack biscuit.

A Korean movie about an aging housemaid that turns out to be one of the best films of the year.

Forgive me, Father, for I was bored.

A tearjerking romance that belongs to another era, when female moviegoers wanted to be transported, not grounded in grim realities.

A serviceable behind-the-scenes tour documentary with about as much insight as a talk-show monologue.

Smart and sweet enough to become the favorite film of some Midwestern adolescent who wrongly believes he's already seen the dark side.

movie_review_blurb: It's smart, heartfelt, handsome and just mutated enough to sustain interest in a specialized subject.
What might have seemed like a lively idea -- an all-star roundelay about love in Los Angeles -- is as fossilized as the wooly mammoths in the La Brea Tar Pits.
A cheesy chew-toy of a comedy about reluctant fatherhood.
Director Kiyoshi Kurosawa cut his teeth on horror movies, and his flattened, formal style mines the horror in everyday urban life.
It's hard to overlook that while Michael's benefactors are white, the villains in the movie are black.
The combination of a literate script, an adroit cast and an economical style is simple addition that achieves an alchemical feat: the best film of the year.
That has the makings of a deliciously dark comedy, but Judge lets the premise simply drift away like a pothead's train of thought.
My One and Only aspires to a top-down breeziness, but at the end of the road it's as foolish and superficial as a suntan.
Williams, with a brave smile that belies the toxic environment, emerges with a trophy as one of Hollywood's greatest survivors.
With its commercial imperatives and subversive ambitions working at cross purposes, this puzzling movie doesn't have a clue what it's all about.
We're left with an impression of a vivacious pioneer; but warm shouldn't have to mean fuzzy.
The sight of the once-great Griffith cruising at a singles bar in a backward baseball cap isn't the worst of it.

Like the mild-mannered protagonist, Taiwanese director Ang Lee sees the '60s through a rose-colored telephoto lens, but his sympathetic spirit extends the generous message of the hippie era like a passed joint.
Outwitting Madison Avenue, these free thinkers turn old cars into utterly unique emblems of identity.
Seraphine is rare in its sympathetic focus on a laborer, yet refined in its execution.
It may not be original, but Adam could leave a lump in your throat.
With its exploded notions of heroism, torture-rack dramatics and kamikaze gusto, it's a fiendishly entertaining flick.
If Not Quite Hollywood is not quite convincing, it is quite entertaining.
movie_title: Not Quite Hollywood: The Wild, Untold Story of Ozploitation! (2008)

movie_review_blurb: What's most conspicuously missing from this ensemble is some input from the advertisers who subsidize Wintour's tyranny, and the readers who are seduced into buying her beautiful four-pound paperweights.
It's impossible not to be moved.
Bandslam had potential, but it succumbed to peer pressure.
The reason District 9 reverberates so loudly is because its moral indignation is cranked to 11.
Humpday is something surprising: a sharply observed slice of life, an entertaining example of the microbudget genre called mumblecore.
It's often obscenely funny, but it tickles more than it stings.
Julie & Julia was directed by Nora Ephron with a light touch that will satisfy an eager audience of female foodies.
This up-close portrait delivers all the runway glamor and backstage gossip that fashionistas crave, yet it's also unexpectedly poignant.
The title Revanche means 'retribution,' and this Oscar nominee for best foreign-language film is a European extract of neo-noir, like a Bavarian Body Heat or a Teutonic 21 Grams.
The collaborative effort is overlong and wrongheaded in some of its sympathies, but it's one of the shrewdest show-business comedies in years.
Slow and odorous, The Ugly Truth is mired in phoniness up to its neck. And above that, there's nothing.
The swooningly romantic comedy (500) Days of Summer is a movie that will be discovered, embraced and shared with friends like a favorite record album.
Departures is sometimes macabre and sometimes manipulative, but the way it speaks to the spirit is miraculous.
This broadside against sharia law lacks the finesse of an import, but it's effectively melodramatic, particularly because of the strong performance of Iranian-born actress Shoreh Aghdashloo
This movie may be sickly sweet, but it's harmless; and as a handcrafted antidote to a toxic toy story like G.I.Joe, Paper Heart has healing properties.
You ought to have a movie that's both smart and sexy. But Jennifer's Body is neither. Most damning of all, it's not scary.
Of all the films to come out of the conflict, Afghan Star is the most provocative, because its message that people are essentially the same is a dubious, double-edge sword.
For those who are keeping the American dream alive, this spirited documentary raises a toast.
Guilty pleasures don't come guiltier than 2012.
The closer you look at The Men Who Stare at Goats, the better you see that its shaggy coat is covering some pointed truths.
movie_title: The Men Who Stare at Goats (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The thread connecting the ambitious girl to the acclaimed woman is enough to make us wish for a sequel titled Chanel No. 2.
A director whose breakthrough was the story of a madman's last stand has exceeded that feat with the story of an angry man's next step.
It's eerie rather than wondrous.
It's a cheap, vicarious high to hear these unidentified denizens reminisce about the orgies and overdoses that seem to have been included with the rent.
Honoring the heroes of the environmental movement is clearly appropriate, but getting mired in nostalgia is a dirty shame.
Because so many of the segments are about young lovers, the standouts involve people past their prime.
Cobbled together from trusty old parts, Astro Boy manages to stand on its own feet.
The movie gives us an eyeful, but the unexamined irony is that the nice old couple can't sell the rest of us on why it's good.
When Weitz and writer Brian Helgeland try to drape a plot over the colorful characters, the movie goes fuzzy.
movie_title: Cirque du Freak: The Vampire's Assistant (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Although Amelia is too conventionally constructed to attain the heights of Martin Scorsese's "The Aviator," the cinematography and Depression-era props are splendid. Swank, of course, is too.
lustrator Renaldo Kuhler is still alive and lucid, so while this fascinating documentary is picturesque, it could have done more to fill in the blanks.

To their credit, the creative team has retained the handmade look and unruly spirit of Maurice Sendak's bedtime fable; to their discredit, they haven't added enough narrative or emotional dimension to make it an effective movie.
Still Walking is a miniaturist's masterpiece, the ebb and flow of familial love distilled to its essence.
You'd be hard-pressed to find a better documentary about on-court dynamics and off-court camaraderie; but as journalism, it's less than thorough.
The big problem with the movie isn't the violence, or the message about coddling criminals, or the two lead actors, although they've never been worse. It's the utter implausibility.
The capable cast is stuck in a movie that's rated PG-13, with flabby, middle-age pacing.
This poignant, provocative documentary reduces the green movement to human scale -- and magnifies the size of mountain it's trying to climb.
Late in this meandering film, Rogers' romantic infidelities and the onset of illness add some much-needed dynamics, but even when it's just shooting the breeze, The Windmill Movie is captivating.
The secret in this case is the jokes, which are ferocious. Marrying a monster flick with an adolescent romance has produced a merry mutant.
The lack of a factual backbone will be catnip for conservatives who attack everything that Moore does, regardless of the validity of his arguments.
What Barrymore brings is good-natured, girl-powered subversion, a sense of when to flaunt clichés and when to flip them over the rails.
The Invention of Lying is an ambitious attempt to smash the wedding cake and eat it, too; but to say it succeeds would be stretching the truth.
Initially, the puzzle structure and a pair of Oscar-winning actresses distract us from the dark vacuum at the center of this enterprise, but when it implodes, it doesn't reverberate.

In his first starring role, Oswalt, a stand-up comedian whose trademark persona is part comic-book geek and part frat-house hedonist, inhabits a character who is both painfully familiar and poignantly alone.
What animates this dramatically constrained film are the lively words and the vitality of nature. An image of butterflies blooming in a bedroom is Keats' worldview in miniature.
Even as it spirals into disaster-flick absurdity, Pirate Radio isn't trying to cause a big sensation, it's just peddling instant gratification.

It's a credit to the director's persistence of vision that he finds such eerie images to adorn this wispy tree of death. Like a newborn planet, "Melancholia" is magnetically beautiful, but it's also an unformed mass of hot air.
While skimming over the troubled waters of impending war and ongoing labor unrest, it's both a vicarious vacation and a crash course in animation.
Scorsese's "Hugo" is a hugely ambitious and wholly satisfying feat. It's a living lesson in movie magic wrapped in a classic kiddie flick.
For better or worse, the whole exercise in lurid leg-pulling goes out with a bang.

On paper this sequel has some promising elements, but on screen it retreats from the very issues that it raises, and on a shelf next to "Captain America: The First Avenger," "The Winter Soldier" is pale.
Without an explanation for the protagonist's physical and emotional injuries, it's a head-scratcher. As with Joe's sexual compulsion, scratching can't cure the itch.
A lovely little film from a place where the little things linger.
This extra-dry mix of drama and comedy is supposed to reflect the complexities of real life; but as a movie, it's so schematic and schizoid, it leaves us scratching our berets.
With this bloody exercise in provocation, the aging action hero climbs aboard the crooked-cop bandwagon like it was an ambulance to revive his dying career.
Although Aronofsky constructs this vessel with a filmmaker's toolbox rather than a theologian's blueprint, a sturdy hull of human spirit enables it to navigate between both worlds.
Like so much about this film, the finale hints at Hitchcock but settles for soap opera.
The way that "Muppets Most Wanted" grabs for the green is criminal.
Despite Gyllenhaal's twitchy, two-headed performance, "Enemy" is hobbled by a genetic flaw: Suspension of disbelief has a twin called suspicion of dumbness.
Bateman is already a star pupil of comedy, and he could earn an honor's diploma in filmmaking if he learns to spell singularity.
After feeding on this sweet buffet, sated cinephiles will want to call the front desk to extend their stay.
The plot is murky, the acting is melodramatic and the movie is way too long, but the target audience will salivate over the inventively choreographed set-pieces ...
It's as if Sobol walked a tight-rope over the falls, got distracted by the view and then crawled back to safety.
We should never forget that Penn and Teller are professional bamboozlers, and their attempt to re-frame the definition of genius might be nothing but smoke and mirrors.
I've never spoken this fuzzy phrase in conversation, let alone written it in a movie review, but it applies perfectly to the formulaic action flick "Non-Stop": It is what it is.
The view is beautiful, but the loftier aims of "The Wind Rises" fall short.
As cinema it is simply inept, with a talented cast rendered ugly and stiff as they speak in inexplicable British accents.
This stinker is only good for endless laughs.
Compared to the humor in the "Iron Man" movies or the vigilante themes in the recent "Batman" series, this reboot﻿ has little to offer.
This film doesn't compensate for its narrow focus with character development, derring-do or robust humor.
"The Lego Movie" is a marvelous piece of work.
"Gloria" is a character study, one that's pitiful in the compassionate sense of the word.
This confounding film might be too roughly textured for mass consumption, but for audiences who aren't bound by expectations, the labor of chewing it over will be rewarded.
A literary love story that's rooted in repression.
Although it's superficially grungy, this true story isn't much more substantive than something that star Vanessa Hudgens might have made for the Disney Channel ...
By the end, even those who had never heard of Stritch can share her rage against the dying of the light.
It's the Sam Bradford of sports movies - not an All Pro, but capable of a close, fourth-quarter win.
Ernest learns to share, Celestine learns to a paint - and the audience learns that in a Disney-dominated marketplace, kids are still free to choose their own mini mouse.
"Joe" is not handsome or especially smart, but like its namesake, the film has enough rough humor and respect for hard work to qualify as average.
The worst thing about this multifaceted failure is the two-time Oscar winner behind the camera. Where there ought to be a director, there's nothing but an empty chair.
Most of the movie is a backgrounder on the Citizens United case, in which a deeply divided Supreme Court opened the door to truckloads of campaign cash from tycoons and corporations.
A sterling example of the new Australian noir.
This is a fascinating story ... But as a movie, "Spanish Lake" misses the opportunity to include other voices.
A self-aware sequel has to hop over hurdles to keep from swallowing its own tail, but the sharp writing and tag-team antics lift "22 Jump Street" to a high level.
In its totality, "The Fault in Our Stars" is as noxious as chemotherapy.
The movie looks like it was made for broadcast television, the place where words and pictures go to die.
"Edge of Tomorrow" has neither an edge nor a vision of tomorrow that matters today.
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Giving an overlooked luminary his due is reason enough for "For No Good Reason."
'Round these parts, when a movie promises a million laughs but only delivers a dozen chuckles, that's a hanging offense.
movie_title: A Million Ways to Die in the West (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Some sequels have such a complicated back story they should come with printed footnotes. The latest sequel in the "X-Men" series requires an encyclopedia that can be read in a fun-house mirror.

Best of all is Favreau. Instead of mass-producing another superhero epic, he has given the overfed public a dish of right-sized comfort food. Whatever he cooks up in the future, it will be hard to top "Chef."

From the Caruso serenade for the new arrivals at Ellis Island to the discordant reality on the other side of the golden door, "The Immigrant" has a ringing message: Succeeding in America is a dream act.
Like something coughed up by a baby, "Blended" is tasteless mush.
Who can quibble when the source material is a novel by Peter Dexter ("Paris Trout"), the debut director is John Slattery ("Mad Men") and the actors are such seasoned pros?
"Million Dollar Arm" is as predictable as a 3-and-0 pitch down the middle, but when it's baseball season, who wants dark clouds?
There's a word for the kind of technocratic brains behind "Godzilla": unbalanced.
There are songs, by a motley crew of tunesmiths who include Bryan Adams, but except for a showstopper tailor-made for Short, they don't make much of an impact. Ditto for the script ...
"Neighbors" is a showcase for Rogen and a coming-out party for Byrne. It's a party where we want to stay, until we're dragged out kicking and screaming.

This documentary version of Jodorowsky's "Dune" is probably more entertaining than what Hollywood would have done to it, with a clearer message: Our lives are like sands though an hourglass, so dream the impossible dream.
While Allen emerges from this mash-up relatively unscathed, Turturro as an implausible male prostitute gets maimed at the intersection of comedy and drama.
"The Amazing Spider-Man 2" is easy to watch but hard to pin down, like a creature with eight legs going in different directions.
The holes in the story are papered over with such beautiful photographs that few viewers could complain.
"The Railway Man" is a polished locomotive that never builds up steam or deviates from its timetable.
"Transcendence" is an ambitious movie, but ultimately there's too much "artificial" and not enough "intelligence."
While Law bellows blasphemous poetry, his director orchestrates a noirish light show with a cockeyed rhythm.
Given its declarative title, "Heaven Is for Real" should have built a more convincing case.
Kevin Hart hits the vicinity of humor with a few of his drive-by wisecracks, but the movie itself has nothing under the hood.
Sorry, partisans, but there's nothing obvious about "Obvious Child."
The burnished backgrounds are pleasant to look at, but finding something to savor in the story is a tough nut to crack.
This movie begs to be compared to epics such as "Reds" and "Gandhi." But while Elba embodies a dignified hero, the film itself is less than revolutionary.
With a piercing edge, "The Patience Stone" is a cry from behind the veil, where a suffocating woman weaves a new life of her own design.
It's neatly formatted, but if there's a message in the margins of this manuscript, "Populaire" doesn't spell it out.
"Enough Said" is a precious little jewel of a movie.
[Gordon-Levitt's] skills as an actor, and those of co-stars Scarlett Johansson and Julianne Moore, keep us watching, even as public-place modesty makes us want to look away.
Here's a toast to the cast and crew: "Drinking Buddies" is a three-dimensional movie that doesn't require beer goggles.
This documentary reconstructing the life of the ultimate cult author is like a three-act thriller, and the character at the center of the story is a mute man of mystery.
"Thanks for Sharing" is redeemed by a reasonably honest script and strong performances.
It's preposterous schlock masquerading as art.
"Short Term 12" may sound like confinement, but it's a redemptive and even funny film that invites us to stay and grow.
This Sundance-sanctioned, love-on-the-run melodrama is indie filmmaking of a deliberately timeless sort.
Whereas many kung-fu movies are a feast that leaves us weary with sensations, the tastefully bittersweet "Grandmaster" puts us in the mood for more.
A tour documentary that's so streamlined, it could only have been produced by a machine.
Even as it looks to the heavens, "Gravity" is bound to earth, where the beauty is in the details.

It's not only a fresh and funny spoof of the movie business, it represents a real-life triumph within it.
This coming-of-age movie should appeal to smart, sensitive young people who haven't been exposed to the better examples of the genre.
The forced mash-up of "Forrest Gump" and "The Remains of the Day" leaves a bit too much machine oil on the shag carpet, but Whitaker is there to clean it up.
To stand out in a crowded marketplace, a sequel can't just kick ass - it has to blow minds.
"Prince Avalanche" is a molehill that dreams it's a mountain when it's really, really stoned.
There's never been a better director of women than Woody Allen. Actresses in his films have earned five Oscars from 11 nominations. Cate Blanchett in "Blue Jasmine" should make it an even dozen.
This vision of a violent future makes "Elysium" well worth seeing, even as the conventional violence of the thriller finale makes it a missed opportunity.
We'd have to be stoned to be interested in these characters or to be surprised when they form a surrogate family just in time for the blooper reel.
In an era of sleepwalking surrender, "Hannah Arendt" is a welcome wake-up call, a ringing reminder that warring forces first assemble on the battlefield of conscience.
With the combined heat of its stars, "2 Guns" should have had double impact, but Washington and Wahlberg are only doing this tango for cash.
It's not exactly "Ratatouille," but this quasi-animated movie makes an amusing late-summer vacation from superheroes and shoot-'em-ups.
A movie so unspectacular and meaningless it might be mistaken for an old episode of "The Incredible Hulk."
An arrested-development comedy that develops into something else altogether.
While pretending to avoid controversy, debut director Peter Landesman continually steps out of bounds.
With its mix of true-blood romance and full-moon madness, Let Me In should hasten the twilight of the twerpy pretenders.
Freighted with weighty issues, "Captain Phillips" is a film worth debating.

In our daydreams, an ambitious, world-embracing movie like "The Secret Life of Walter Mitty" deserves to be a bigger hit than yet another "Night at the Museum" or "Madagascar" sequel. But your mileage may vary.
movie_title: The Secret Life Of Walter Mitty (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Scorsese, as always, knows exactly what he is doing. Although it's long, the movie is never less than entertaining.
The good intentions are fossilized under the cutesy poop.
With a solid-gold cast and a sterling script, "American Hustle" has a higher return on investment than any other movie in the marketplace.

The movie lacks an effective comedic structure. There's nothing to stop Ferrell and co-writer/director Adam McKay from wobbling across the fine line between stupid and clever like they've had too much scotch.
We were promised desolation, but "The Hobbit" just keeps dragon on.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug (2013)

movie_review_blurb: While the movie includes enough details about the physiology, strategy and marketing of bike racing to satisfy some of our curiosity, other questions remain unanswered.
This supposed slice of life is so half-baked it's poisonous.
For all its professionalism, I found it as cold as the ice rink at Rockefeller Center.
One of the best films of the year ...
Dench, Coogan and sure-handed director Stephen Frears ("The Queen") keep the focus on character, and in "Philomena" they've got an earthbound angel.
The ingredients are in place for a potent finale, but "Catching Fire" is watered down.
"Delivery Man" is stuck in the tow-away zone.
A love story so erotically charged that it short circuits our higher functions.
We get the predictable plot points - storms, sharks, close calls with passing ships - but it feels like a uniquely handmade artifact.

"Thor: The Dark World" spreads enough of the love to co-stars, set designers and special effects personnel to make us forget that the hero is just a glorified quarterback from somebody else's favorite team.
There's a lot of comic and fantasy potential here, but much of it gets squandered.
A blandly sanitized spectacle.
Injecting a dose of dumbed-down nostalgia into a certain smash comedy about four dudes on the loose in Sin City, this arthritic exercise should be called "The Combover."
Serious cinema of the globalist sort.

In its cross-cultural breadth, director Ridley Scott's smart and violent film merits comparison to Steven Soderbergh's "Traffic," but the dialogue delivered by the stellar cast is incomparably McCarthy's.
Director Greg "Freddy" Camalier augments the talking heads with unusually evocative vistas ...
There are very few good movies about journalism, and even fewer about computers. "The Fifth Estate" succeeds on at least the latter count.
This delightful debut feature by a Saudi woman named Haifaa Al-Mansour uses a bicycle as a metaphor for freedom within a social circumference.
When a celebrity chef like Rodriguez is just going through the motions, we can smell that the grindhouse fad is way past its expiration date. It's time to put a fork in it.
"The Summit" is an impressive achievement, but there's a good reason to ask whether cameras are turning the planet into a playground for the reckless rich: because it's there.
Shakespeare's play evokes the poetry of undying love, but this "Romeo and Juliet" is prosaic.
For those who appreciate fiery dialogue delivered by fine actors, "August: Osage County" is heaven-sent.
A middling showcase for rising star Aubrey Plaza.
"Ivory Tower" makes a persuasive case that the gravest epidemic that's spreading from college campuses isn't student-loan debt but attention-deficit disorder.
McCarthy and first-time director Falcone must have assumed that tossing a drunk and a dunce into a Cadillac would negate the need for a motive or even a script.
Crowe is effectively restrained in his acting, but in his debut as a director, he overdoes the manipulative music and the pretty images from cinematographer Andrew Lesnie.
With a stellar cast and seductive look, "Ex Machina" is a sleek contraption for capturing our imagination.
Starved of sufficient comedy or drama, "The Age of Adaline" is a pipsqueak.
While the movie sometimes seems like faux Fincher, the symbiotic acting, artful imagery and punchline ending turn "True Story" into credible entertainment.

"Monkey Kingdom" tugs our heartstrings to the top of the trees. With a lot of patience, and perhaps a little trickery, directors Mark Linfield and Alastair Fothergill have produced a simian "Cinderella."
Only an artist at the midpoint between the maypole and maturity could concoct a comedy as potent as "While We're Young."
Hawke's cinematic etude may not unlock all the mysteries of music, but "Seymour: An Introduction" is universal enough to be understood by a bananafish.
A movie about manufactured consensus would be a vital public service. But "Merchants of Doubt" isn't quite that movie.
Despite a debatable focus and dubious moralizing -money plays a pivotal role in the final outcome - "The Woman in Gold" works, largely because of the odd-couple chemistry between Mirren and Reynolds.
The lesson of this likable little movie is that it's never too late to reclaim your integrity.

The grunted catch-phrases, the implausible escapes, the plot holes the size of the Bonneville Salt Flats - it's all pitched at a particular audience like a dog whistle that fully grown humans can't hear.

Although the film got stuck in editing limbo for two years, no amount of cutting could rid the project of a diseased premise. Nor is it erotic or violent enough to be an effective critique of human nature.

"Age of Ultron" has self-aware laughs, grandiose themes and the best effects that money can buy. But at this point, it will take true vision to plot the umpteen sequels without getting trapped in a time loop.
When we scratch beneath the sugary surface, there's something tart inside that's difficult to digest.
As Viviane laments, this kind of thing wouldn't happen in America. True, but there's not an actress in America who wouldn't twist her hair into a bun for the chance to play this role.
movie_title: GETT: The Trial of Viviane Amsalem (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Director Abderrahmane Sissako, a Muslim from neighboring Mauritania, has made a movie that is worthy of comparisons on several levels to Terrence Malick's wheat-field tragedy "Days of Heaven."
Were it not for the five lines of recognizably human dialogue spoken by Miles Teller, this whole thing would implode into a black hole.
A well-executed thriller that leaves us stirred but not shaken.
If you're a fan of the "Taken" movies and tend to give action-hero Neeson the benefit of the doubt, our advice here is simple: Run away!
"Cinderella" is so scrubbed of personality, it's not even worth calling a mess.
Madden has stripped away the socio-economic context from the first film and turned the sequel into some kind of thinly rationed romantic comedy.
movie_title: The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel (2015)

movie_review_blurb: An entertaining tour of Tinseltown served with poisoned popcorn.
It's yet another reminder that if it's not called "The Sting," you shouldn't get too comfortable with a con-game movie.
Sports, and hockey in particular, were a propaganda tool for the communist system, which is richly illustrated here in archival footage and poster art.
The likably coy Johnson has no chemistry with the dreary, self-serious Dornan. He's a casting disaster ...
"Kingsman" is like a high-speed collision between a Jaguar and a jaywalking soccer hooligan. It's ridiculously out of balance, and when you're stuck in the middle, it doesn't seem so funny.
The audience gets a crash course in kreplach, pastrami and matzo-ball soup. Nothing fancy here - no tarragon top notes, says one of the interviewees - but big portions and good company.

The two fellows who managed the Who aren't so well known, but what they represent about their era - and the extent to which they documented it - makes "Lambert & Stamp" the cinematic equivalent of an ambitious double album.
This is Wiig's show, and connoisseurs of the comedy craft will flip for her.
While Black is painfully effective as the dork who drops slangy kudos on his new BFF, Marsden is a revelation.
"The Muppets," the troupe's first film in more than a decade, is a more aggressively absurd antidote to what it calls "a hard, cynical world." Happily, it works.
The "Star Wars" franchise has become what the marketing executive always thought: an excuse to steal money from children. The Lucas empire has finally succumbed to the Dark Side.
The technical wizardry of the action scenes are ultimately more important than the story and reason enough for nonbelievers to see and enjoy the movie.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode II - Attack of the Clones (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Long before you've gotten a nickel's worth of entertainment out of this dumb, unfunny flick, you'll be wishing for the flashing sign that says "Game over."
Although "Southpaw" has some punch, it's not exactly coming from left field.
This is a fully fleshed-out movie, the funniest of the year.
Everyone involved can proudly declare, "Honey, I shrunk the Marvel Cinematic Universe."
"Minions" is product, pure and simple. Little kids will love it, but grown-ups will feel like they're being held hostage in a Fisher-Price test laboratory.
As a story, it evokes a word that no battlefield nurse would ever apply to her experiences: sterile.
Director Anne Fontaine eroticizes her porcelain-skinned star but also adds some subversively feminist flourishes.
With stingy portions and plenty of filler, "Magic Mike XXL" is the worst sausage party ever.
This mash-up movie is like a greatest-hits collection for obsessive collectors. On its own terms, Terminator Genisys makes virtually no sense.
Because one man's mirth is another man's poison, this critic can only consult his belly as the barometer. On a gut level, "Ted 2" is a funny film.
As a bite-size lesson in loyalty and courage, it's a nice alternative to the too-many movies about a dog-eat-dog world.
Apparently, the focus of the movie was determined by whomever answered Nguyen's invites. Well, isn't that special?
Even without world-class smarts or amusing mutations, the next generation of "Jurassic" is an enjoyable ride.
With the overlong, limp and lazy "Spy," Feig has lost his mojo.
Pohlad has surrounded himself with award-worthy talent on both sides of the camera, from music supervisor Atticus Ross to the art department to the stellar cast.
On that vicarious-pleasure level, the movie version delivers. Yet for anyone with a sense of irony or social justice, it's also frustratingly soft around the edges.
Blessed with a stellar cast and idyllic locale, Crowe seems reluctant to waste anything, including his own half-baked themes.
It seems destined for a Hollywood remake, which is likely to be more polished but not nearly as weirdly charming.
movie_title: The 100-Year-Old Man Who Climbed Out the Window and Disappeared (2015)

movie_review_blurb: We need to have a dialogue about the wages of war in the remote-control era. But it's hard to spark a good dialogue with movies whose dialogue is so bad.
Not even a baby Einstein could follow this nonsensical plot, and even if your kids stay awake, the payoff is paltry.
This is analog filmmaking at its most daring.
"Felix and Meira" raises the question: Are we happiest with a twin spirit - or with a reverse image that completes the picture?
Second verse, not as good as the first.

Mulligan uses her beguiling smile to defuse the dramatic underpinnings of the story, and Sheen adds another shading to his gallery of great performances. But it's Belgian actor Schoenaerts who will leave the target audience atwitter.
Instead of a cinematic drag queen like the guilty pleasure "The Fifth Element," "Jupiter Ascending" is a mutant that's mostly dog.
In an homage to such "cinema of cruelty" classics as Andy Warhol's real-time "Sleep," Bay allows the film to run for almost three hours and abandons all pretense of a plot.
Even kids will smell something phony about the repeated cheers of "Teamwork!" And any grown-up who thinks the obvious puns are somehow clever or subversive has been smoking seaweed.
movie_title: The SpongeBob Movie: Sponge Out of Water (2015)

movie_review_blurb: For modern moviegoers, the earthy "Mr. Turner" may seem like slowly steeped tea with an unpleasant aftertaste. But while some are impatiently waiting for the paint to dry, astute viewers will see a cinematic landscape bloom.
In a poignant and potentially depressing film, it's redeeming to see that when they are with their kindred spirits, even the saddest skeletons can dance.
Liam Neeson has a particular set of skills, but choosing worthwhile projects is no longer one of them.
"Love Is Strange" is beautifully acted and bittersweet. It's a gentle reminder that modern love, like a houseplant, needs sunlight, space and attention to grow.
Although Driver is one of the hottest young actors in Hollywood, his character is so overbearing, he sandbags the whole movie.
movie_title: This Is Where I Leave You (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A coo-inducing movie that runs on autopilot without veering into the realm of bad taste.
While director Michael Roskam lays the groundwork for a heist thriller, "The Drop" is fueled by character, not plot.
With Winterbottom's first-ever sequel, his "Trip" films now rival ﻿Linklater's "Before" series in charting how a twosome evolves over time. Plus, they're bloody hilarious.
Although "The November Man" shows us some attractive people in motion, the cumulative effect leaves us neither shaken nor stirred.
As in the first film, there are judicious stabs of color ... And Alba is a showstopper in a fringed cowgirl outfit. But nine years wiser, we know that pretty things aren't always worth killing for.
movie_title: Frank Miller's Sin City: A Dame to Kill For (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The settings and supporting roles suggest that "If I Stay" started out as someone's passion project, but the final product only requires its star to sleepwalk through buckets of schlock.
"Land Ho!" is a tepid little movie that goes almost nowhere, and if I had to sit in that rental car for one more boob joke, I'd rather jump into a volcano.
Both the comedy and the violence are watered down by a dark melancholy.
A guilty-pleasure platform for Washington's slow-cooked, kick-butt heroism.

Largely thanks to the intoxicating scenery and the gorgeous natural-light cinematography, "Magic in the Moonlight" does weave its a spell, resurrecting the spirit of sturdier and more inventive movies by the same conjurer.
Perhaps the saddest thing about the film is the thought that nobody raised in Rich Hill could have made it.
The closest thing to a lived life that fictional cinema has yet produced.
If you're old enough to remember when sci-fi and comic books were fun, "Guardians of the Galaxy" will be your new favorite movie. If you're not, it will set a standard for everything you see.
If cranking out this kind of mediocre, head-scratching blarney is the only option available to Hollywood veterans like Reiner, we have some friendly advice: Open a haberdashery.
With such an empty core, it's hard to love "Lucy," but it's also hard to change the channel when it promises wisdom with just a spoonful of Vitameatavegamin.
"I Origins" has the genetic markers of a formulaic supernatural thriller, and it's marred by some muddy metaphysics and fuzzy science, but the beauty is in the details.
"Venus in Fur" is a stellar achievement.
For audiences seeking shelter from superhero carnage, "Wish I Was Here" is a lovely place to be.
Without the kindling of character development, "Planes: Fire and Rescue" is no smoldering success, but if Disney's flight plan is to share Pixar's airspace, it's getting warmer.
The most metaphorically and morally evolved film of the bunch.
movie_title: Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes (2014)

movie_review_blurb: "Life Itself" completes the circular conversation between the movies, the man and the masses.
Doggedly indie but unpretentious, "Begin Again" is one of the best movies I've seen about the music industry and the ways it changes people whose paths diverge.
Although the outcome is as predetermined as a prix-fixe menu, the storytelling is as smooth as goose-liver pate through a pastry nozzle.
"Annabelle" is so lazily coat-tailing on Roman Polanski, they should have called it "Rosemary's Barbie."
Ultimately what makes "Gone Girl" so watchable is the three-headed monster of Fincher, Pike and Affleck.

While the chronological details and social significance of the story Webb reported get shortchanged, "Kill the Messenger" is a vital reminder that a free press must be free to press the powerful for answers.
Young volunteers have been at war for 14 futile years, and the next Chris Kyle deserves to be understood.
Even with a third eye on your forehead and peyote in your bloodstream, you won't be able to follow this long and winding road any better than Doc does.
The message of the movie is as clear as Siberian ice: Whether you're a Tea Partier, an Occupier or just an ordinary Joe, you might be the next citizen who's stranded in limbo.

Like an alternate version of Network in which Faye Dunaway cannibalizes the conscientious William Holden character, Nightcrawler cleverly dispenses with any debate about the tyranny of ratings and the erosion of privacy.
Bluntly funny and ever-so-slightly sweet.
Cumberbatch is moviedom's man of the moment, and with this painfully human performance, the actor who has specialized in difficult geniuses finally cracks the code of compassion.
If you can take it, "Unbroken" will lift you like the classics of adventure cinema.
"Into the Woods" could have taken a well-worn path toward stagey sentiments, but those who worried that Hollywood might drain the enchantment from the Enchanted Forest can live happily after.
Granted, this series is primarily for kids, but nobody should feel dumber after watching a movie with "museum" in the title.
movie_title: Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb (2014)

movie_review_blurb: If you're willing to be thrown for a loop, you're in good hands with this medal-worthy cast and crew.
Whose story is this? There's an old saying that history is written by the winners. The screenplay for "The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies" must have been written by elves.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies (2014)

movie_review_blurb: For better or worse, this is an affluent American's view of the world, and in the post-mortem interview segments, director Marshall Curry does little to broaden the conversation.
Maybe the lack of answers is the point. How do you save your life by hiking 1,000 miles? By putting one foot in front of the other.

We have no idea. What's the point of a Moses movie without a message from the mountaintop? Scott has broken the second commandment of a Bible movie: Have something to say and someone majestic to say it.
"Horrible Bosses 2" is further proof that likable actors have to take an occasional sick day.
Although it doesn't make a lick of sense as a stand-alone story, "Mockingjay - Part 1" is the first "Hunger Games" movie with meat on its bones.
"The Theory of Everything" is a brainy bio that exerts a gravitational pull on the heartstrings.
This is epic cinema that begs to be compared to "2001: A Space Odyssey." But unlike Stanley Kubrick's psychedelic joyride, this journey is powered by a human heart.
"Glen Campbell: I'll be Me" is a gift, to its celebrated subject, who gets a final keepsake, and to its audience, which gets a ticket to our shared past and an insight into our shared future.

Although the characters don't lapse into stereotypes, neither are they sufficiently funny or fierce to engage us in the issues they raise. The movie is a windy debate, the kind that is suited for the safe confines of a college campus.
"The Blue Room" is the kind of film that demands to be seen more than once.
Sorry, Keanu, but you stole my time and you murdered my brain cells.

Sparks would be delighted if this movie were compared to his other story about reunited lovers, but compared to "The Notebook," "The Best of Me" is the coffee-stained outline of a sales pitch for sleeping pills.
Of course, Murray is the star attraction here, in a role that's both fan-friendly and reminiscent of the range he showed in "Broken Flowers" and "Lost in Translation."
In trying to be a big, important movie, "Men, Women & Children" is about none of the above.
One one level, "Pride" is as fake as a lip-sync revue, yet the emotions it arouses are real.
Despite playing with a stacked deck, "The Judge" is guilty of exceeding expectations.
A well-intentioned, white-perspective drama like "Black or White" isn't going to change the world, but it might change the terms of an overdue conversation.
It's amusing fluff, but from an Oscar-winning dramatist, this return to comedy is a bit of a letdown.
With stately surroundings and hissable villains, director Amma Assante imbues the finale with such dramatic resonance that "Belle" becomes a ringing proclamation of human dignity.
With its forked tongue planted loosely in cheek, this haunted-house flick is enjoyably retro in both style and substance.
From the first image of sensory awakening to the final acceptance of adult responsibility, it pulses with the warm blood of a very human hero.
Pine and the always-watchable Banks make the best of a bad screenplay, but "People Like Us" gives us nothing that we can relate to.
Like a cat nap, it gives us a brief, refreshing dream with little to remember.
It's guilty of some sleight-of-hand hokum, but in pulling the rug from under the norm, "Magic Mike" turns a trick.
"Brave" is easy to like but hard to love, a feel-good fable with the latest bells and whistles.
The problem with this nice-try comedy is the nice-guy protagonist.
movie_title: Seeking a Friend for the End of the World (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Like a train, "I Wish" is slow to build momentum, then it carries us away in a wondrous rush.

"Abraham Lincoln: Vampire Hunter" is a blast, the best action movie of the summer.
Through the documentary lens, Richter's enigmatic paintings speak to us.

Forced laughter is the only kind you'll hear during "That's My Boy," between the long stretches of slack-jawed silence.
These are critically important issues, but it needs a sharper point to get through thick skulls, and even evolved humans who are tired of the treadmill of progress might ask: What else is new?
As a sex-education comedy, "Hysteria" is flaccid, forced and unfunny.

Phonies may complain that Anderson's island of misfit toys is a retreat from the real world, but for pure-hearted adventurers who share the secret map, "Moonrise Kingdom" is a joy that cannot be eclipsed.
Aping Stanley Kubrick's "2001: A Space Odyssey," Scott and his screenwriters have designed this towering puzzle to provoke debate, with liberal allusions to gender, race and religion.
The easygoing posture and strong casting keep The Intouchables from stumbling over vexing questions of race, class and disability.

"Come Back, Africa" is most effective as an ethnographic documentary, with cinema verite images of white privilege and black poverty.
"Goodbye First Love" is like a postcard from a lost Eden, a painfully pure oasis where we're not allowed to linger.
movie_title: Un amour de jeunesse (Goodbye First Love) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: "Men in Black 3" is all surface but, as with the moon, the surface can steal our attention
For someone (like me) who has never been to a ballet, the talent of these teens and tweens is a revelation.
Like a Teutonic techno band, this thriller is both skillfully familiar and chillingly strange.

A world of wonders without a guide or an agenda, "Samsara" rewards a leap of faith.

The fire that stokes the story is violence. Yet despite some gruesome images and the psychotic fervor of Rakes, it's a frustratingly slow boil.

Watching "Killer Joe" to the bitter end is like playing the Pick 6 lottery and getting three of the numbers right. You don't win anything, but you still think you're smarter than all those other idiots.
Although this Swedish vehicle is thoughtfully engineered and has some vivid streaks of color, it could use a jump start to escape the vanilla ice.

"Hit and Run" isn't a catastrophe, but it leaves loose ends and a more adventurous map by the side of the winding road.

Kids are too smart to fall for it, and any grown-up who thinks that "The Odd Life of Timothy Green" is funny or heartwarming has a head made out of cabbage.
movie_title: The Odd Life of Timothy Green (2012)

movie_review_blurb: In different hands, "Elena" might have been a noir thriller, but this serving of cinematic borscht is as cold as a Russian winter.

Only an audience as constipated as these characters could mistake this lukewarm stream of pablum for a hard nugget of truth.

On its own terms, "Neil Young Journeys" is an enjoyable concert film of a solo show in Toronto, interspersed with memories of his Canadian boyhood.
If this movie wanders into your neighborhood, the only watch that will hold your attention is the timepiece on your wrist.

"The Best Exotic Marigold Hotel" is an Indian dish for day-trippers. Lacking beef or sufficient spice, it's nonetheless colorful comfort food.

Persons' short quasi-documentary doesn't offer specific solutions to toxic modernity, but the film itself is a temporary fix for fallen spirits.
"The Conquest" is like a French restaurant that serves small portions of tart appetizers and calls them freedom fries, yet begrudgingly we must salute the gall.
"Act of Valor" is a competently directed action movie, but forcing the audience to wear such narrow goggles is a dereliction of duty.
"A Separation" is a plaintive fable of the human condition that unites us.
Even by the standards of light entertainment, "This Means War" is meaningless.
While other stars of his generation stoop to self-parody, Washington stands tall. We cannot tell a lie: Yes, he makes us nervous, but in a good way.
Anyone old enough to have read Jules Verne or seen the way his work was successfully adapted in the past will suffer worse than the kids in the audience who just came to laugh.
With its broad strokes, this invitation to an important discussion is hard to ignore, but the blood and honey on the table is an unpalatable mix.

With such a large and likable cast, the whales are a relatively small part of the movie. But the wonder of "Big Miracle" is that their fate can make a cold-hearted audience blubber.

"We Need to Talk About Kevin" is confrontational cinema that will leave you speechless.

Biff! Bam! Boring!

"Coriolanus" is a triumph.

Apted skillfully weaves old footage with the new, and we become poignantly aware of another factor shaping their lives (and our own): biology, as the we watch the once-cute kids grow gray and heavy.

Goro Miyazaki has a style that's both more painterly and more cinematic than the cartoonish norm, while his father's screenplay is a classic coming-of-age story that seems suited for a live-action remake.
Hallstrom makes the mishmash palatable, and romance mainstay Duhamel provides some sweet-and-salty charm, but there's not much they can do with Sparks' canned dialogue and Hough's undercooked acting.
This world is divided between the makers and the takers, and after just a few minutes of "Red Dawn," you'll realize there's not much more you can take.
Spielberg is legendary for his visual feasts, yet he serves us this turkey with no relish. There's scarcely a memorable image in the entire film.
It's not a good film, but viewed from a cockeyed angle, it's a great guilty pleasure, and director Bill Condon is in on the joke.

movie_review_blurb: There's weighty material waiting to be processed here, but in "Little Red Wagon" it doesn't have a home.

In this poignant movie we meet four Chinese-born teenagers who are living with American parents from Berkeley to Boston.

movie_review_blurb: Aiming for a middle path between drama and comedy, "The Way Way Back" is so overloaded with jokes that it could sink in the water hazard, but on the final scorecard, sure enough, it's in the hole.
"The Other Son" is such a disarming feat that cynics will get left at the checkpoint.
With its fool's-gold cinematography, over-emphatic musical score and self-important protagonist, "Simon and the Oaks" is a puny acorn that dreams it's a towering achievement.
Granted, both directors have been adrift for the past decade, but even someone with water in his ears should have sensed that this script needed a rescue.
"Cloud Atlas" is superior filmmaking. Yes, it runs almost three hours - but you've probably seen 90-minute films that felt a lot longer.
Befitting the title, there's little nutritional value, but there's a bit of sweetness inside the throwaway wrapper.

Resurrects the spirit of Middle Eastern fables, albeit with a French twist.
Formulaic serial-killer crapola ...
The derivative script and skimpy effects don't convey either the power or the problems of being a young witch.
Loud, incoherent and unfunny, "Here Comes the Boom" is the sound of American culture imploding.
Before he was a Middle Eastern studies major, Ben Affleck dreamed of directing a movie that mattered. "Argo" is his dream come true.
Some audiences might feel that "Frankenweenie" is creaky, but those on the same wavelength as Burton will gratefully declare it's alive.

movie_review_blurb: "The Oranges" is a watered-down dramedy with little sense of place - or human behavior.

Going deep without resorting to trick plays, the sure-handed "Silver Linings Playbook" scores on every possession.

This movie is a bloody mess if I've ever seen one.

movie_review_blurb: Angelina, here's something to remember next time: It's better to tell us one story that makes us feel than a thousand stories that make us numb.
Leave it to Hollywood to make a movie called Radio that would play better on TV.
Scary Movie 3 is even funnier than the first two.
Lara Croft is pure popcorn, lighter than air and a little bit greasy. And the rare summer sequel that's even more fun than the first.
movie_title: Lara Croft Tomb Raider - The Cradle of Life (2003)

movie_review_blurb: There's a lot of hand-to-hand action, just like a video game, that gets harder as you move up a level. Also, like a video game, there is no story. You have no idea who is fighting whom. Or why.
Eastwood tells the story simply, barely moving the camera. The only special effect in this film is genius.
These stars not only light up the screen, they generate enough electricity to light up Times Square. Movies just don't get better.
Just when you think you can root for the deckhand, he becomes mean and abusive.
I felt sorry for Mr. Heston.
Charlotte's Web is absolutely one of the best films of the year.
Save some of those Kleenex for The Pursuit of Happyness.

I started crying when I was writing this review. It is a tough movie. You are going to cry, but I urge you to see it. And when was the last time you saw or read something that made you feel positive about the human race.
You'll laugh, you'll cry, you'll get a ticket for doing 70 in a 45-mile-an-hour zone. It's that kind of a movie, and the real feel of the racing footage is absolutely spectacular.
There is a great movie in A Prairie Home Companion, which is based on Garrison Keillor's long-running radio show. Meryl Streep gives an amazing performance as a country singer.
No gore, no death-defying screams and not too many scares either.
V for Vendetta, based on a graphic novel, is sabotaged by its second half, which is more like V for vacuous. By the end, it's 1984 meets The Phantom of the Opera.
In a lame attempt to amuse older teens, She's the Man manages to alienate the parents of the younger ones with tampon jokes.
The situations in this sitcom never get as funny as they should.
Good Night and Good Luck will make my 10-best list. It's unquestionably one of the best films of the year.
I love movies about movies and this is one of the best.
Phillip Seymour Hoffman must be nominated for his uncanny portrayal of Truman Capote. It's frightening and fascinating.

How to Deal would be a terrible movie anyway, but here are seven reasons parents with children under 13 years old might want to practice due diligence: sex scenes, the F-word, teenage pregnancy, teenage death, tobacco use, alcohol use, drug use.
This film could earn eight Oscar nominations. It's so much fun. Let's go see a movie where you smile, and cheer ... and tap your feet a little, too.
White Oleander is one of the those movies you watch and think, "Yeah, I bet the book was great."

Seabiscuit starts slow, finishes fast, not an eye without a tear, not a throat without a lump. It jumps out of the gate as a front-runner in the race for Hollywood's Triple Crown: best actor, best direction and best picture.
This is a genius romantic comedy.

The worst thing I can say about this movie is that it's so smart, so deep, so well done, it might be too good for the teenage boy-audience these films are usually aimed at. Then again, that might be the best thing I can say about it.
X-Men works because it isn't about the effects. It's really about being different (in this case, a mutant). That's why it resonates so with its adolescent fans.
Analyze That is even funnier than Analyze This.
Even with Vin Diesel's help, Knockaround Guys got knocked around a few times too many.
There's great storytelling - some of Hollywood's best ever. The story takes jaw-dropping turns.
The best review I can give a drama or an actor: When the film ends you still believe the character lives on.
I'll say two things about an Oscar nomination for Julianne Moore for best actress: for sure and at least.
It plays long but it all works because everyone has so much fun.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl (2003)

movie_review_blurb: When you have time to think these thoughts while you're watching $100 million+ explode on a screen, that's one more sign the movie doesn't work.
It's no divine comedy, there's no real revelation, but the funny bits are up there with Jim Carrey's best.

This purports to be a modern version of the Doris Day-Rock Hudson Pillow Talk comedies but ends up being a big snore.

I wanted more jokes. But I'm never tired of watching the star.

The film isn't the least bit erotic, or prurient - or even interesting.
Ultimately, it's a suspense thriller in dire need of more suspense and more thrills.

Very well done.

What sets this fluffy, ultimately enjoyable trifle apart is that it doesn't make a big deal about its cross-cultural cast. The characters are presented as individuals, rather than sweeping representations of a group or race.

Despite the conflicting statements on faith and religion, revenge and forgiveness, and sex and love, the divergent arguments are ultimately part of the ramshackle grace and peculiar charm of this modest, frequently-satisfying film.

Coffee Date has lots going on, and its message -- there are all kinds of love - is an earnest one. But the script relies too heavily on stock characters and overused plot devices to make any real impact.
A sentimental valentine to a man who, underneath it all, simply wants to move people with his message.
The real problem is that none of the character arcs are taken any further than a basic outline.
The film's first half is an uneven string of scenes that offer little setup and sometimes confuse.

Grease: Live was a success -- with its game cast, classic songs, seamless transitions, moving camera, quick changes and, above all else, energy.

Complete Unknown is perhaps most titillating when it quietly observes moments between its central duo, two long-lost lovers hurling nearly two decades' worth of unresolved pain at each other over the course of a single evening.
If no one's listening, you must build a platform and shout, and the women behind Equity have done just that.
An ideal movie for Internet conspiracy theorists displeased with the powers that be, though Gibney deserves credit for doing more than just fanning the flames of paranoia.

The hows and whys of the quest at hand aren't exactly important, as Central Intelligence is far more concerned with squeezing its leading men together-often literally-and kicking back to enjoy the juice, and that's a wise move.

Zookeeper is a lighthearted, harmless afternoon at the movies for the hordes of families that will be drawn to it like lions to a straggling zebra. As a casual filmgoer, however, the film's shortcomings will disappoint.
You can't endear when you're subtly insulting, and Miracles From Heaven's otherwise good intentions are lost in its confusing mix of uplifting spirituality and judgment.

The kids come off like little spokesmodels, or aliens, and if not for Long's implausibly patient but good-natured Suzanne, there wouldn't be a recognizably human character in the film.
It isn't pretty, but for all the melodramatic hoohah of Verhoeven's latest, it all feels pretty real.
Pink is the new black, 50 is the new 30 and, at the movies, confusion is the new suspense.
Alain Resnais turns this multi-character tale of misspent love into pure cinema, transforming the physical world into a symbolic statement about divisions, distances and separation anxiety.
There is invaluable material here, but also a lack of context for the wonderfully outre footage.
movie_title: Jack Smith and the Destruction of Atlantis (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Fido, which feels original despite borrowing from a half-dozen genres, shouldn't be taken too seriously.

Paced like a drama, imbued with a spellbinding intimacy, and impressionistic in its visual portrayal of crime and punishment, it follows the 2002 murder of Francois Chenu, a gay man beaten by Nazi skinheads and left to drown in a nearby pond in Reims.

Refuses to embrace the fashionable elements of torture porn that are currently cutting a bloody swath through the horror genre, relying largely on psychological terror to impart the sense of someone possibly going mad, and taking the viewer along.
It's still relatively early in 2007, but this wry comedy about sheep gone baaaaad promises to be the best vampire-flesh-eating livestock movie of the year.
A film that is a combination immigrant/resurrection tale, Visitor tilts toward the soulful rather than the political and could be this year's humanistic indie hit.
Where pic goes astray is in turning anonymous, indigenous peoples into ducks at a shooting gallery.
In the endearing musical time-piece Honeydripper, the indie icon [Sayles] lets his narrative gifts take the lead and the social issues follow like a tight bass line.
A lunatic, Twin Peaks-like meld of black-comedy soap and Z-grade horror flick that looks like an instant cult item.
Director Craig Gillespie keeps things moving along at a brisk clip, without doing anything particularly distracting or stylistic.
Honigmann's subtle asides -- moody cuts to mournful statuary, insects crawling over tombs -- all speak to her art-is-immortal theme.
Braun and his team manage to make this knotty situation lucid and palatable. Darfur Now could conceivably make a difference in enlisting people to the cause.
No one involved will benefit from their association with Babenco's ambitious but failed effort.
Can a movie be an adrenalin-fueled, blood-gushing thrill ride and still be as boring as dirt? Apparently.
Trade is as gripping as it is important.
The acting's good, the camera work is haunting and [director] Fessenden continues to build his image as the thinking person's creepmeister.
A sometimes funny, occasionally maudlin coming-of-age dramedy that wants to be Goodfellas but might have been called Mild in the Streets.
If Paul Verhoeven hadn't produced Black Book last year, Lust, Caution would have seemed like its own subgenre, the eroto-feminist spy thriller.

Production values are tops, and Lukas Ettlin's athletic camerawork -- coursing through the streets of Boyle Heights and other Los Angeles locations -- adds a kinetic element to a film that is half thriller, half psychodrama.

This rational, human and very serious documentary by Daniel Karslake gets at the historical distortions of the Good Book as well as the ease with which holy writings have been used in America to propagate hate.
movie_title: For the Bible Tells Me So (2007)

movie_review_blurb: There's not quite as much corn in The Final Season as there is in the Iowa farm fields that run through it, but it's close.
Yes, plenty of things fly at your face, but they're not the only things worthy of interest.

Jacques Vergès had defended a lot of people, and it's his Zelig-like journey through the politics of the postwar 20th century that is the contentious subject of Barbet Schroeder's unwieldy, unforgettable film.
movie_title: L' Avocat de la Terreur (Terror's Advocate) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The big question is whether Harper's one-woman film creates a memorable character out of a woman with whom many audiences will be very familiar. The answer has to be no.
Khadak makes the most of Mongolia's vast horizons and swallowing space, the grandeur of emptiness, together with precisely composed pictures, making the whole thing seem like one of Bagi's visions.
The performances are all good, and there's enough history in O Jerusalem to float a boat of refugees.
The film moves from truly creepy to truly inane.
[Director] Bier is graceful, observant of small details, but her efforts to mine a greater meaning through the camera than Loeb has put on the page is a fruitless endeavor.
movie_title: Things We Lost in the Fire (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Unlike Hanks in Big, there's little consistency to [Garner's] character.
Beset by bad lighting, limited visual imagination and acting so wooden it might have termites.
movie_title: Sarah Landon and the Paranormal Hour (2007)

movie_review_blurb: ...profoundly confusing In Bloom arrives at some very tenuous moral conclusions that might alienate much of its supposed target audience.
Gurwitch examines what it is about being sacked that gnaws so angrily at the American mentality and how a country that once held the promise of lifelong employment now offers perpetual insecurity.
Such an elegant enterprise you might say it has gossamer wings.
movie_title: In the Shadow of the Moon (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A sometimes laugh-out-loud send-up of homebuyers' worst instincts, the extreme behavior of real-estate agents and what happens when the certifiably insane save enough for a down payment.
Doesn't go very far beneath the surface, or ask many provocative questions.

[Director] Cassavetes shows genuine, even original, talent in the way she creates emotional connections between camera and character, via fluid movement and unhinged perspective. But the advantage of having Posey as her lead shouldn't be underestimated.
Shot with remarkable confidence and an understated eloquence.
... amid the slo-mo furniture smashing and cheese-wizardry is a movie in touch with its inner lunatic.
Ira and Abby is launched with an infectious elation, a no-guts-no-glory take on love that's joyous...
Far less cartoonish than, say Pirates of the Caribbean 3. And its characters are the most poignant, and convincingly human, of the summer.
In addition to statements about urban anonymity and the cult of beauty, writer-director Kim is also making a mordant statement about love, the kind you can get lost in while losing yourself.
What were they thinking? Simple: They weren't.
movie_title: I Now Pronounce You Chuck & Larry (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Based on the popular German comedy Mostly Martha, it doesn't leave a bad taste. It doesn't leave much taste at all, save perhaps for the cloying echoes of Velveeta cheese.
The failure of world conscience haunts The Devil Came on Horseback.
Where Caddy really shines is in the supporting comedy ensemble, which acts like a demented Greek chorus, tossing out bits of incongruous dialogue that hit the funny bone more often than not.
For all its blather about 'letting your spirit soar,' it's really about furthering an MTV-defined version of cool, which means too many clothes, too little education and too much money.
[Rosario Dawson] could have provided a 100-minute closeup and revealed more about human nature and anguish than all of Descent.
Everything but the enchanted kitchen sink shows up in the sprawling fairy tale Stardust.
A beautiful, strange film, deeply moving and no surprise from [director] Majidi.
Daddy Day Camp suffers all the near-classic sequel handicaps.
Delpy's script is less a tale than it is a series of character-revealing snapshots, so the personalities are all we have to work with. And they are not personalities that wear well at feature length.
Guedes is electrifying, and so un-Hollywood you have to cheer for the continuing health of Brazilian cinema.
If you still need an argument about global warming, the documentary -- makes a good one.
Like Altman's Gosford Park, Oz's film is an organism comprising intersecting oddballs...
Amusing diversion.
Despite the occasional gleam of wit, very little is to be taken seriously -- not the story, not the acting and certainly not the history.
Hawke does some nice things with the camera -- the film has style -- but what it doesn't have is the essential thing you need in a drama. Namely, drama.
Quiet City often attains a floating, poetic buoyancy that pulls a fast one on gravity.

Auds will experience the joy of discovery in Greco's fact-based drama -- not just in its perspective on schizophrenia and the effect of the disease on one Florida family, but in Joe Pantoliano's cliche-demolishing performance.
...painful, funny and honest, and the tone Garlin achieves is steady and true.
movie_title: I Want Someone to Eat Cheese With (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Marilyn Hotchkiss' Ballroom Dance & Charm School is like a first date who shows up at the door with flowers, candy, a blood test and a U-Haul. It's trying much too hard.
movie_title: Marilyn Hotchkiss Ballroom Dancing & Charm School (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Moody pictures, swollen music and portentous dialogue are all great, but they need to have a narrative propping them up.
A passionate, harrowing drama about rebellion, atrocity and child soldiering in Africa, Ezra is raw and violent.
Part of Mini's charm... may be in its single-minded devotion to the utterly depraved and comically debauched.
A sturdy, concise, no-nonsense documentary that should hit screens as soon as possible.
movie_title: Factor 8: The Arkansas Prison Blood Scandal (2005)

movie_review_blurb: A comedy that's a mix of Mean Girls, Mamet and Mephistopheles.

[Director Andre] Techiné always locates a steadfast emotional element in the worlds he creates, a defiant human construct against unstoppable change. In Changing Times, it is love, in unfamiliar forms.
Mostly, MSEG is one of those movies that make you ask why: Why was it made? Why did Uma Thurman waste her time? And, most important, why is there 10 bucks missing from my pocket?
Overdone and overlong, but its lunatic flavor -- check out Joe Odagiri's Tiny Tim as ninja sadist -- saves the day.
If one is interested in seeing everything that's wrong with movies today -- from cynical marketing to the creative poverty of contemporary screenwriting -- Tucker provides one-stop shopping.
[Russo] has created such an inflammatory piece of clumsy propaganda it's hard to take his best arguments seriously.
By the end ... audiences will need mass manicures.
It's a rough-hewn film, more interesting, probably, to those who've actually made it through a meal there, but fun and maybe even inspiring.

A doubter's parable, the film's story is built on one ironic juxtaposition after another and told in a manner so devoid of irony, that one begins to wonder how the filmmakers could keep their balance in such a gale of metaphysics. But they do.

Jarecki certainly thinks his subject deserves such an accolade, and he's made a great-looking film to make his case, one that is edited gracefully and briskly -- and leaves the heady aftertaste of birthday cake.
Sloppily directed, often amateurishly acted and fixated on booty and blood, Snoop Dogg's Hood of Horror is nevertheless gleefully disgusting.
Being an urban dance movie, guns make their appearance, along with every stereotype about hip-hop or the young. Don't believe the hype. Just watch them dance.
Amid all the might-have-been cliches, director Ryan Fleck and his co-screenwriter, Anna Boden, give us a movie about history and destiny.
If David Lean and William Faulkner had ever collaborated, and brought in Henry Moore to do set design, House of Sand might have been their troubling brainchild.

The Trouble With Men and Women doesn't illuminate anything, including the compulsion among some filmmakers to recycle the hoariest romantic situations, in the presumed hope that a charming cast might save the day.
movie_title: The Trouble With Men and Women (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Unfortunately in this New York, no crisis is insurmountable, and no upscale downtown restaurant is deprived of product placement.
It is an indispensable treatise on Western hegemony and capitalist plunder -- as seen through the troubled history of the Congo.

[Idlewild] achieves magic -- something sorely missing from so many movies these days -- and does so via a philosophy of respect, but not reverence, for what's come before it; it never recycles, it just reimagines.
The most convincing and engaging of the six features Edward Burns has turned out since The Brothers McMullen.
In Princesas, [writer-director Fernando León de Aranoa] leaves too many loose ends hanging about, but his sentiments are noble.
[The film] deals with a number of subjects -- age, parenthood, estrangement, generosity -- all guaranteed to have you reaching for your hankie. So bring three.
movie_title: Riding Alone for Thousands of Miles (2006)

movie_review_blurb: What Douglas Sirk did for big-budget Hollywood melodrama in films like Imitation of Life, Andrew Bujarski is doing for the low-budget indie.

[The] pic feels overlong because once it's established that this is going to be a tasteless, if occasionally hilarious, exercise in social criticism, the movie needs to constantly accelerate the level of hilarity, which is impossible to do.
A frothy lark with a decided sense of the outrageous, sincere affection for its characters and their romantic plights.
movie_title: The Mostly Unfabulous Social Life of Ethan Green (2006)

movie_review_blurb: What Woods achieves in his arch, velvet-cushioned vignettes is a sense of the subjects being reduced to symptom and diagnosis.
A beat-driven, inspirational organism that develops and blossoms along with its subjects.

Likké should be applauded for tackling a subject that's bristling with socio-political thorns and raises some provocative questions, particularly about what we find attractive in other people and why.

I Am a Sex Addict is a sophisticated and open baring of one man's soul. And quite a few other things.
In terms of entertainment, the movie is consistently amusing, often hilarious, and energetic in its editing.
Not only are slasher/horror/splatter films enjoying a sharp spike in popularity, right now they're also where one can find the best comedy.
Despite the ungainly script and direction, the climactic performances -- including one by young singer Anny Jules --absolve the movie of most of its sins.
Kinky Boots shoehorns what should be a fresh story into the same old pair of narrative galoshes.

[Anton Chekhov's The Three Sisters'] egacy of stifled dreams and inter-familial anxieties are as relevant as ever. Updating it, however, should involve more than adding incest, lesbianism and the uncontrolled venting of spleen.
The much-honored Australian dramedy Look Both Ways may be the type of film that provides a purifying rain just when its beleaguered characters need it.
Pic is targeted at the already initiated, but directors Steve Cantor and Matthew Galkin deftly resolve one often glaring problem with tribute documentaries -- making those who might not care do so.
movie_title: LoudQUIETloud: A Film About the Pixies (2006)

movie_review_blurb: An indelicately titled but inventive, energetic fable about reconciling reality and roaring egos, it is a movie almost totally reliant on well-developed character, quick-witted repartee and mercurial relationships.
As Emily's tale rolls out, it does so in fashion devoid of cliche and convention, toying with time and portraying a heroine who provokes contempt as easily as empathy.
The perfect summer movie -- fast-paced, action-packed, emotionally engaging (without demanding too much investment), and pure, unadulterated eye candy. Whattya want for 10 bucks?
A princess with a curse, a case of mistaken identity and some of the worst special effects in a film by a world-class director.
movie_title: The Promise (Master of Crimson Armor) (Wu ji) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Less, however, would have been considerably more.
Saving Shiloh, the third in the dog-hero trilogy drawn from the Phyllis Reynolds Naylor books, may be naive and narratively simple, but it's prime fare for the always underserved family aud.
A movie full of contrivance and confection.
Less captivating dramatically than anthropologically.
Loss is a big part of 12 and Holding. So is identity. But its scope is much larger, and its echoes far more resonant.
Several things are missing in Shem, most apparently a consistent tone of voice.

[Robert] Baer's Tocquevillean tour is a spare but indispensable political-cultural exposé of a country and region poised to play an increasing and increasingly troubling role in the history of our own.
movie_title: The Cult of the Suicide Bomber (2006)

movie_review_blurb: To resort to strictly ethnocentric references, Fanaa is equal parts MGM extravaganza, Shakespeare lite and James Bond. In their heart of hearts, isn't that what movie audiences really want?

You'll be exhausted when it's over, but harbor a lingering sense of vicarious accomplishment.
Neo Ned may be ludicrous on paper, but it has what fans of independent film are looking for -- atmosphere, humanity and just a dash of fantastic drama.
Synthesizes aspiration, resignation, anonymity, celebrity, opportunity and denial into a portrait of something far beyond the immigrant experience.
The results, while a bit overlong, are engaging and real.
A fable, and as such carrying few surprises, Opal Dream features solid acting and likable characters.
Less rocking on and better jokes would have made Tenacious D seem more than just tenacious.
movie_title: Tenacious D in The Pick of Destiny (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Easily the world's most influential living filmmaker and one of the greatest in cinema history, Bergman reveals himself here in a manner previously available only through his movies.
movie_title: Bergman Island (Ingmar Bergman - 3 dokumentärer om film, teater, Fårö och livet av Marie Nyreröd) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: The dialogue is truly painful. The situations are so contrived they make "SpongeBob" seem like a nature documentary. But what's more annoying about Minors, is the calculation behind it.
Capably narrated by Kevin Costner, Ever Again is a mixed bag, briskly edited, good-looking but suspect in some of its logic.
Director-writer Hobbs, making his feature debut, walks the lip of the campy abyss in this deliberately theatrical rendering of the disturbed mind.
Eastwood may not be a primarily political filmmaker, but his celebration of men fighting a lost war is timeless, as well as urgently topical.
It's really the Norton-Watts show, and they make The Painted Veil resonate with love and regret.
The script by Hanif Kureishi is smart, witty, understated and fits O'Toole to a T.
In her restraint, Chernick makes us admire an artist with none.

Although Freedom Writers is the latest in a long line of saint-saves-students stories, it takes the bold approach of being earnest, honest and unafraid to be called naive. As a result, it's extremely affecting.

Director Les Mayfield can only do so much with the anemic, obvious script by Robert Adetuyi and George Gallo. And while his limited action sequences are very solid, this is a comedy, and within it he doesn't do much for his actors.
Freedom Writers takes plenty of shots at the system, too, and makes the quite righteous statement that only through individual effort does anything wrong ever really get changed.

A bit paint-by-numbers, not to torture a pun out of all this, but when the story of Beatrix Potter, spinster book author and happenstance feminist, eventually does take shape, it is an emotionally and even politically potent story.

Arthur and the Invisibles makes an excellent case against casting animated movies with celebrity voices. There are people who make their living as voiceover artists, and they would have been infinitely better than the lackluster Robert De Niro.
movie_title: Arthur and the Invisibles (Arthur and the Minimoys) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Fairly ludicrous, utterly predictable chest-beater about a black university obsessed with step-dancing, Greek letter life and romance.

Molly Shannon's bittersweet portrayal of its lonely canine-loving heroine, along with a passel of pups trying to steal the picture, make for a satisfyingand funny, if ironic, comedy intended for lovers of both the beast and/or sophisticated laughs.

The young black faces are too beautiful, the landscapes too pretty, and the personal stories of slaughter too scripted to excuse War Dance from trying and failing to make Westerners feel less awful about horror, genocide and global negligence.

There are too many distracting elements to allow a viewer total immersion in the story.
[Douglas] is a manic joy, and Wood manages to hang on for the ride.

Immediate, urgent and cinematic,

Auds will respond, either to the uplifting message and the solid action sequences.

A unusual and potent portrait of the Filipino undersoul.
