Offers a few salient notions about the nature of human sexuality, but matters are ultimately stretched further than a sumo wrestler's bra strap.

movie_title: A Pigeon Sat on a Branch Reflecting on Existence (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Who among the great filmmakers has put the workings of the human psyche front and center and made it so intellectually engrossing? Hitchcock? Bergman? Maybe, but I really can't remember laughing very much at Vertigo or Persona.
An intelligent, emotionally honest and satisfying film.
movie_title: Me and Earl and the Dying Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Senese has made a convincing, slightly campy contribution to genre cinema. But he's also struck a blow against stupidity.
Tarpits of treacle and swamps of sentiment seem to await anyone reckless enough to drive such a vehicle as far as a script meeting. Yet it's largely true. And it rings that way.
Riklis is a director of enormous grace and handles the various character dynamics with sensitivity.

Not only one of the more entertainingly human fantasies to come out of the studio, but it also defies the bedrock fanboy aesthetic that you don't want to merely watch the superhero-you want to be the superhero.
McKellen is masterful, in a multilayered tale that navigates the no man's land between memory and fiction.
Smart, antic comedy that's eager to offend.
Surprisingly entertaining, highly informative and honest.
A commercial for Legos.
"Samba" tries to be too many things to too many people, although you can't say it doesn't have heart.
Provocative, profoundly moving and the acting is virtuosic.
While it dwells in a much darker realm than American humor generally ventures into, what it uncovers is worth a stare. Maybe even a shudder.
Revelatory biography of Rosenwald, whose beneficence made him an influence on much of 20th century American life.

While she can make static cinema as well as anybody in the boys club -- Hot Pursuit is solid evidence of that -- Ms. Fletcher also monkeys with the conventions enough to make one wonder what kind of mischief she could ultimately commit.
Mr. Johnson isn't out just for blood, or sociology, but the clever hybrid he creates is wholly entertaining.
While Bette Gordon may be a filmmaker of daring and a painterly hand, the eternal truths of Handsome Harry are finally what hold us.
Disturbingly excessive, but perversely funny and emotionally roiling.
Sturdy, moving, nostalgic in a good way.
Gripping, mournful, suspenseful.
As a movie about a guy who lived life the way he wanted, it will win certainly fans. It should win some for its execution as well.
Entertaining, over-the-top and more than a little anxiety-inducing.
Suspenseful, wonderfully acted, emotionally jarring.
movie_title: GETT: The Trial of Viviane Amsalem (2015)

movie_review_blurb: That money is the root of all evil is hardly news, but Kenner's documentary is more than just a plaint against corruption. He is, for one thing, a first-rate filmmaker.
Fascinating, funny, heroic, moving and may even make hockey fans out of nonbelievers.
A chance encounter, a missed rendezvous, a marriage and a torrid affair make for an intoxicating mix.
Unusual, intelligent documentary whose subject is a pleasure to spend time with.
Less than propulsive as a narrative, but provocative, instructive, consistently surprising and a kind of slow-motion thriller.
There are plot twists, to be sure, and some very polished filmmaking.
Everyone has a least favorite bad dream, and Hook's may be yours: the nightmare of being hopelessly lost in a place where time has stopped and hope has vanished.
Good-natured look at the virtuoso workhorses of classic rock and pop.
Visually voluptuous, though the pacing occasionally suggests watching a Pre-Raphaelite dry.
The ostensibly inanimate objects are far more animated than most movie stars.
Levin, in an effort to appease an American sensibility, has taken sophisticated subject matter and made a movie for children.
Pacino's exuberance rescues Dan Fogelman's directing debut from the schematic snares in Fogelman's script.
Lightweight script doesn't help a grandiose premise.
Astounding performances by Binoche and Stewart, in a film that keeps the viewer constantly off-balance.
Okay, it's hooey. "Adaline" is not a documentary. What it is, though, is seductive.

Mr. Morgen is perhaps the leading revolutionary in American documentary filmmaking, a collagist/synthesist extraordinaire who has channeled Mr. Cobain's physical legacy ... into a work of art completely his own.
A slightly sourish cocktail of bad behavior, wry observation, and commentary on how difficult modern life can be, especially for characters who feel entitled to a better one.

The film is a work of craft, from the actors like Mr. Downey, who can deliver a comic line with the timing of a mouse trap, to the editors, Jeffrey Ford and Lisa Lassek, upon whom so much of the movie's very elegant fluidity rests ...
Stunning imagery and a stirring story, about Sebastiao Salgado and his 40-odd years of shooting global catastrophe.

While Losing Control is a thoroughly likable, playful comedy, there's never a sense that writer-director Valerie Weiss is in total command of film's tone, pacing or comic content, which is considerable.

Swim is, among other things, a movie about sisters, who actually seem like sisters...This may seem like a small thing, but it's an aspect of filmmaking that's ignored often enough to be noteworthy when it's not.
Douglas Tirola's pic seems a bit late for the poker craze, and at any rate will be preaching largely to the converted.
Rodanthe is the Death Valley of erotic illusion.

Rob Brown's performance in the title role is solid and static, but Dennis Quaid's portrayal of coach Ben Schwartzwalder provides a convincing metaphor for a nation going through a crisis of conscience.
The pacing is too pokey by half, and the payoff is a wrenching disappointment.
Yet another vehicle in which Simon Pegg can play yet another of the world's more obnoxious humans. And still make us love him.
movie_title: How to Lose Friends & Alienate People (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A far more intelligent movie than the ads might make it seem.
Oliver Stone doesn't do comedy, intentionally. But perhaps he should: The half-baked, hayseed Hamlet he's created in W. feels alive only when it ventures into the comically absurd.
Days and Clouds serves as a primer in coping with depression, financial and/or personal. But it is stirring, serious and, ultimately, mercifully optimistic cinema.
Mark Wahlberg, who has proved himself a very capable actor, seems to have nominated himself for the Russell Crowe Lack of Charisma Award, and is running a pretty convincing campaign.
Should cast a spell even in a tone-deaf theatrical marketplace.

Convinced that Arab terrorists are inherently hilarious, and that shooting fish in the leaky barrel of American pop culture takes marksmanship, Boll is a boor, and a symptom of something sad and dehumanizing.
If actor Ryan Reynolds isn't careful, he's going to parlay his good looks and engaging presence into a full-time job as a game-show host.
Although a minor work by Chabrol, it would be a major work by most directors, and one that's still fascinating even in its flaws.
movie_title: La Fille Coupée en Deux (The Girl Cut in Two) (A Girl Cut in Two) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Comedy and chemistry make for an intoxicating mix in this acerbic, knowing character study from Czech director Jan Hrebejk and screenwriter Petr Jarchovsky.
Streetwise, kinetic and solidly dramatic.
This John Cusack-driven exercise in scorched-earth political comedy is neither as dark nor as timely as intended, and certainly not as funny.
A very darkly humorous film.
The film is an enlightening recap of '50s Red Scare politics, and a parade of actors giving meaningful, earnest readings of Trumbo's speeches and letters.
It is, however, such a spectacular-looking movie, as shot by cinematographer Zhao Xiaoding that it is, to use that old cliche, worth the price of admission.
HSM3 is eminently watchable, occasionally very funny, and sweet enough to give you diabetes.
Intelligently directed, beautifully shot (by Declan Quinn) and takes what has come to be an unorthodox approach to the writing of screenplays: It assumes the audience isn't made up of idiots.
A film lacking in dramatic propulsion and actorly grace from Clint Eastwood, a director usually synonymous with both.
With apologies to all the flat-screen salesmen and mail-order movie companies, it isn't a film to be seen anywhere but on the largest screen available.
Spare, effective and genuinely frightening.

Robbie Cavalina and Ian McCrudden's loving tribute to the great singer orchestrates archival footage, late-in-life interviews and some spectacular music into one of the better bio-pics of recent years.
movie_title: Anita O'Day: The Life of a Jazz Singer (2007)

movie_review_blurb: All of Salina's interviews and data tell a graphic story about corporate water piracy, the complicity of governments, the burden put on the poor and the scam of bottled water. But she can't quite jam it all in and still have a film that, well, flows.

As elegant in its storytelling as in its story, Carlos Sorin's The Window is a tale of age and mortality that firmly resists the 'cute' tag reflexively assigned to movies with old people, and mines a rich, deep vein of melancholy and humor.

Director Tony Leondis and screenwriter Chris McKennna have mined everything from Young Frankenstein to Sleepy Hollow to Japanese anime to the German Neo-Expressionists to create that rare thing, a cartoon for adults.
How many thrillers could put the outcome in the title and still provide as many white-knuckle moments as Harvard Beats Yale 29-29?
There's a precision to the visual ornateness of Hellboy II that exceeds even that of its predecessor.
Probably has the highest screams-per-capita ratio in the history of action-adventure pics, and a better thrill-per-minute deal than most.
movie_title: Journey to the Center of the Earth (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Prendergast seems clueless that an excess of pure weirdness won't lead to an excess of laughs. It won't.
Smartly scripted, convincingly atmospheric morality fable in which Hartnett, usually insubstantial as a good guy, plays a convincingly flawed character galloping toward the precipice.
Tough, brutish prison drama with an easy windup, but good acting and an uncompromising take on the prison system.
Dramatically, however, Take consistently works, and, with such a story, that's an amazing thing.
It makes the viewer uncomfortable, too -- but it's unquestionably honest, like so much of Hip-Hop.
The way the film marries its subplots will keep audiences off balance, which is exactly right for an X-Files movie.
movie_title: The X-Files: I Want to Believe (The X Files 2) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Nothing is revealed here, save for the sad fact that while young people's appetite for nonfiction film was supposed to be whetted by reality television, nonfiction film instead has turned into reality television.
[A] lush, bold, intellectual treatment of the Evelyn Waugh novel about Catholicism and nonconformity, which ventures where the fabled '80s miniseries couldn't.
Seesawing from the gleefully stupid to the desperately stupid, Step Brothers is an indicator that the Judd Apatow juggernaut has made one too many trips to the well.

This well-crafted documentary about the purported theft of the 2004 presidential election could well be the feel-good movie of the summer -- after all, it absolves the general public for everything that happened.
Holdridge shows talent, as do his leads, but along with money for popcorn, bring patience.
movie_title: In Search of a Midnight Kiss (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A film that might be called stubbornly magical.
With very little sex and very little city, The Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants 2 still seems a good bet to grab a sizable chunk of the underserved chick-flick demographic.
movie_title: The Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants 2 (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Touching, wonderfully acted examination of the corrosive effects of doubt on love.
A winning cast and a magnum's worth of subplots make Bottle Shock extremely watchable, perhaps a bit fruity, with grace notes of leather, oak and no ham.
It's a wingless exercise, despite a rather heartening attitude toward space travel that will introduce young auds to the glory that was NASA in the '60s.
The most fantastical plotline can be a perfectly convincing movie, but in Cthulhu, the acting is so emotionally unhinged and erratic it borders on camp.
The House Bunny is a blissfully broad comedy that should catapult Anna Faris into a singular kind of stardom.
Brilliant melding of first-person footage, heart, and directors Tia Lessin and Carl Deal's documentary expertise.
There are few movies out right now more genuine than this Cinderella story.
It's sweet, no doubt, but a bit too slick for its own good.
Smartly supernatural, and featuring sensational performances by Ricky Gervais and Tea Leoni, Ghost Town is a Topper for our times.
Like a mouthful of honey, The Secret Life of Bees is cloyingly sweet and gooey, and you're not quite sure you can swallow it undiluted.
It's a film that works through guilelessness and cynicism.
A winning Stateside debut for beautiful Indian actress Shriya Saran.
movie_title: The Other End of the Line (2008)

movie_review_blurb: There are moments of comedic fire that justify the presence of the two stars in the film, and us in the theater.
Typical tale of self-discovery, punctuated by genuine hilarity and top-flight animation.
It is a profoundly indulgent work -- what three-hour filmed memoir wouldn't be? -- but the memory of Auder's memory will linger on for the handful of resilient experimental-film fans who see it.
The future of vacuous action movies is clearly with the likes of Cena, humans who resemble characters from video games, albeit without the acting chops.
Adventureland may be targeted at teens, but it's a sophisticated film that just happens to be about unformed people and their raw emotions.
Director Peter Chesholm does a fine job moving Hannah out of its $14.95 Disney Channel set and onto a bigger canvas.
Lymelife is well told, superbly acted, recalls some of the truly banal pop hits of the late '70s and hardly ever digresses from the genuine. It's a pearl among zucchinis.
Given that the ordinarily likable Seth Rogen is portraying a delusional, violent, sexist, racist, homophobic mall cop with a bipolar disorder, there's not really a lot to laugh at.
American Violet is a justice story, with some honest justice. It's nicely reassuring that it happens to be true.
For all the utter phoniness of Fighting... [it's] not so bad.
The beauty of the landscape, the beauty of the animals, it's all irresistible.

A nihilistic, narcissistic, knuckleheaded move about nihilistic, narcissistic knuckleheads, The Informers might have been an interesting exercise in satire, if it only had a sense of humor. Which it doesn't.
It's their reminiscences that are the most poignant and revealing about a man who seems, in Cooper's interviews, to have done all he could to conceal himself.
Spends much time spinning its wheels and making auds practically beg for an explanation to all the madness and obsession.
Wolverine is full of angst, and yet it has virtually all the humanity wrung out of it in an effort to create a live-action cartoon.
Auds, regardless of their politics, will find Kirby Dick's filmentertaining, brisk, visually interesting and perhaps even thrilling.
An urban nightmare with a surfeit of soul, "Precious: Based on the Novel 'Push' by Sapphire" is like a diamond -- clear, bright, but oh so hard.
movie_title: Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire (2009)

movie_review_blurb: What the movie is supposed to accomplish -- laying out a fairly complex mystery in a way that creates suspense -- is precisely what it doesn't do.

Darker, grimmer and more stylistically single-minded than its two relatively giddy predecessors, "Terminator Salvation" boasts the kind of singular vision that distinguished the James Cameron original.
Less of a comedy than a hilarious tragedy.
We live in desperate times. But no one's desperate enough to laugh at Dance Flick. Which is sort of encouraging, no?
A screwball comedy for the New Depression, "The Brothers Bloom" makes an abundant number of erudite references that mean almost nothing, and, like most con-man movies, it can't be trusted.
Director Christophe Van Rompaey has a script, of course, but much of what comes across so eloquently in this Flemish comedy of ill-manners is wordless.
Vardalos is charming.
A movie that takes a major step toward reasserting Murphy's place as the comic heir not just to such obvious models as Richard Pryor but to Groucho Marx.
Does for the supermarket what "Jaws" did for the beach -- marches straight into the dark side of cutthroat agri-business, corporatized meat and the greedy manipulation of both genetics and the law.
Tetro has no internal tension and should have been a comedy.

Adams and Blunt are a great team and provide Sunshine Cleaning with nearly all of its potency, pain and emotional payoff, as sisters trying to avoid their own tragedy while cleaning up the mess of others.
A jewel of a film in conception, execution and message.
Even though I Love You, Man supplies plenty of cringes, it also has overtones of warmth and undertones of real humor, and two stars -- Paul Rudd and Jason Segel -- who do what they do with aplomb.
Very little that anyone here says, or does, has the slightest connection to any known reality, and if a film is going to perform an autopsy on love, the corpse should at least be recognizable.
Yet another attempt to revisit a sorrowful event in history that should never be forgotten or used for entertainment.
movie_title: The Boy in the Striped Pajamas (The Boy in the Striped Pyjamas) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A spectacularly moving and elegant movie, and to dismiss it into genre-hood, to mentally stuff it into the horror pigeonhole, is to overlook a remarkable film.
[An] anemic sequel.
Stars Dustin Hoffman and Emma Thompson are so disarmingly charming that even the most treacly moments work an emotional magic.
It's hard to resist: Here's a battered superstar who has occupied so many fantasies, but in his fantasies he's just like us.
Watch Lola Montes and you may never watch a movie the same way again.
Approaching the blues with the enthusiasm of an overcaffeinated brass band, helmer Darnell Martin nonetheless makes some kind of music with the percolating '50s biopic Cadillac Records.
Gore-drenched actioner is guaranteed to draw fans of wretched excess like moths to a nuclear holocaust.
A high-tech animation adventure with a top-flight voice cast and a well-told if familiar fable about power, peace and people getting it together.
It's a beautiful film, but in the end, Despereaux is esthetically charmed but dramatically inert.
Imagining someone other than the beatifically battered Mickey Rourke in the title role of The Wrestler would be like picturing someone other than John Malkovich in Being John Malkovich.
A rock-solid biopic with a foolproof rise-and-fall storyline and a warmly nuanced performance by Jamal Woolard as iconic rapper Christopher Wallace.
A chihuahua-sized concept served up in a doggy bag of contrivances and shtick.
If Chandni Chowk to China were a person, it would need Valium.
Barker takes structural chances, eschewing the predictable for a more unorthodox film, and it works.
What needed to be a taut, structurally sound psychothriller instead malfunctions from the start.
Waltz With Bashir, a movie about memory, is as devious and subversive as it is brilliant and nightmarish.
Has "cult hit" written all over it.
You can see where this is going all the way from Duluth.
For all its virtues, Wendy and Lucy seems like the most overrated of art movies.
A not-quite-romantic-comedy that should click with the young-adult demos of both sexes.
movie_title: He's Just Not That Into You (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Rebecca is the Lucy Ricardo of profligate spending.
Isla Fisher is carrying this often stylish comedy on her Prada-upholstered back.
The Class is not just the best film released thus far this year. It may be the most gripping.
The Cuban Missile Crisis is a year passed and the assassination is looming, and yet Adam's pubescent crises are given Wagnerian emphasis.
Overall a raggedy, unfocused affair that wastes both directors' acting talent and feels like too much work between the laughs.

What's wrong here is that there's so much swirling, relentless action, indistinct robot characterizations and over-caffeinated techies loose on the special-effects machines that the movie, in mere seconds, achieves incoherence.
Pic's condescending attitude toward its subjects won't help its already limited commercial chances.
Where it's going all seems predetermined, but the visual journey is lovely, Robbie Ryan's camera turning even council-housing London into something optically enchanting.
Order of Myths looks good, and its characters are memorable.
Vaguely magical, insistently modern fable that could become an arthouse hit, even a cult fave.

With about as much documentary credibility as Borat, Where in the World Is Osama bin Laden? combines low comedy, high production values and the Middle East for what will surely be a hit, even as it delivers nothing new.
movie_title: Where in the World Is Osama Bin Laden? (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Results are somewhat inspiring, but equally predictable.
The story itself is a hodgepodge of devices, conceits and half-baked motives, but amid the dissing and the dancing are affecting moments, usually quieter ones, between people at war who shouldn't be.
It's a funny film, a parable of sorts, and a character-driven take on what's ticking in China.
Popularity of the two stars could make the film an arthouse hit; they're a joy to watch.
It's the acting and the nearly faultless script that make Strangers a winner.

Helmer Bernard Shakey -- a.k.a. Neil Young -- has constructed a chronicle of his old band's Freedom of Speech tour of summer '06 and come up with an aud-friendly, activist musical that seems sure to raise both political ire and major bucks.

What one observes via Reed's portrait isn't that Orbinski is defiant of danger, but that his sense of decency is so strong it over-powers any fear. Which is a considerable accomplishment, in a film that deserves wider exposure than it's likely to get.
A pleasant enough diversion, but DC will be bettered watched from the horizontal position of a couch, one to which the film seems all too eager to send you.
An American Soldier doesn't pander or judge, and as such will make itself palatable to a much wider audience than a war doc might otherwise.

Stranded: I've Come From a Plane That Crashed in the Mountains is an oxymoron: a docu constructed from re-enactments, talking heads and no actual footage of the story it tells, but that still packs a knock-out punch.
movie_title: Stranded: I Have Come from a Plane That Crashed on the Mountains (2008)

movie_review_blurb: An irresistibly joyous, tearful and, most importantly, musical doc about a band of senior pop singers.
A gentle, tender-hearted portrait of a devout young Jew with Down syndrome, Lior will not be for everyone, ...but its messages of family and love are pretty seductive.
Co-writer/director Mike Clattenburg is right on target with his trio of inept trailer-park criminals.
None of it makes sense -- logically, emotionally or dramatically.
A courageous scab-ripper of a tale about slavery, white privilege and original sin.
movie_title: Traces of the Trade: A Story From the Deep North (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Aspires to so much it ends up being less than the sum of its parts.
Ultimately, The Hottie & the Nottie is no worse in many ways than a lot of teen-centric comedies, which generally appeal to their audience through cruelty and vulgarity.
That two of the three scribes responsible for Fool's Gold have previously specialized in horror makes perfect sense.

There are moments of performing brilliance in Vince Vaughn's Wild West Comedy Show: 30 Days, 30 Nights -- Hollywood to the Heartland; there is enough intimacy with the characters that we care about what happens.
movie_title: Vince Vaughn's Wild West Comedy Show: 30 Days & 30 Nights - Hollywood to the Heartland (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Releasing a movie on Valentine's Day can mean only one thing and, yes, Definitely, Maybe has it in big fragrant bouquets. Love, heartache and dollops of schmaltz.
In a movie about perception, misperception and the ramifications of misunderstanding, it's a bit ironic that the directors can't get out of one another's way.
A gloriously cinematic doc of epic, poetic sadness.
A relentless, I-thought-my-eyeballs-were-bleeding exercise in visual disorientation.
There's very little that rings true.
In Yu Hong (Hao Lei), the film also has a vibrant heroine.
Although Greenwald has made a fairly lighthearted film, replete with playful graphics and humorous digressions, it does prompt some serious reflection on what college sports are really all about.
Certainly stage-bound and dusty, but it's a perfect vehicle for Davies the aesthete/social critic.
Gorgeous, visually and musically.
movie_title: Note by Note: The Making of Steinway L1037 (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The film looks so good it could play without sound.
When the most intriguing thing about a film is the production design, you know you're in trouble.
Some may think the Holocaust has nothing new to offer up, but Michele Ohayon says otherwise.
P2 struggles to maintain its momentum because there's simply not enough to do in a parking garage to fill out a feature film.
Both too literal and too thorough.
movie_title: Love in the Time of Cholera (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Less a documentary than a sales pitch.
This Rob VanAlkemade film has a good title and no focus.
I'm Not There takes its audience across a Rubicon of moviegoing disillusionment, apathy and sloth: If you are, as you say, so tired of the old, then here is the new. Embrace it, or please shut up.
All a goof. Revealing the pragmatic side of the CG-assisted filmmaker, [director] Gens makes a movie that seems entirely computer generated.
A tortured talkfest with a premise far less ripe than its title.
"With a few words, I could change the world," says a pugnacious charmer named Alex; with a few pictures, Hold Me Tight, Let Me Go is trying to do the same.
movie_title: Hold Me Tight, Let Me Go (2008)

movie_review_blurb: This entertaining and passionate documentary about the obscure jazz singer Jackie Paris tells the tale of an extraordinary voice and a self-destructive genius.
movie_title: 'Tis Autumn: The Search for Jackie Paris (2007)

movie_review_blurb: In this, the third in his 'lonely man' trilogy, [writer/director Paul] Schrader's reach exceeds his grasp, but his intentions are interesting, and the artifice he creates contributes to the otherworldliness of his Washington.
A movie already reputed to be hipper than tomorrow night, Jason Reitman's follow-up to Thank You for Smoking is actually sweet, romantic and irony-free.
Tony n' Tina's Wedding picks all the Queens-Long Island clichés, rolls them into a ball, and then throws what's probably more of a spare than a strike.
There's a lot of sap in this Christmas tree.
The question of love after death has been asked frequently enough in the movies, but seldom with the high ick factor found in P.S. I Love You.

If pic's B.O. potential seems slight, the same can't be said of the film's impact on awareness of Africa, altruism and the lifelong misery caused by reparable medical conditions in areas where the closest road can mean a three-day hike.

[Director] Epstein's opinion on the issue is never in doubt and once the attitude of the film is established, it seems to make the same points repeatedly. Fortunately, Epstein herself gets pregnant, and she gets to test her own theories.
Clever enough to keep adults entertained, even if the story is something of an antique.
movie_title: The Pirates Who Don't Do Anything: A VeggieTales Movie (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The overall sense is of a movie coasting on an obvious and somewhat flimsy premise, to which no one thought to bring much else besides Nicholson and Freeman.
The results are exhilarating, expertly choreographed and a movie to change one's view of both cinema and life.
The question regarding Vantage Point is how this thriller with the Groundhog Day fixation was allowed to meander out of Columbia Pictures so overloaded with bad acting.
What The Cool School does so well, through its color accents and black-and-white photography...is impart a sense of discovery.

One can only hope that Witless Protection is targeted at a vanishing species of American Neanderthal. In the meantime, perhaps Larry and his accomplices at Lionsgate could take some sensitivity traning.
A worldly, knowing look at adult affairs.
movie_title: A Good Day to Be Black & Sexy (2008)

movie_review_blurb: What may be the first real outsourcing comedy, Baby Mama is like a pacifier: floppy, nourishment-free and may even keep your teeth from growing in straight.
Deal is perhaps too briskly paced: The narrative moves along a bit too fleetingly for any genuine character development.
If it manages not to lose its assets while dipping its toe into murkier issues -- becoming, say, a brow-knitting thumb-sucker -- then it's really a work of art; such is Guest of Cindy Sherman.

A blackly comic take on the first totally outsourced war? We're too close to being in one right now, which makes this John Cusack vehicle too close for comfort. It's also so close to being funny you can just about taste it -- just about.
The film is well-acted, a broad colonial allegory, and again, visually gorgeous.
What Happens in Vegas contains enough unbridled silliness to salvage its lowbrow high concept.

Despite the occasional detour into mawkishness, "A Previous Engagement" nicely balances unutterable truths about marriage and love with the comedy that is human interaction and the unending drama that is man and women, repulsion and attraction.

Terra isn't sugar-coated -- the humans are hardly paragons of virtue, but neither are the Terrareans. And the story's resolution won't make Terra the feel-good cartoon of 2008, although it is a work of art.
Prince Caspian has the same problems as its predecessor: a C.S. Lewis story line rendered anemic, and a cast of sweet but unengaging principals.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: Prince Caspian (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A beautifully made film, one that possesses a troubling visual sense of spiritual corruption.
The grimy elegance of this Sundance award winner elevates it well above the standard-issue immigrant drama.
Suffers from, if anything, a lack of pure confidence in the story, the actors or the audience.
A film crying out to be discovered by midnight movie mavens.
The performance-enhancing quality behind this muscular movie is director Chris Bell's willingness to go far beyond the call of duty.
Stuck is genuinely suspenseful and grotesque. It may make you wonder why anyone thought it had to be made, but it is absorbingly macabre.
This computer-animated DreamWorks film is infectious and inspiring, despite one's best efforts to resist its charms.
Director Tucker's virtuosity is in marrying Blake's memories to the present and finding they are one.
movie_title: When Did You Last See Your Father? (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The best thing about Children is the cinematography by Zhao Xiaoding (Hero, House of Flying Daggers), which is so distracting because it so out-classes the rest of the movie.
Bold, epic battle-happy movie that humanizes the world-conqueror and gives him plenty to be aggressive about.
What's missing from the payload is surprise.
A lot of the comedy seems to have been lost in the translation.
While they might have had their ups and downs, the subjects of Chris & Don are a testament to fidelity.
The portrayal of employment in America is too close for comfort. Or comedy...Not the stuff of lighthearted summer comedy.
A movie that is as happily warped and enthusiastically disturbed as the rest of [director Guy] Maddin's eccentric cinema.
Overacted and overblown, pic will underwhelm commercially, with theatrical perhaps limited to friends and family.
The atmosphere created by director H.S. Miller is gothic, tortured, stylized yet tinged with a classicist's sense of composition, symmetry and, yes, perspective.
Mike Myers is anti-comedy . . . that is, if one presumes comedy ought to be smart, new, surprising or, yes, funny.
A work of art on the order of a poem by Yeats or a painting by Rothko.
movie_title: Le Voyage du Ballon Rouge (The Flight of the Red Balloon) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Obvious, plodding, cloying and politically innocuous.
City of Men tells a multilayered story coherently, with propulsive action and a naturalistic nod to the fact that so much of the world is a violent place.
Anyone willing to tolerate the tortured premise of the story will be paid off handsomely by several winning performances and a moral that makes most of the absurdity worthwhile.
There are enough good stories for three movies in Lucy Walker's Blindsight, an exhilarating trip with six blind Tibetan teenagers as they scale one of the highest peaks in the Himalayas.
Fighting for Life is briskly paced, and there's often a palpable, appropriate sense of disorientation parlayed through the roaming p.o.v.
Not that we expected much, when all is said and done. But College Road Trip ran out of ideas just after they came up with the title and had the inevitable meeting.
Simply an ingenious way of constructing a good film out of virtually nothing.

No elevating moments, but a few of pure mirth: "In my world," says one of the film's furry woodland creatures, "everybody's a pony, they eat rainbows and poop butterflies ... " Now that would be something to see.
movie_title: Dr. Seuss' Horton Hears a Who! (2008)

movie_review_blurb: While the movie's star -- and ruler, and ship's captain, and grand poobah -- is Haneke himself, his actors are sublime.

In The Witnesses, [director] Techine levels his gaze on the '80s, an era of seeming innocence, perhaps license, and one in which biological freedom has led to a loose, even sloppily knit fabric of humanity.

The human body can't do or withstand the things this movie claims it can, and one can only hope that pic's probable success doesn't trigger a dramatic rise in schoolyard body-slams, arm locks and chokeholds.
What, after all, is Snow Angels? It feels like a comedy at first and is often blackly comedic, but it also reflects a universe in which each human spins alone.
Insensible.
movie_title: Dao huo xian (City Without Mercy) (Flash Point) (Fuse) (The Signal) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Whimsy and the macabre are the operating systems in Just Add Water, and they're not always complementary.
It's a remarkably entertaining movie, thanks in part to a first-rate cast and a director who knows you can't make a point without calling everyone to attention.
The Year My Parents Went on Vacation seems to be about, in the end, is big-time sport as the opiate of the masses.
movie_title: The Year My Parents Went on Vacation (O Ano em Que Meus Pais Saíram de Férias) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Cool School is a must for anyone interested in 20th century American art.
It's a bit late in the game for Superhero Movie, which was never going to fly, and barely crawls.
It may not be what you expect. But with Wong Kar-wai, it seldom is.
While S&D101 is not quite [Heathers], it's a return to something closer to the caustic wit of which [Daniel Waters] is capable.
There's a flatness about the whole enterprise -- like drinking champagne, but from an old house slipper.
Architecturally sound, emotionally ravaging.
It concludes in a way that will have you asking whether the ending was misguided, or maybe it was just the rest of the movie.
The director has created a not-to-miss gem for the discriminating viewer.

Just showing us what ex-sitcom stars and Bavarian directors do in their spare time isn't quite enough to justify The Grand, which does for poker what Best in Show did for dogs while completely avoiding any jokes about poker-playing canines.
Hou Hsiao-hsien's first French-language film shows why the Taiwanese master is considered one of the world's great filmmakers.
movie_title: Le Voyage du Ballon Rouge (The Flight of the Red Balloon) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Kunis is not just Peter's savior, but the saving grace of a comedy that is really a series of sketches, a few of which sparkle, and most of which you'll soon forget.

For all the elasticity of the form, Anne Fontaine's Girl is still a cloying bit of business, rarely very funny and never smart enough to make a solid point, at least about anything we don't already know.
movie_title: La Fille de Monaco (The Girl from Monaco) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Although a first-rate investigative documentary on its own, Andrei Nekrasov's Poisoned by Polonium also serves as a sequel to 2004's Disbelief.
movie_title: Bunt. Delo Litvinenko (Poisoned by Polonium: The Litvinenko File) (Rebellion: The Litvinenko Case) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Despite the advances humankind has made since dragging itself out of the primordial ooze, Shore is a successful comedian.

An overweight loner, a goofy sidekick, the school siren -- you can write the script yourself, all about an insecure teenager adrift in a sea of adolescent anguish, blahblahblah. And yet, that's not quite what happens.
The less one knows about this perverse thriller from debuting director Nick Tomnay the better; a full appreciation of its delights lies in its revelations.
More soap opera than high drama, the film is confused and confusing, and tedious to boot.
The film follows too many tangents, including film editing, sound and the purportedly evil effects of rock lyrics, to adequately consider any of them.

Fans of the subject matter, especially students of the Beat era, will find this revisionist reconstruction indispensible; others will share the same tedium claimed by some of the principals on the bus.

Director Larysa Kondracki's debut film is unsparing in its portrayal of sexual trafficking in a supposedly civilized world. But it's valiant, too -- especially regarding Rachel Weisz's performance as reluctant crusader Kathryn Bolkovac.
A hell-on-earth thriller that makes valiant gestures toward geopolitical savvy but gets bushwhacked by vet helmer Renny Harlin's weakness for the Rambo-esque.
The human element of the film is so weirdly distracting it often deflects from its primary target.
Ned turns out to be a strangely moving figure, a comic foil worthy of affection, perhaps even respect.

The film is almost distractingly beautiful to look at, something that accentuates the tension between the film's conflicting quantities, i.e., the glories of the physical world, and the corrupted humanity it hosts.
Mr. Nixey is doing an Alfred Hitchcock homage within a movie lacking anything as subversive, or skilled, as Hitchcock.
movie_title: Don't Be Afraid Of The Dark (2011)

movie_review_blurb: This is a movie about longing, desire, desperation and the abandonment of principle -- quite a collection of themes, all universal.
There are movies you want to like that just won't let you.
One could hardly make an honest movie about Gainsbourg that wasn't as recklessly ambitious as this.
A delicious thriller that gets under the skin à la "All About Eve," albeit with a twist: The craft here is still theater, but of the workplace rather than the stage.
Some of the action in "Detective Dee" is computer-generated hallucination, some is just good-old life-threatening stunt work, but it is almost always a thrill.
movie_title: Detective Dee and the Mystery of the Phantom Flame (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Destined to rank as one of the major achievements in American documentary, the Paradise Lost project comes to a presumed end with Paradise Lost 3: Purgatory.
A potent comedy of genetic chaos.

Watching Limelight, about the rise and politically engineered fall of onetime Manhattan nightclub kingpin Peter Gatien, is like looking through a family album: If you're in the family, you might be interested.
Compensates for a lack of revelation with portentous music and a rather ham-fisted narration by the actor Peter Fonda.
What's refreshing about Oka! is its aversion to any kind of cliches.
We've seen this kind of thing before; it was old when Bill Murray did it in Meatballs.

The type of film with which Mr. Ratner has claimed to be infatuated is itself like a caper -- it requires precise execution. "Tower Heist" is more like that 10-story Snoopy, as he drunkenly bobs along Central Park West.
It's ... unworthy of Mr. Stölzl, who amid all the facile antics does manage to show his directorial mettle, if only in a single and critical scene...
Mr. Farina has never been more in control of his "instrument," as actors like to say, or more convincing.
movie_title: The Last Rites of Joe May (2011)

movie_review_blurb: At 157 minutes, "Transformers: Dark of the Moon" isn't just a movie. It's a sentence.
Something is lacking in the dramatic equation.
You wonder who thought any of this was funny.
An ambitious revue film with a two-pronged mission: making Western audiences laugh and exploring why Mideast audiences might not.
Bernstein is made a complicated, even morbidly fascinating figure in a film that will have limited theatrical exposure but, like the director's earlier work, will likely enjoy a cultish afterlife.
movie_title: I am Secretly an Important Man (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The performances are fun, if musically only adequate -- there are no evident virtuosi languishing within Angola's walls -- and Chiarelli's attempts to frame matters philosophically fall a little flat.
A likely cult hit among horror fans and a gleeful affront to more delicate sensibilities.
The very idea of this movie suffers from a form of myopia that simply can't be overcome. And, of course, all would be forgiven, if only the thing were funny.
Its bubbling optimism and spectacular scenery are hard not to like.
"Hanna" is, on a certain level, ridiculous. But the way Mr. Wright conjures his images and parcels out his narrative is hypnotic and so seductive that wherever the film is heading we want to follow.
A moving, engaging and revelatory IMAX attraction with two heroines and a crowd of charming beasts.
A bracing courtroom drama whose every scene seems wreathed in mist, dust motes and cigar smoke, the better to suggest a nation befogged by grief.
Sex, drugs and rock 'n' roll get a markedly downbeat spin in Roadie, helmer Michael Cuesta's take on youthful dreams gone out of tune.
Bracingly original, alarming and droll, the righteously ribald Rid of Me should prove a breakthrough for helmer James Westby and his producer and leading lady, Katie O'Grady.
A celebration and a lament -- a celebration of Channing's seven decades as musical comedy star, and a lament that there's really no one like her anymore.
A rollicking, violent, Western-cum-comedy that serves many masters, but adds up to an entertaining hot pot of wry political commentary and general mischief.
The film is accessible -- and funny -- enough to attract a wide aud, sports-minded or not.
A wedding movie that may have viewers rooting for divorce lawyers.
Real people may not be this glib and witty, but Rosen and Lister-Jones sell us on Casper and Becky nonetheless.
[A] rather affectionate and candid portrait of a singer/TV personality whose continuing respiration is regarded as a marvel of human achievement.
A very likable cast and some terrific sketch-style comedy should please (if not deeply satisfy the lustful yearnings of) auds lured by the film's title.
Offhandedly charming, if a bit labored in its eccentricity.
A charming, affectionate and often elegantly executed study of teenage magicians, their craft and the social shadows they step out of when they do their stuff.
One of the more convincing, radical and politically volatile docus to come out of the burgeoning good-food genre.
Performances range from wooden to hysterical, and it's largely due to Mulroney's inexperience behind the camera.

Too deliberately eccentric to attain quite the level of wigginess it aspires to, Jesus Henry Christ does feature some standout perfs and a refreshingly unconventional approach to telling its slight story.
Technically accomplished but dramatically unconvincing.
Despite all this boilerplate gangster-with-a-heart-of-gold stuff, there's an emotional payoff to Joe May that feels solid and right.
movie_title: The Last Rites of Joe May (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Michael Winterbottom's The Trip is about 20 minutes too long, but the other 90 are among the funniest in recent memory.

A battle ordinarily requires two sides, yet this earnest, ungracefully reconstructed saga posits that opposition to the building of the New Jersey Nets' future home took place in a virtual vacuum, and that the fix was in from the start.
If you can't dazzle 'em with brilliance, baffle 'em with genre baloney -- and enough shoplifted visual trickery to fill Quentin Tarantino's kitchen sink.
A raggedly charming indie with a strong central performance by Julia Garcia Combs amid a story set in a (literally) crazy Hollywood.
The results are not only funny and fresh, but represent a new way of tackling the whole yuletide paradigm: Santa as a high-tech hereditary monarchy.
"Safe House" is a sturdy enough thriller, but one that consistently defaults to the less interesting of its two lead characters.
With Mr. Harrelson, Mr. Moverman has created an antihero of epic proportions and indiscretions.
The island locale rings with reggae music regardless of its proximity to Jamaica, and any action sequence is rendered in painfully deliberate slo-mo.
"Star Wars: Episode 1 -- The Phantom Menace" got dismissive reviews in 1999, and it deserves the same today. But you probably know that.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode I - The Phantom Menace (1999)

movie_review_blurb: It's the kind of story that will stir the heartstrings, and even, quite possibly, those of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts & Sciences.
It is Mr. Kinnear's slippery charm that keeps "Thin Ice" from sinking into the frosty Wisconsin slush toward which it seems to be heading from the start.
A sturdy vehicle for unadorned morality and pragmatic justice.

The gay coming-of-age story's been done, but "Pariah" has something fresh to say, largely about the knotty complexities of love, and how they might keep someone in the closet: How badly do you need to be free, to hurt the people you love?
Olnek's sensibility is singular, and the work of the cast -- notably the sweetfaced Haas and the hilariously robotic Ziegler -- make for a movie that seeks, and earns, affection.
movie_title: Codependent Lesbian Space Alien Seeks Same (2012)

movie_review_blurb: [A] fascinating if not entirely revealing portrait.
movie_title: Ain't In It For My Health: A Film About Levon Helm (2013)

movie_review_blurb: While Girl Model falls a bit short in the delivery of hard facts and incriminating evidence, it more than makes up for that with its knotty psychological profile of Arbaugh.

Whether the glass is half full or half empty isn't the point of the effervescent Last Call at the Oasis: It's whether there'll be anything in the glass at all.
Though clearly besotted with Crane's poetry, the writer-director-star never achieves full immersion in the man's life or work; the sense is of people playing a very cerebral game of dress-up.
Pic sidesteps cloying sentimentality and heavy-handedness with the help of a solid cast.
Ardently passionate and naturally provocative.
An epic, and no less of one for taking place largely in the claustrophobic confines of a Polish sewer system.
A droll New Zealand parody with a tone so deadpan it becomes laugh-out-loud funny.

A surprisingly stylish and confident high-concept thriller.

One and one (and one and one and one and one) never quite add up to two.
In addition to being crowded and overlong, the pic is thoroughly unpleasant.
The landscape is dire, the architecture is haunted, children disappear by the dozens and antique toys inexplicably spark to life. That Mr. Radcliffe doesn't is part of the problem.

Levinson piles on the anguish with such abandon he never convinces you that these people would ever speak to each other, much less live under the same roof.
Largely inoffensive but equally unimaginative.
A frenetic bonbon with an empty center, and a movie made without any perceivable audience outside of filmmakers besotted by their own innovative processes.
A malformed, would-be horror shocker with a deliriously deranged performance by Dennis Quaid, who unfortunately seems to be the only one onboard who thinks he's in a comedy.

The astonishing Waltz steals the picture, possibly because he's the one with a rational perspective (despite his telephonic obsessiveness): He sees the whole exercise as pointless. Ultimately, so do we.
Despite its dubious inhabitants, the film consistently entertains by throwing the kinds of curves one should see coming but doesn't.
Even fans of their Cartoon Network series or those simply familiar with the pair via YouTube will likely find the extended version of their pathos-and-pain-driven comedy hard to digest.

movie_review_blurb: [A] first-rate investigative docu on the notorious West Memphis Three case, its questionable prosecution and its dubious resolution.
A Kennedy family album of insight-free affection and nostalgia that lobs long, lofting softballs at its subject.

An energetic and imaginative tale of siblings at a criminal crossroads.
[A] charming and slightly unhinged low-budget comedy.

A David-and Goliath story that delves into corporate scare tactics, legal effrontery, brand protection, media manipulation, online propagandizing and craven behavior.

This very promising feature debut by director Josh Trank turns into one smart thriller, a parable of unchecked power, and an action film in which the action -- although seen through a viewfinder -- carries the viewer away.
The director's apparent blindness to the epic banality of her subjects suggests that the whole project is one royally misguided mess.
Ms. Israel's movie proves, once again, that the best nonfiction cinema possesses the same attributes as good fiction: Strong characters, conflict, story arc, visual style.

The big difference between Mr. Romero's film and Mr. Eisner's -- which is so intelligent you fear the fanboys will scatter -- is that Mr. Eisner never gives us the military's point of view.
The movie is a sturdy entry in the paranoid-thriller genre, and raises some interesting issues about our relationship with the country we used to call China.
The performances are uniformly good, but Training Day helmer Antoine Fuqua seems to lack the maturity as a filmmaker to match his casting or his budget.

At no time will the viewer be under the impression that the performers are engaged in anything but a recycling project, regurgitating 50 years of corrupt-cop movies. Fuqua is striving for gritty street cred and instead delivers a clone.
This appealingly cast movie seesaws from unlikely thoughtfulness to imbecilic vulgarity.
The only bouquet anyone's going to catch from this contrivance has the aroma of stale comedy.
One can forgive the movie's defects, and its indecision about being tragedy or comedy.
A very funny film, and one that operates at the sea level of humanity. Quaint. Slightly peculiar.
Works as a well-guided female empowerment missile -- few women on film have managed to terrorize two possibly psychotic males while handcuffed to a bed and bleeding to death.
Whether or not Shrek has outlived his usefulness as a profit center, it's clear that time and technology have passed him by.

movie_title: No One Knows About Persian Cats (Les Chats Persans) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Aspires to the noble tradition of L.A. film noir, but boasts all the cerebral and aesthetic restraint of a West Hollywood dance club.
dds up to a revelatory trip into complex, innovative ideas and altered perspectives on how people think.

Exhilarating, heartbreaking and righteous, Waiting for Superman is also a kind of high-minded thriller: Can the American education system be cured?
Advocacy to the point of propaganda.

Despite its remarkably intimate footage of war and loss, Sebastian Junger and Tim Hetherington's documentary suffers from the same problem as the ongoing U.S. drama in Afghanistan: a lack of narrative coherence.

The Last Exorcism makes first-rate use of religious doubt and religious extremism to concoct a novel horror-thriller clever enough to seduce unbelievers while satisfying the bloodlust of its congregation/fanbase.

Quinn, alternately charming and loathsome, is brilliant, as is Hinds, an actor who has elevated everything he's been in.
An urgent, immediate, jarring-but-fluid, multicharacter portrayal of Arab life in an Israel ghetto.
A film that begins in an eerie gothic mist of suggestion-and turns into a toothless exercise in the obvious.
A less-than-electrifying account of an electrifying election.
movie_title: By the People: The Election of Barack Obama (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A sci-fi-fueled indictment of man's inhumanity to man -- and the non-human -- District 9 is all horribly familiar, and transfixing.

Simultaneously shiny and retro, calibrated and uncalculated, familiar and unpredictable.

The good news is that the seemingly perennial TV fixture is still funny and sharp and folksy. The bad news is that he lost the bet, or whatever it was that got him into Marc Fienberg's smarmy, lackluster comedy.

Depicts wood, lacquer and hardware the way Hugh Hefner depicts Miss September. Guitar nuts will be turned on, but everyone else will have a good time, too.

Proving that demagoguery can come as easily from the left as from the right, Michael Moore has produced a jerry-rigged jeremiad about free enterprise that hands up some very legitimate indictments, without really making a case.

movie_review_blurb: Not only is it a hapless crime drama about outrage and revenge, it provides the sad spectacle of a movie far less intelligent than the one its filmmakers thought they were making.
It's hard to get absorbed in a story with so many unresolved issues.

A fish-out-of-water story with a bit of a freshness issue.
movie_title: Did You Hear About the Morgans? (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The entirety of Under the Eightball is important, as a memorial gesture to Hall-Steele and a figurative slap in the face to corrupt factions of the medical establishment.
With the exception of Akerman's Annie, the characters are uniformly annoying, their stories insubstantial and the tone one of smug contentment. Production values are grade-A.
Bio skews a bit triumphal, perhaps, but it's an even-handed history of a person who might have led a very comfortable life, but ended up dying for the cause of her nation's hobbled democracy.

A worthy portrait of a phenomenal woman.
Many women would probably like to duct-tape their unfaithful mates to a toilet bowl, but watching it happen isn't quite as funny as it sounds.
An extraordinarily eloquent synthesis of imagery and urgency.
A magical amalgam of Jean-Luc Godard, Miles Davis, Morris Engel and The Umbrellas of Cherbourg.
movie_title: Guy and Madeline on a Park Bench (2010)

movie_review_blurb: [A] generally woeful comedy.

movie_review_blurb: Sing Your Song does three things only a superior bio-doc can do: Tell a stirring life story, place that life in the context of its times, and portray it with the kind of depth and breadth that makes you wonder why it hasn't been told before.
Although helmer Yoav Potash's approach is low-key and only vaguely cinematic, each instance of judicial malfeasance -- and there are many -- is allowed to toll loudly in its own moral echo chamber.

Facile, formulaic and utterly charm-free.
Helmer Constance Marks gives us a gentle giant of a man, whose precocious interest in puppets and puppetry was inspired by the same show that made Elmo a cultural fixture, Sesame Street.
A gimlet-eyed glimpse into the roots of terrorism and the politics behind its prosecution.
movie_title: If a Tree Falls: A Story of the Earth Liberation Front (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Peter Miller's historical docu strikes out a stadium-load of assumptions.
movie_title: Jews And Baseball: An American Love Story (2010)

movie_review_blurb: "The Mechanic," 2011 edition, is a striking-looking work, combining an arty inkiness with a retro-graininess that more or less screams 1970s, albeit without the cliches and flatness. If only you liked the people in the picture.
This mob-war romance could still find an audience in niche release, given its action-oriented underdog story and Ray Stevenson's oddly charismatic lead performance.
Virtually every shot in Bereavement -- a sort of prequel to Mena's Malevolence (2005) -- is the right one; the editing, also by Mena, is first-rate.

The principal joy of "Win Win" is how often it fails to meet one's programmed expectations. The effect is oddly exhilarating.
As a work of nonfiction, it deserves its own nomenclature. "Docu-poem" is too inelegant; "masterpiece" works, although it's been used before.
Worth seeing just to watch Ms. Green ride that teacher right off the rails.
The ability to mix humor and emotion is the strong suit of this upbeat, music-saturated docu.
While the pic is far from perfect, the helmers certainly deliver a must-see film for serious music fans that should make beautiful music at the arthouse.
movie_title: Genius Within: The Inner Life of Glenn Gould (2010)

movie_review_blurb: There's little to really love in One Hundred Mornings.
"Potiche" would be easy to dismiss if it weren't so tartly funny at times and if Mr. Ozon weren't up to mischief.

Frequently enough at the movies, an isolated scene can take place in which an actor who may or may not be the lead steals the whole film through naked emotion, or power, or eloquence. Mr. Lang certainly has one here.
The last thing propaganda should do is make its audience work. "Miral" is a lot of work.
A movie that eludes the viewer's grasp, because it's arguing a position auds will find instinctively wrong.
A disjointed hybrid of dysfunction drama and psychological thriller.
Well intended but inert.
A fatally unwieldy construct of naturalistic drama and cataclysmic sci-fi.
While it will strike some as smug and others as sincere, pic certainly has a feel-good tone and playful attitude.
A politically urgent picture, it will also literally scare the breath out of what will certainly be a worldwide audience.
Acting, particularly by Anthony Mackie and Kerry Washington, is first-rate, but the story is as ramshackle as a South Philly tenement, with an equal number of structural violations.
As she tries to find her husband, and perhaps assassinate the Russian president, she's not quite sure who or what she is. And neither are we. Which is precisely why the whole thing works.

The nighttime photography, of the world's most luminous cities, awakens our sense of grief -- not for what's gone, but for what could be, in the blink of an eye. The editing by Brad Fuller and Brian Johnson is miraculous.
Mr. Kusturica, whose own best directing days may be behind him, nevertheless gives a terrific portrayal of a man living inside his head and his history...
It's a trip into a primordial world and primeval sensibilities, and if you're looking to shake off the mall-movie blahs, there are few better places to look.
Schneider tells us the whole story right there, but Mr. Duvall, who's probably looking at another Oscar nomination next year, gives it a heart.
Derives its blackly comedic bite from being both tragic and immediate.
That Mr. Rebney is a real character comes as no surprise. What's odd, given Mr. Steinbauer's obvious intelligence, is the director's blinkered view of his subject.
The point of the movie is how miserable Tim's life is made by Barry, and audiences will know exactly how he feels.
Ultimately electrifying, both in what it reveals and how it reveals it.
Kline is his usual engaging self but it's a supporting role he's playing by virtue of the script, but also Mr. Dano's presence, in this potent charmer of a film.
By convoluting the various planes of experience, by overlapping and obscuring ostensible realities and ostensible dreams, Mr. Nolan deprives us the opportunity of investing emotionally in any of it.
Well-intended and informative, but also unfocused, unwieldy and a little smug.
Anyone seeking a dialectic, of course, can look elsewhere, but Hershman Leeson's film is a valuable resource on a movement whose issues remain relevant.
With his second feature, GassDonnelly achieves that longed-for thing, a whole greater than the parts, one in which each disparate element complements the other.
Viewers will get a fairly frank look inside a profession where huge financial success doesn't require much more, as even Ziff's mother admits, than being "pretty and on time."
Preoccupation with tragedy does not a narrative make.

Perversely eccentric and frequently inert, screenwriter Mitch Glazer's directorial debut, Passion Play, will benefit from some of the well-known names attached, but the near-painful hipness of the production will yield poisonous word of mouth.
A romantic-comedy-cum-serial-killer-movie that bends genre to the point of snapping.
For all the information here, Gibney is unusual among investigative documentarians in that he never forgets he's making cinema.
movie_title: Client 9: The Rise and Fall of Eliot Spitzer (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Is Olive practicing prostitution? Hair-splitters would say so, but hair-splitters likely won't be seeing Easy A, with its silliness, over-the-topitude and fabulous leading lady, who caps her fresh, charming performance with a musical number at the end.
Luessenhop and his antic camera are after a kineticism that eludes them: He shoots too closely; he's practically crawling up his characters' nostrils with his unhinged camera.
An improbable fantasy in which the people who make political advertising emerge as chisel-jawed heroes of democracy.
Even the inevitable flaws of the low-budget production are winning, showcasing as they do the narrative artistry that makes Boy so distinctive amid current factory-written studio productions.
Suzuki retires the cumbersome plots and predictable settings of his genre films, and lends his bizarre, outrageous, and completely visual language to a bona fide art film.
Among its other virtues, the film reminds us that Chiwetel Ejiofor is one of the most comfortable, consistently convincing and undervalued actors in movies today.
A 'Carnival of Souls' for Mitch Albom readers...

'We love you no matter what your job is,' a character tells her son. That's a love that this very humanistic if dark film asks us to extend to everybody, even those whose sins invite outrage and disgust.
Plenty of fun action sequences, but one wants more from a movie that contains this promising line: 'Summon the witch. The one born of wolves.'
The gross-out and gay-panic humor is overdone, but like its predecessor, the movie makes some cogent if clumsy points about racial identity.
movie_title: Harold & Kumar Escape from Guantanamo Bay (2008)

movie_review_blurb: What's stuck with me aren't the film's flaws but the success of its mission: It puts a real human face -- many human faces, in fact -- on a problem that many politicians would prefer to represent with a racist caricature.
As perfectly tailored an introduction of a new (if limited) movie star as has been seen since the golden age of the Hollywood studio system.
An utterly convincing depiction of childhood loneliness and uncertainty, in a world I'd never seen onscreen: the Orthodox Jewish community of Sao Paulo.
movie_title: The Year My Parents Went on Vacation (O Ano em Que Meus Pais Saíram de Férias) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Exciting, but the message is mixed: Stark's creation of Iron Man affirms rather than repudiates his arms race-exploiting past -- it proves once again that the one with the best weapons wins.

'Why don't you start your own band? That's a lot cooler than having a boyfriend in a band!' So says 15-year-old Laura, who makes a better pitch for the 'empowerment' aspects of the Rock 'n' Roll Camp for Girls than do the adult counselors...
Dramatizes the notion that a person's 'burden of conscience' is not an innate reality but a malleable construct, motivated by narcissism.
Like a stomach-churning human-interest sidebar to the Iraq War overview of 'No End in Sight.'
Plays like a sitcom writer's idea of a Noah Baumbach film, with characters who are amusing, intelligent and screwed-up but not as prickly or treacherous as Baumbach's.

Stripped of the novel's kudzu-like excess, the story loses its timeless, nightmarish, existential power and becomes another cautionary tale in which beautiful and privileged post-9/11 young people learn the world is no longer safe for Americans.
If early slasher films, as their critics claimed, punished teens for having sex, the new 'Prom Night' punishes teens for their conspicuous consumption (stretch limos, hotel suites, and so on).

From the Day-Glo pop of its computer-generated environments to the '2001'-like rush of its almost abstract action climax, this may be the most extreme head-trip movie for kids since Gene Wilder conducted us to a lethal candyland in 'Willy Wonka.'
Offers no more enlightenment or catharsis than a drugged insect could expect in the moment before it is skewered by a lepidopterist's pin.

Beautifully acted and staged, but at odds with itself: the emphasis is not on the 'visitors' but on the uptight professor, who experiences a spiritual rebirth thanks to the life-affirming presence of his new Third World friends...
A movie without a context, as useless as a shoe phone in an iPhone era.

Shyamalan's ideas might have more impact in a half-hour 'Twilight Zone' episode, where they would be shorn of some of the pretensions that seem to be mandatory in the feature-length work of a one-time Best Director Oscar nominee.
Is this a trial balloon for a new comedy franchise or for Myers' post-movie stardom career as the next Dr. Phil?
Contains a property-damaging clash-of-the-titans free-for-all of such intensity that in the pre-computer effects era it could have been visualized only in a cartoon or a comic book.
A flawed movie, made with sympathy and integrity...
Probably the only movie you'll ever see that opens in '1192 -- Year of the Black Rat.'
The most visually stunning cartoon yet from DreamWorks...

Marred by the dull performance of the movie's pinup-ready title swashbuckler and the relative charmlessness of the English schoolchildren (the Hogwarts Sorting Hat would have kicked these kids to the curb).
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: Prince Caspian (2008)

movie_review_blurb: As pretty and bland as its lead actors.
Errol Morris has become the Steven Spielberg or Martin Scorsese of documentary filmmaking, with all the positives and negatives that rather facile comparison implies.
May not do much for its director's resume, but it certainly must have filled out his passport.
The long, go-for-broke opening sequence in the Nevada desert is a triumph that announces that Spielberg and Indiana Jones are not just an explosive combination, they're positively atomic.
movie_title: Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull (2008)

movie_review_blurb: As unhealthy-looking as a Dust Bowl migrant in a Dorothea Lange portrait, Hunt appears to have wandered onto the set in hopes of finding something to chew.
A funny, worthy film that -- unlike Sylvester Stallone's one-man army -- loses focus before it completes its mission.

Worth seeing only for the mysterious adhesion process of Tautou's dresses and for Gilles Henry's glossy cinematography, which treats the luxurious Monte Carlo and Nice locations the way a tongue treats a lollipop.
Gripping, but would have more impact if it had been staged -- like Paul Verhoeven's 'Black Book' -- in the straightforward manner of a classic Hollywood suspense film.
Absurd second installment in the Indiana Jones-for-idiots franchise...
The 'Saturday Night Live' veterans make a great team...
Katherine Heigl proves she deserves leading-lady status in this predictable but entertaining romantic comedy...

Topiary folk artist and chainsaw-wielding 'plant whisperer' Pearl Fryar seems like a wonderful man, but the directors never justify the feature-length treatment they give to a story that easily would have fit into a Sunday morning Charles Kuralt segment.

The flirtatious banter is often clever, but 'Leatherheads' demonstrates that writing alone wasn't responsible for the head-spinning irresistibility of Howard Hawks' 'Twentieth Century' and 'His Girl Friday,' to cite two screwball-masterpiece influences.
May have been filmed in a new process: Pectoralscope.
Like America, it's both excited by and ashamed of its bloodlust.

Suggests the influence of YouTube and (inevitably) 9/11, but actually belongs to the old-fashioned exploitation tradition as it uses state-of-the-art effects and ballyhoo to update B-movie subject matter for a new audience.
In its re-edit, Paramount tries to hide the cultural specificity that makes the movie interesting beneath generic 'urban' camouflage.

Those who believe America is trading blood for oil will find agreement in the film's very title, as well as in the action of prospecting and drilling, in which heavy stakes are driven into the Earth's heart to loose dark gushers...

There is something cinematic about Bauby's situation. Like the moviegoer stuck in a seat in the dark, he can only observe the action in front of him. His comments are unheard by the people who move before his eyes and attempt to manipulate his emotions.
movie_title: The Diving Bell and the Butterfly (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Hoffman and Linney make a great comedy team, even though the movie they're in is a sometimes grim affair...

Vaughn seems to believe that bringing hundreds of F-bombs per night and such guest stars as 'the gay guy from "Wedding Crashers"' to the benighted masses that live between New York and Los Angeles is the domestic equivalent of a USO show.
movie_title: Vince Vaughn's Wild West Comedy Show: 30 Days & 30 Nights - Hollywood to the Heartland (2008)

movie_review_blurb: As Lead Belly might sing, to the tune of 'One Meat Ball': 'You get no thrills/ From One Missed Call...'
The latest from the Apatow comedy factory abandons the relative realism of 'Knocked Up' and 'Superbad' for Mad Magazine-esque, 'Airplane!'-style spoofery...
movie_title: Walk Hard: The Dewey Cox Story (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The Old School nondigital face-huggings and chest-burstings don't compensate for the Sci Fi network dialogue and story logic.

After three viewings, I kind of feel like I have a crush on 'Juno' the movie and Juno the character. I'm poised halfway on the emotional scale between the bemused affection of Juno's tolerant father and the wide-eyed wonder of Juno's pale boyfriend.
Criticizing Timur Bekmambetov for overkill is like dismissing Alfred Hitchcock for being fat.
That Morgan Freeman is one narratin' son of a gun.
Goes for the heart as well as the throat...
A sort of 'Glory Road' or 'Pride' rewrite that celebrates young people who are better at stringing words than shooting hoops or swimming laps.
It doesn't condescend to kids; its themes and narrative structure are fairly sophisticated.
movie_title: The Water Horse: Legend of the Deep (2007)

movie_review_blurb: If Charles M. Schulz's 'Peanuts' cast was transported inside 'The Cabinet of Dr. Caligari,' the visual result might resemble this film...
Movies used to boast of being 'torn from the headlines.' Now, they're torn from an electronics catalog. Who needs James Bond's Q when you've got Best Buy?

As the 'ironic' contrast between historic Flemish beauty and modern vulgarity and violence increases, the movie becomes overdetermined in its twist-of-fate plotting and over-reliant on thuggish humor...
The formality and the deliberate pace suggest the influence of Laurel and Hardy and Jacques Tati...
A formulaic sisters-are-doing-it-for-themselves (and doing each other's hair) ensemble drama in the manner of 'Beauty Shop,' elevated by the novelty of its Lebanese locations and Arabic cast...
The glossiness of director Robert Luketic's staging offers reassurance even when events turn grim, as if Luketic was unable to shake the good-time vibe of his previous films...
Overcomes its occasional stumbles, thanks almost entirely to the charm of its cast...
Delivers the exploitation goods and then some, but it's so utterly derivative it represents a depressing step backward for Marshall...
Not only is it a carbon copy, but such recent genre movies as 'Hostel' have examined the attraction of screen violence with greater immediacy and subversiveness.
The first film from the Judd Apatow Productions assembly line that feels like it came off an assembly line: 'Drillbit' is to Judd Apatow as 'Harry and the Hendersons' is to Steven Spielberg.
Seuss' stories depend on an economy of line, both in their rhymes and their drawings. 'Horton,' to some extent, respects this...
movie_title: Dr. Seuss' Horton Hears a Who! (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Coppola was more efficiently mystical when he wasn't trying so hard.

'A sweeping odyssey into a mythical age of prophesies and gods,' according to the press notes; it's also a sweeping odyssey into a mythical age in which snow is referred to even by Ice Age veterans as 'the great white rain'...
Disappointing but also bracing, and it ends with the question that has motivated all Romero's work: 'Are we worth saving?'

This flat-footed screwball period piece is aimed at the 'art house' crowd, which means it must take itself seriously, which means it must stop dead in its tracks to address the waste of war, and so on...
movie_title: Miss Pettigrew Lives for a Day (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Morelli's film is most effective at its most documentarian, when it focuses on street detail and the casual, everyday behavior of the people inside the desperate favelas.
