movie_title: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button (2008)

movie_review_blurb: As a person who had the glasses literally slapped from his face by a Roman Catholic sister in elementary school, I can testify that it's hard to exaggerate when portraying a nun.

Lacks the irresistible bump of Biggie's music and the flow of his rhymes; unlike Wallace, the filmmakers don't create anything fresh from the elements 'sampled' from the art (in this case, musical movie biographies) of the past...
No movie is produced to lose money, but the new 'Pink Panther' films have no apparent reason to exist except to wring more dollars from an already throttled franchise...
The ending is a cop-out: It lets the audience off the hook while congratulating it for its empathy.
In a packed auditorium in 3D, the film is a true thrill ride -- a communal experience of shared screams and relieved laughter.
Never play hide-and-seek in a haunted house, unless you want to discover you're sharing your dumbwaiter hidey-hole with a ghostly charred corpse.

Crafted with such professionalism it might be the story of Gandhi rather than a wallow in rape, murder and the vengeance of the parents (who, true to the domestic associations of the title, dispatch the evildoers with garbage disposal and microwave oven).
movie_title: The Last House on the Left (2009)

movie_review_blurb: AnnaSophia Robb and Alexander Ludwig are fine, but this 'X Files' for small fry has about as much heft as a bubble of swamp gas.
Directed with admirable sensitivity and spot-on populist instincts...
A wacked-out, quasi-religious 'Donnie Darko' for dummies... It earns my endorsement not because it's coherent but because it's so over the top it kept me engrossed for its full 122 minutes.
Gray doesn't underline 'significant' moments or bits of information, but asks the viewer to be attentive to his story and sympathetic to his characters.
The classroom becomes symbolic of society as a whole: An incubator of problems as well as solutions, and a source of disaster and promise, hope and despair, affection and enmity...
Although the film focuses on a particular conflict, it paints war in general as an absurd and primitive exercise that seems as inexplicable to its perpetrators as to its victims.
Pretty funny, as long as it focuses on geek-specific references ('Hey, it's Willow's spell book!').
A morally specious but undeniably efficient brainstem-tickler -- the most effective action/revenge thriller in years.
I can't think of a more generous or humane filmmaker than Kelly Reichardt.
The director approaches this potentially sensationalistic material the way a cat creeps up on a live meal: with quiet patience and cunning.

The 'Friday' movies are about the fear of death -- especially violent, untimely death, the type that is most scary to the teenagers who flock to the films. Jason is the car that runs a red light and kills a kid on the way to the prom...

More intriguing than the action is Tykwer's use of architecture; his characters are dwarfed by looming towers of cold steel and glass, which says more about the apparent hopelessness of their quest for justice than any of the machinations of the plot.
Preteen girls looking for slumber-party DVD rentals probably represent the film's ideal audience.
A generous, upbeat film that provides lively, unthreatening entertainment for young viewers...
Borrows from 'Romeo and Juliet,' 'The Passion of the Christ' (there are two, count 'em, two gory scourging scenes) and, especially, 'Spartacus'...
movie_title: Underworld: The Rise of the Lycans (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Seems to be the first 'teen' comedy inspired by the recession, even if the downturn depicted here is the hard-times Reagan year of 1987...

Say it loud, I'm green and I'm proud: 'It's not slime, it's mucus,' Tiana asserts during the film's final act, after Disney's first African-American princess has spent most of the film in the emerald skin of an amphibian.

The camera's gaze is so steady in the lengthy final shot that we can't help but notice the imperfections in even Pfeiffer's famously lovely aspect, especially when the only noise we hear on the soundtrack is the muffled but ruthless ticking of a clock.
The British character actors intone their lines with the sincere and intense glee of cats sucking a songbird's bones...
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A fun trifle -- essentially, a homemade 'Little Rascals' update in which youngsters with a 'wishing rock' wreak accidental havoc (and create upright crocodiles, a giant dung beetle, a 'big bad booger' monster and an intellectual telepathic baby).
movie_title: Shorts: The Adventures of the Wishing Rock (2009)

movie_review_blurb: 'Coco Before Chanel'? Whose bright idea was that? Isn't that like 'Amelia Before Airplanes'? Or 'Frankenstein Before Med School'?

Tailored to fit Sandra Bullock more snugly than the antique wedding gown altered for the star during the final act, the film begins to fall apart at the seams after its focus wanders from its promising screwball premise...

Effective when it exposes the immoral, even 'evil' excesses of an economic system that prizes profit above public welfare; less persuasive when it waxes nostalgic about the factory era of the mid-20th century...
A fun, energetic adventure with plenty of inoffensive ghoulish touches that should please kid and adult horror buffs alike.
movie_title: Cirque du Freak: The Vampire's Assistant (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Substitutes an Oedipus complex for sexual menace by replacing the teenage daughter heroine of the earlier film with a hunky military school bad boy, then compounds the mistake with a bad pop/rock soundtrack and a silly action climax...
Reveals a 'King of Pop' whose talent was undiminished by whatever private demons contributed to his shocking death at the age of 50.

Would make a good co-feature with Michael Moore's 'Sicko,' as self-righteous maniac Jigsaw -- apparently a fan of the public option -- plays his bloody, lethal 'games' with health insurance professionals who deny coverage to the needy.
Takes the concept of the self-loathing Jew to an arguably loathsome new level... Perhaps the most revealing and personal film yet from the Coens...

Burns a lot of fuel over the idea that Earhart was not just a hero of the air but an original feminist -- an iconoclast in jodhpurs and a necktie whose addiction to the 'freedom' of flight was representative of womankind's yearning for independence...
It may creep some people out -- parents more than children, no doubt.
The title isn't a question, but the movie provides an answer: Everywhere.

'Maybe we shouldn't have the camera?' Katie asks, raising the interesting if undeveloped notion that the plugged-in generation's endless self-regard and intentional surrendering of privacy invites discontent, disruption, even disaster.

'It's gonna be biblical,' promises the self-righteous Butler about his vengeance, although moviegoers familiar with the Good Book may wonder how they missed the chapter in which the Philistines were smote with a booby-trapped cell phone.
Amiable, kid-oriented slapstick...

Tonally inconsistent, at least it errs on the side of ambition and cleverness; its box-office failure suggests that male genre fans don't want to be asked to identify with the victims instead of the menace.
Unlike most documentaries with a message, 'Good Hair' invites moviegoers to a conversation, not a lecture.

With its self-conscious references to the artistic process and to art itself (in a scene that wouldn't be out of place in a Godard project, a character reads Poe's 'The Bells,' almost in its entirety), this is Swanberg's most moving and impressive film...

Confounds expectations and discomfits the audience by reversing the strategy of 'Gran Torino,' with Holbrook's proud, cantankerous old-timer becoming less worthy of the audience's early investment of loyalty and trust as the story progresses...

As a film inspired by British football, this may hold limited appeal for American moviegoers. But it's also a film about a form of spurned love, which means it's a story about love and hate, which means it's a movie that everybody can relate to.

It reminded me of a Road Runner cartoon. The battlefield violence is essentially repetitious, but Woo -- the auteur as Wile E. Coyote -- introduces gimmicks ('the tortoise formation'), tricks and variations to keep things interesting.
Overstates the Establishment-vs.-youth culture impact of Britain's real-life offshore radio stations...
Contains an honest, thoughtful, relatively unmannered De Niro performance...

'Seize the Day.' That's the title of a song that plays during the end credits... It's also the trite message of this tedious tapestry-of-life ensemble piece, in which a prettily dying young man advises his man-less sister to 'take a chance on chance.'
Bella's tedious moping takes center stage until a poorly delivered telephone message (what a lame dramatic device!) sends everyone to Italy to confront 'the Volturi'...
Never tries to be anything but a slick update of the cheap martial arts thrillers distributed by Cannon Films in the 1980s...

Add scary music, and some scenes could come straight from a horror movie, with no need for re-editing, as when Williams is trapped in a tanning booth, or when Williams slams a car trunk's lid onto a woman's arms, like Terry O'Quinn did in 'Stepfather 2.'
A celebration of 'wild animals with true natures and beautiful talents.' (In other words, artists and children?)
Sapphire's story and the film's performances are powerful enough to compensate for Daniels' miscalculations and phony tricks.
movie_title: Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Sarah Palin isn't the only gun-toting, ex-cheerleader, conservative Christian sports mom back in the news. This week also gives us Sandra Bullock as Leigh Anne Tuohy...
The message proves surprisingly conventional, but its delivery is entirely pleasurable.
A trite compendium of everything that's wrong with non-Pixar computer-animated feature films.
Not the acerbic, Strangelovian satire one might expect but a pleasant, good-natured film that adopts the happy hippy vibe of Bridges' far-out Vietnam vet...
movie_title: The Men Who Stare at Goats (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The 3D isn't enough to justify yet another version of this familiar tale; the film seems more opportunistic than necessary.
The first half is a brilliantly realized exercise in sustained tension; the suspense fades as the story becomes increasingly bizarre...

'I'm going to eat you like a mountain lion,' says the sex-starved Bullock as she attacks Cooper in his van, moments after meeting him, in one of several appalling scenes that represent director Phil Traill's idea of cute.
The bad news: The world as we know it has come to an end. The good news: Mommy's new boyfriend was squashed in the gears of a giant high-tech ark, so Daddy's back in the picture!

SF chillers of the past that warned about dehumanization -- 'Invaders from Mars,' for example -- posited an outside threat; now, in a 21st-century world of plastic surgery and online avatars, the danger comes from within: the dehumanization is voluntary.
A throwback to the relatively thoughtful, adult-oriented science-fiction films that briefly were in vogue in the late 1960s and 1970s.

The jaundiced color scheme -- evocative of the corn starch that is the company's prime product -- and Damon's increasingly disturbing calmness and seemingly irrelevant narration suggest this is a movie about societal as well as personal sickness.

Hip but not smart-aleck, the film is not afraid to wear its heart on its sleeve as an invisible accessory to the pads, helmet and embarrassing Barbie skates that propel its underage heroine to a new identity...
Redeems a trite 'redemptive' story about family with hushed, beautifully staged sequences of 'encoffinment'...

A galvanizing thriller that delivers an unfortunate mixed message through its 'alien apartheid' metaphor... A young white suburbanite might emerge from a screening thinking that aliens are cool, but, y'know, black folks are really scary.
As thoughtful, calculated, somber and cold as a heavily footnoted term paper...
Harks back to the pulpy spirit of 'Doc Savage' adventures and Roger Moore-era James Bond movies...
movie_title: G.I. Joe: The Rise of Cobra (2009)

movie_review_blurb: This ultra-sadistic, efficiently single-minded Grand Guignol endurance test plays like something cooked up by a clever 14-year-old devotee of Bloody-Disgusting.com.
Modest but twisty B-thriller is elevated by nice character touches, witty writing and its tropical setting.

As an old man, Horten is a rare movie hero, but the director reminds us that other things are more ancient; in one scene, Horten hefts a meteorite that predates the sun, and in another scene, Strindberg is quoted: 'In due time, even the stars must fall.'
Near the end of the story, Michael Keaton utters what could come to be regarded as the direst threat in movie history: 'From now on, it's Malby time.'
Messy, self-indulgent, intriguing -- but it only really comes alive when it focuses on the competitive 'friendship' of the actor-roommates played by Seth Rogen, Jonah Hill and Jason Schwartzman.

This sub-Elmore Leonard comedy/murder mystery is redeemed by Robert Patrick's dignified, respectful interpretation of the 70-something Elvis as a man who's given up drugs and fried foods for wheat grass and Tai Chi.
This old-fashioned star vehicle of the highest order lacks conventional drama and conflict -- and is none the worse for those absences.
Have you ever wondered what a Jerry Bruckheimer-produced talking-animal movie would be like? Me, neither. But here's the answer.

Another movie that demonstrates it's bad feng shui to place a glass coffee table beneath a chandelier beneath an attic that can't even support the weight of a blond wearing little more than the whipped-cream bikini she sported in 'Varsity Blues.'
Distinguished by a loony plot twist and by its sympathetic treatment of characters...
A thoughtful nail-biter that inspires us to appreciate the precariousness and relative brevity of existence.

The movie is laced with edgy, eyebrow-singeing 'shock' moments, but Bruno himself belongs to a long tradition of English-mangling funny 'foreigners,' as portrayed by Peter Sellers, Sid Caesar, Danny Kaye and armies of radio and vaudeville comedians.
The lead male character is shy and even gentlemanly, which is not just a novelty but a relief in this Age of Apatow.
The sight of the giddy and newly bipedal Ponyo racing atop the waves of a magically roiling flood may be the happiest and most memorable image of the movie year.

Adam and Beth are remarkably nice, likable characters, played by Dancy and Byrne without the tics and self-consciousness that more pretentious or perhaps less secure performers might have brought to the roles.
The performances are fine, but this feels like a companion piece to 'When We Were Kings' rather than a work that can stand on its own...
Money -- not love or family -- is the (literal) currency that motivates social behavior; human relationships are reduced to financial transactions.
A pleasant trifle of a movie that doesn't let facts interfere with a good fable.
Extremely relaxed and unfailingly entertaining...

The misleading trailer suggests 'Nancy Drew vs. the Thing,' but this graphic-novel adaptation is more 'CSI: Antractica' -- a straight if occasionally gruesome murder mystery, boosted by the novelty of its sub-zero South Pole setting.
The cast list tells the story: It includes such characters as 'Bra-Clad Sister,' 'Slutty Sister' and (for fans of 'The Man Show'?) 'Trampoline Sister.'

Like the 'Crank' films, this is an absurdly exaggerated, outlandishly crass and alternately inventive and appalling depiction of a man violently fighting to liberate himself from the forces that seek to control him...
It's hard to be too rough on a movie in which a zombie horse -- yes, horse -- pulls a victim through a window with its big horsey teeth.
Could be interpreted as a commentary on the potential perils of genetically engineered 'Frankenfood,' but this unpretentious movie doesn't sweat the message.
movie_title: Cloudy With a Chance of Meatballs (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A relentlessly foul-mouthed political satire about an obscene process: the fabrication of a phony case for war to justify U.S. and British plans to invade the Middle East.
Too enamored of its cleverness... but unusual and worth seeing...
Mumblecore meets screwball in 'Humpday,' an audacious character comedy that squeezes so much humor and pertinence out of its low budget and high concept that even the audience feels the pinch.
Yet another nightmare post-apocalyptic world is imagined with a wealth of technical brilliance and a dearth of thematic originality...

Perhaps because of the increased influence that comes with greater celebrity, Judge now seems to sympathize with management instead of labor, a shift in perspective that may prevent this movie from achieving the cult status of 'Office Space.'
James Cameron and the folks at Pixar may disagree, but this is what 3D was made for: To make audiences scream and duck as Death hurls lethal objects from the screen.

Brutal and redundant but not without a certain ugly integrity, this gruesome sequel allows Zombie to continue to explore his idea that Michael Myers is a pathetic and tragically irredeemable product of childhood abuse...

The cameo by Rod Taylor and the references to Yvette Mimieux (the stars of 'The Time Machine') are the tip-offs: This is Tarantino's celebration of cinema as time machine -- a device that can erase the years and, on an imaginative level, change the past.
The filmmakers use Woodstock as wallpaper for a hackneyed story of personal growth and reinvention.
According to movie lore, a bullet to the brain can drop a zombie. The typically less lethal presence of Bill Murray, however, is all that is needed to stop 'Zombieland' dead in its tracks.
Sharon Stone's teary monologue near the end of the film might be more effective if she weren't buried inside a fat suit that makes her look like Jiminy Glick.
The film is most interesting when it bypasses the universality of its spiritual lessons and becomes culturally specific (a Buddhist 'sutra,' a ritual sucide...)
Utterly convincing in the density of its street-level detail and occasionally awe-inspiring in the bravado of its complicated action sequences...
In an early scene, a television is tuned to 'Frankenstein Meets the Wolf Man.' That represents the first and last witty moment in the film.
The band's literal Dr. Phil even develops a 'Metallica Mission Statement' that asks the musicians to become 'healers of ourselves' -- a far cry from 'Kill 'Em All.'
Visually, 'Collateral' locates the post-apocalypse landscape growing within a city still waiting for its apocalypse.
Linklater gives his characters something we rarely get in real life: an opportunity to resolve the sense of loss and regret created by a blown chance at love and happiness.
Viewers may feel as if they're watching a dramatization of 'Fahrenheit 9/11' ...
What's the point of this live-action version of a puppet show? As in 'Pinocchio,' the magic disappears when the marionettes become flesh and blood.
This hairball on the soiled rug of the summer blockbuster schedule is gruesome enough to have been ejected from the esophagus of Bill the Cat...
Too cheesy and clumsy to have earned a theatrical booking outside of a few film festivals and fund-raisers without the profitable precedent of 'Fahrenheit 9/11'...
Eye-rattling visual chaos that many moviegoers will want to rate X, for Excedrin.
Leaves viewers with a welcome and all too rare feeling of movie-induced giddiness...
The audience ends up identifying with the privileged wine-drinker (Reford) and rooting against the underclass cereal-eater (Dafoe)...
Mario Van Peebles celebrates not just his father but the ragged glory of independent cinema in the risky days before DVD, Sundance and the Internet.
Michell's sometimes oddly cropped compositions suggest that May is seeing the world through new eyes, and finding its edges and corners for perhaps the first time.
No plot, no so-called redeeming social value and no desire to pluck the hearstrings, which is why it's superior to 'Elf.'
movie_title: Anchorman - The Legend Of Ron Burgundy (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Greil Marcus has described the folk and "race" records of the 1920s and 30s as expressions of "the old, weird America." Guy Maddin seems obsessed with "the old, weird cinema."
movie_title: The Saddest Music in the World (2004)

movie_review_blurb: 'With great power comes great responsibility' is a lesson the makers of Spider-Man 2 have taken to heart.
Porter's lyrics and melodies still sparkle with the brilliance of bubbling champagne, but this movie biography is about as effervescent as swamp gas.
This example of minimalist stunt filmmaking doesn't add up to much, but the filmmakers deserve credit for their diabolically simple, inexpensive and effective premise...
Imagine you're watching 'Dizzy Detectives' and after Moe wallops Curly with a two-by-four, he delivers a treacly speech about how much he appreciates his friendship...
Earnest but bland depiction of Mormon missionaries as normal guys, even if they do live within the drug-, alcohol- and sex-free context of an old TV series.
Not quite convincing, but Estes deserves credit for asking us to sympathize with the type of obnoxious bully most movies offer up as a deserving target of 'payback.'
Well-made, but those who aren't ready to zen out in Surf City can find documentaries that are just as worthwhile on The History Channel or Animal Planet.
The documentary-like detail and lack of sensationalism allows us to make our own judgments and to make connections between the drug trade and the legitimate business world.
A 'Sorry, Wrong Number' for the driving-while-talking generation...
With her whiskey-marinated, desperate-for-love, full-tilt blooz mama wildcat yowl still intact, Janis Joplin is the best thing about this film...
A caffeinated exercise in nonsequitur metaphysics...
Okay, it ain't Shakespeare, not to mention Romero; but did we really need a scene in which a cop BUNGEE-JUMPS from a helicopter, both guns blazing?
In the words of an Al Jazeera producer: 'Rumsfeld calls this ''incitement.'' I call it true journalism.'
A film for grown-ups in which actions have consequences and consequences aren't resolved with a lecture or a hug or a gun.
Nair's least persuasive film, in part because Becky has been reimagined as such a modern, proto-feminist heroine that she sometimes seems advanced beyond her environment...
A movie that would make a good play.
It's a delight until the weirdly adult-like child grows up to be a childish adult: Farrell, wearing a caveman wig as a stud version of Chance the Gardener...
movie_title: A Home at the End of the World (2004)

movie_review_blurb: The film transforms fighting and killing into something artful, balletic and even color-coordinated, but is somewhat weighted down by a self-conscious patina of quality...
A scary, fun, fast and efficient B-movie that crushes such bloated would-be blockbusters as 'Van Helsing' and 'AVP' in its CGI coils.
movie_title: Anacondas: The Hunt for the Blood Orchid (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Kitano critiques genre conventions and poses, linking himself to the Jarmusch of 'Dead Man' and 'Ghost Dog' rather than to Kurosawa or Eastwood...
Aspires to be a self-actualization session for stifled wives, a plea for gay rights, a Holocaust story and a class in pastry appreciation, all at once...
If you're familiar with the music of The Shins and Nick Drake, you have a sense of the melancholic-ironic-romantic-euphoric buzz the movie aspires to instill in viewers...
The rare family film that doesn't talk down to audiences, yet never as gripping or moving as one anticipates.
The recent film it closely evokes is no sci-fi blockbuster but "The Saddest Music in the World" by Guy Maddin, another filmmaker obsessed with silent and Expressionist cinema.
movie_title: Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow (2004)

movie_review_blurb: A protest against a system of entitlement in which scare tactics and appeals to patriotism are used to exploit the underprivileged to ensure the safety of the rich.
Spurlock comes across as a kinder, gentler, less egomaniacal and -- not irrelevant, in this context -- thinner Michael Moore.
'The Alamo' is forgettable, with the exception of Billy Bob Thornton's performance as a Davy Crockett who deserves a movie of his own...
A masterpiece of dire circumstance, economic disaster and shattered dreams...
movie_title: Kimi ga wakamono nara (If You Were Young: Rage) (Our Dear Buddies) (2000)

movie_review_blurb: A sure-fire premise that sputters like a wet match...
Loaded with pop references and clips from old movies, it's like a bizarre comic precursor to 'The Dreamers'...
Intentionally humorous and oddly poetic...
movie_title: Godzilla, Mothra and King Ghidorah - Giant Monsters All-Out Attack (2001)

movie_review_blurb: A morally specious revenge fantasy for viewers frustrated by their own feelings of impotence in the face of crime, unruly children, and so on...
Collapses under the weight of unlikely melodrama and over-pretty visual flourishes...
Charming but sentimental...
movie_title: Monsieur Ibrahim et les fleurs du Coran (Monsieur Ibrahim) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: The visual equivalent of the type of jokey, cowpokey, retro-Western Swing song that k.d. lang might record for a children's album... (And I mean that in a good way.)
This 'gangsta noir' is a worthy heir to both 'blaxploitation' and to the Warner Bros. gangster classics that linked economic hardship and the allure of crime...
When such amazing artifacts of genuine 1950s ineptitude as 'Robot Monster' are available on DVD, it's hard to imagine why anyone would prefer this ersatz cult readymade...
By living up to its subtitle, it's at least a vast improvement over its noxious predecessor...
Those carpetbagger auteurs, the Coen Brothers, have descended again on Dixie and brought back a heapin' helpin' of Southern caricature and racial condescension...
Watching 'Elephant,' you begin to understand how Scrooge must have felt during the evening he spent with the ghosts in 'A Christmas Carol.'
A non-nutritious junk food snack compared to Romero's feast of gore and metaphor.
Angelina Jolie manages to make attractiveness seem unappealing.
Succeeds as a supernatural special-effects free-for-all, a no-holds-barred monster throwdown and even a love story.
Goes through more contortions than a Tijuana pole dancer as it tries to be all things to all people, and yet it works...
A melancholy alt-rock soundtrack tells us that wistful regret is the appropriate reaction to almost every scene...
If 'Vol. 1' was pure cinema, composed entirely of pulp dreams, 'Vol. 2' finds the Bride awakening to the consequences of something approximating the real world...
More successful as an overslick prison-genre exploitation movie than as a vehicle of social protest...
Suggests that America remains the generous land of opportunity that immigrants have dreamed of for decades, despite terrorism and Homeland Security...
Redundant and gutless -- as phony, prefab and programmed as its robotic housewives. It actually subverts the feminist message of the novel and first film...
Could become a true cult film, if it can reach a sympathetic audience of progressive Christians and their allies.
As in "Princess" and "Mama," Cuaron explores the secret lives of young people forging identities in an adult world that alternately wants to ignore and to control them.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Naked bodies and raw emotions rub against each other with equally sad results...
Where's Yukon Cornelius when you need him?
Clearly, it's a problem when a movie's least interesting characters are its title hero and his signficant ogre...
Rappeneau directs with dutiful predictability, even resorting to slow-motion when the hero throws a chair through a window...
A black-cast romantic comedy that derives its humor from character and plot development rather than from cliched notions of race-based uproariousness...
Says Hector: "No son of Troy will ever submit to a foreign ruler." The bootleg of this movie is sure to be a big seller in Fallujah.
Fans have come to love the likes of 'I Was a Teenage Frankenstein,' so why not have fun with a movie that could have been called 'I Was a Kick-*** Van Helsing'?
The twin millionaires bust up an international piracy ring to help make the world safe again for the manufacturers of overpriced CDs and DVDs...
This examination of selfishness, xenophobia and the human ability to rationalize acts of horror may have audience members squirming not with outrage but recognition...
Despite an occasional excess of sentiment and politics that are sometimes naive, 'Wrath' remains essential viewing...
Gives real insight into a part of the world that likely will dominate our newscasts and newspapers for years to come...
The hero's imaginary GDR is not just a child's-eye view of a socialist Utopia but a literal motherland, contrived for the love of his mother...
Buried beneath prosthetic makeup, the Wayans brothers look like plastic surgery addicts or robot refugees from 'Heartbeeps.' The result is more creepy than funny.
He's magically malicious.
Shows not only respect for the zombie genre but respect for the audience...
Nothing registers through the smothering cheesecloth of the dull staging and inconsequential kookiness...
Not as much a film of social protest as a sexually fluid update of a classic Hollywood mystery-melodrama...
As the film unspools at its slow, observational pace, the effect is almost therapeutic, like sinking into a warm bath.
movie_title: The Story of the Weeping Camel (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Vera seems a figure 'stamped from the dough of human suffering with a heart-shaped cookie knife,' to appropriate Nathanael West's phrase.
After Freeman refers to a place that exists "somewhere between nowhere and goodbye," we realize he's identified the dark space inhabited by all the film's characters.
Not uncompromised, but still powerful...
Bicke's name is a nod to Travis Bickle, but with his creepy mustache and discount-rack suit, Bicke more closely resembles a later Scorsese-De Niro lunatic, Rupert Pupkin...
The evolution of Ice Cube from 'AmeriKKKa's Most Wanted' to America's Most Cuddly continues.
The opening disclaimer suggests that 'intolerance of the Jews' is something the world has outgrown, rather than an attitude that continues to be exploited...
movie_title: William Shakespeare's The Merchant of Venice (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Unfolds in exactly the way you expect a sensitive Sundance indie to handle this distasteful subject matter...
A tolerable but derivative combination of 'Babe,' 'National Velvet' and 'Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer,' with recycled life lessons and poop jokes...
For all their magical and mystical moments, Jeunet's films are suffocatingly literal; his ever-mobile camera leaves no empty spaces for the viewer's imagination to inhabit.
This so-called thriller modulates the eerie static buzz of an empty frequency into the cinematic equivalent of sleep apnea.
A disturbing self-portrait limned from the filmmaker's relentless narcissism and his fetishization of mental illness, family dysfunction and personal suffering.
Not so much a biopic as a performance art project...
The Phantom calls himself a 'loathsome gargoyle,' but, unmasked, he looks more like a guy with a bad sunburn, or maybe a seafood allergy.
Na, na, na, gonna have a good time? Nay, nay, nay.
It's not just escapism. 'Are you for real?' Mei asks Jin; later, he asks her, 'Who are you, really?' These are questions with cultural as well as personal associations.
Transforms Austen's masterpiece into a Bollywood version of chick-lit...
Those who aren't already converts to Perry's dramaturgy will wonder what elevates this material above, say, a typical episode of '227.'
movie_title: Diary of a Mad Black Woman (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Briski's seeming sincerity and her positive results make up for one's occasional misgivings about her showy empathy for the unfortunate...
The geriatric, Teutonic equivalent of a Jim Jarmusch film.
The film warns us to be wary of True Believers of any affiliation. 'They gave us the mandate,' says Goebbels. 'And now their little throats are being cut.'
Lock 'n load as the flip-side of rock 'n roll, with literal battle raps that function as both painful autobiography and frontline reportage.
Romantic fantasies of idealized materialism that have been marketed to white viewers for decades are now being peddled to upwardly mobile African-Americans. Is this progress?
Ice Cube and his investors continue their box-office gentrification of the inner city. As obvious and visually bland as a sitcom, but likable...
Hugely entertaining, but as its smarmy male-centric title implies, 'Inside Deep Throat' swallows whole the idea that the film was some kind of milestone of free expression.
Randle Patrick McMurphy in a motorized wheelchair.
If the film had been about Weaver rather than her family, Harris might have scripted an ending that represented a risky individual choice instead of a communal retreat.
Horror movies have long exploited the anxieties associated with birth and child-rearing, but 'The Ring Two' may be the first to credit its hauntings to postpartum depression.
About the only CGI illusion occurs when the bad guy exhales cigarette smoke through the blowhole of his tracheotomy. But Pinkaew isn't blowing smoke: this is the real deal.
A Transformer of a kids' movie that reconfigures itself into a literal depiction of the idea that Big Money wants to throw the old, rusty and broken onto the scrap heap.
Snatches the sadistic content of a rabble-rousing exploitation film and stashes it within the overblown blockbuster pretensions of a Bruce Willis action vehicle...
Tries the patience of sober viewers, who are likely to envy the onscreen eccentrics their ever-present plastic cups of Abita...
movie_title: A Love Song for Bobby Long (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Earnest, admirable and pretty, but about as compelling as one of the blander episodes of 'Little House on the Prairie.'
A compelling addition to the long tradition of artful French film adaptations of works of mystery and suspense literature.
Eventually abandons its trippy sense of mind-bending mystery for life-is-beautiful affirmation: a Reader's Digest message camouflaged within Nine Inch Nails grisliness.
Built around Bardem's immobile presence, the film can't help but seem stolidly monumental even as it explores issues that are heart-wrenchingly personal.
movie_title: The Sea Inside (Mar Adentro) (The Sea Within) (2004)

movie_review_blurb: A comic clash of stereotypical Red State and Blue State culture, but with a wish-fulfillment Hollywood ending in which 'Fockerization' triumphs...
Allusions to Frank Wills, the security guard who discovered the Watergate break-in, suggest a story that would have made a much better Spike Lee movie than this misfire...
Lacks the energy and snap of previous Anderson films, but as Bill Murray says about a jaguar shark: 'It's pretty good, isn't it?'
movie_title: The Life Aquatic with Steve Zissou (2004)

movie_review_blurb: At times, it's like a John Waters spoof of Andy Hardy; Kinsey remarks "Let's get back to masturbation!" while his wife asks "Is the pot roast too dry?"
Those who've seen Shimizu's creepy original aren't likely to be impressed...
A must-see that exposes the increasing interconnection of business, politics and 'every living system of Earth'...
Dee Dee is the most humorous band member, as he remembers the halcyon days of pre-fame Forest Hills: 'We would hang out, sniff glue or smoke pot... listen to the Stooges...'
movie_title: End of the Century: The Story of the Ramones (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Too fey, too coy, too precious...
Hilarious, yes; but one can almost already hear the film's rousing theme song, 'America: F--ck Yeah!,' blasting unironically from boom boxes across the country...

Marred by absurd plot digressions and choppy, sloppy and incoherent shaky-camera action sequences.

I kept imagining an alternate-universe rewrite, with a young Bob Hope and maybe Paulette Goddard in the leads, and a 1940s journeyman in the director's chair -- the kind of guy who could crank out 30 minutes of snappy comedy-mystery before happy hour.

In this era of obsessive and globally connected cult cinema fans, it's foolish to give the movie's core target audience an excuse to skip the theatrical experience for the more 'authentic' home edition available uncut on import DVD.
movie_title: The Promise (Master of Crimson Armor) (Wu ji) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: The film has no more depth than the M.C. Escher-esque wallpaper that turns each room into a busy sort of moire cage.
If Paul Verhoeven's film was a potent if hard to swallow sex-and-blood pop cocktail, this London-set sequel is a cup of thin, tepid tea.

At this point, 'V for Vendetta' seems more fashionable than radical.

An 11-year-old word wizard from the inner city longs for a little r-e-s-p-e-c-t, as Aretha Franklin sings in pop music's most famous spelling test. We know she'll get it; what's remarkable is that writer-director Doug Atchison earns our respect as well.

This story of a vaguely Elvis-esque troublemaker who transforms the misfit gospel choir at a Baptist halfway house into a rockin' blues band could probably be screened at a real Baptist halfway house without controversy.
A calculated provocation with pretensions to public service value (think of the infamous 'molester' episode of 'Diff'rent Strokes').

Surprisingly palatable family comedy...
The girls' theatrical ferocity, relative innocence and youthful earnestness is almost heartbreaking.

Pretentious, with Jigsaw a splatter Mitch Albom.

movie_title: Tenacious D in The Pick of Destiny (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Whether the monarchy is worthy of such affection is a debate for another movie; this one works wonderfully on its own terms.

There's something immoral about a film that asks us to chuckle at the naughty murders of innocent people and then expects our hearts to swell when a husband and wife affirm their holy union. 'Saw III' has more integrity.

I sympathize with the directors' agenda, but this is a movie in which shots of American flags and 'God Bless the U.S.A.' signs are supposed to be as ominous as hammer-and-sickle insignia in a 'duck and cover' propaganda film.
To paraphrase a great possum: We have met the racist, anti-Semitic, homophobic crazy Kazakh, and he is us.
movie_title: Borat: Cultural Learnings of America for Make Benefit Glorious Nation of Kazakhstan (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Press releases are promoting the film as 'controversial' before the fact, but compared to such predecessors as 'Jesus Christ Superstar,' 'Godspell' and 'The Passion of the Christ,' 'Color' -- race issue aside -- unspools like a Sunday-school filmstrip.
Accomplished and visually persuasive, but the movie's central conceit remains something of a stunt...
Manages to feel dated despite the extreme relevance of the message that one man's freedom fighter is another man's terrorist...
Let them eat cake? Sofia Coppola feeds it to us in spoonfuls -- pink, sugary, decadent. The entire film seems to have been squeezed onto the screen from a confectioner's pastry bag...
Part 'Sleuth,' part 'Itchy & Scratchy,' part science-fiction...
One awful 'dramatic' scene follows another, until we become almost awed (wait until you hear Fishburne's chef deliver a metaphorical speech about blueberry cobbler).

A testimonial to the viability and efficiency of the American marketplace of ideas, where Toby Keith, Natalie Maines, Bill O'Reilly and millions of other voices are free to annoy, heckle, praise, please and sing...
movie_title: Dixie Chicks - Shut Up and Sing (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Not entirely disconnected from Hardwicke's previous work: It's the tale of an unwed pregnant teen whose parents worry about her getting stoned. The difference here is that the pregnant teen is a virgin, and we're talking about actual stones.

Perhaps most satisfying when viewed as a particularly fraught, literate and beautifully acted soap opera; no doubt the movie's East Wyndham, Mass., is located on the same commuter train line that serves Peyton Place and Wisteria Lane.
An extremely ambitious and spectacularly produced thriller indebted to the 1960s tradition of the 'giallo'...
movie_title: Perfume: The Story of a Murderer (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Director Glen Morgan has a nice pictorial sense and a flair for ghoulish caricature, but the film is muddled and choppy.

Stefen Fangmeier establishes himself as the Uwe Boll of family-friendly fantasy.

Seems to have been inspired by two of De Niro's more celebrated movies, 'The Godfather Part II' and 'Once Upon a Time in America'; if it lacks the bravura set pieces of those films, it at least unfolds with its own whispery integrity.

Earnest, effective and entertaining, although in no way an adequate substitute for the much richer experience of White's novel.

movie_title: De Battre mon Coeur s'est Arrêté (The Beat That My Heart Skipped) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: I'm still eager for children's films that aren't supersized or edgy or flatulent. I just want them to be better than 'Herbie.'

movie_review_blurb: Entirely sympathetic to its youthful, even bratty characters -- and, by extension, to the youth audience that is likely to respond most enthusiastically to the film.

The work of a wry, generous filmmaker who wants to sympathize with even her most self-centered characters...

The rare remake that honors rather than exploits or degrades its source.

movie_title: Enron: The Smartest Guys in the Room (2005)

movie_review_blurb: For once, the words 'A long time ago in a galaxy far, far away' seem ironic, and it's hard to watch what follows without drawing comparisons to our own political landscape.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode III - Revenge of the Sith (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Fonda is in great shape, but she *is* slightly older than Joan Crawford was when Mommie Dearest co-starred with a thawed caveman in 'Trog.' At least Crawford got top billing.
A fable of the end of innocence, complete with such symbols of paradise lost as a snake (a fugitive copperhead) and a toppled playhouse.
movie_title: The Ballad of Jack and Rose (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Its sweet surprise ending may be the most satisfying movie moment of the year to date.
movie_title: The Wild Parrots of Telegraph Hill (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Droll literary humor, genital violence played for laughs, references to German New Wave cinema and Al Pacino impersonations are among the elements that make this one of the year's most beguiling and entertaining surprises.
movie_title: Tristram Shandy: A Cock & Bull Story (2005)

movie_review_blurb: A 'Song of Bernadette' for a violent show-me age, with Emily Rose helping to restore the faith of those around her with visions of hell rather than heaven.
A movie in which you can be sure that whenever a lovable old dog is in the frame, a cutely plaintive whine will be added to the sound mix.
Intimations of Abu Ghraib and allusions to 'The Wicker Man' suggest Roth's intentions are honorable... The film isn't escapist; like 'Straw Dogs,' it demands that viewers respond to its violence.
A film of extreme tenderness, with sympathy for all its deserving characters, including the wives and family members who suffer alongside the frustrated Jack and Ennis.
The film proffers both a fantasy of wealth and the reassurance that money isn't what really matters.

Interviews with the real-life Haskins and others during the closing credits are more interesting than the movie, and suggest the story of this incredible team will be told best in a future documentary.
A milestone on the road that led from Stepin Fetchit to Sidney Poitier to Spike Lee...
Enlivened by a few moments of boudoir slapstick that resemble a Benny Hill skit as produced by Merchant Ivory.

The bright, retro-futuristic Pop Art production design matches the 1970s 'THX-1138' values of a story that suggests freedom can be found within the natural world that lies outside our technological cocoons.
The whimsy is so forced, a half-dozen Mitzi Gaynor references occur during the first 15 minutes.
The darkest lump of coal ever dropped down a moviegoer's throat on Christmas Day, bought by the Weinsteins for $3.5 million. Next time, could we get a gift certificate instead?
Only occasionally does the camp classic struggling to free itself from the constricting kimonos and white pancake makeup of 'Geisha' claw its way to the surface.
Resurrected by the necromancy of digital special effects, the twin towers in the final shot cast a shadow over the three hours that passed before, making the film appear even bleaker in retrospect.
'Everything is show biz, don't you know,' states Lane, and 'The Producers' evangelizes this message with fundamentalist zeal.
At once alien and familiar: part Old World folk tale, part inspirational sitcom.
The climactic clash of zoological and mythological combatants is the stuff of my childhood fantasies made digitally simulated flesh: It's like 'Doctor Dolittle' as reimagined by Robert E. Howard.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, The Witch and The Wardrobe (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Delineates the scary disillusion that occurs when a child realizes his parents are not only fallible but, sometimes, pathetic...

Jackson's ape is so fully realized as a specific 'realistic' character that he lacks the metaphorical resonance of the 1933 Kong, who seemed a creature captured from a nightmare rather than from nature.
The supporting cast is mind-melting: Michael Madsen is as out of place in this Medieval milieu as Meat Loaf in a hoop skirt, and Meat Loaf is just out of place.
Pale WB-style hunks and hotties and a 'funny' black guy whose sole purpose is to say words like 'dawg' confront a CGI mist that looks like it could be erased with a couple of mouse clicks.

Jodie Foster, the real-life mother of two young sons, follows 'Panic Room' with another thriller that allows her to physicalize her maternal instincts into action-movie heroics. (Does her experience as a child actor help explain this protective streak?)
Both a solemn search for a dead child and a violent race riot are scored with celestial keyboard washes and choral harmonies intended to imbue the scenes with Significance.
The notion of horror movie as thrill ride is cannily literalized in the bravura amusement-park opening sequence...
It seems, well, curious that former child star Ron Howard --the beloved 'Opie' himself -- should have carved out a profitable side career as a despoiler of classic children's picture books.
Martin and Levy fail to convince us of Clouseau's belief in his own reality. We find ourselves watching Martin riffing on Sellers rather than a legitimate if ridiculous character.
The symbolism of the situation -- a blind diplomat trying, and once again failing, to stage-manage international harmony -- seems like something from a socially conscious play of the 1930s.
Another Hollywood movie that presents a 'typical' American family as ultra-privileged and glamorous.
What to remake next? 'My Bloody Valentine' or 'Sorority House Massacre'?
Moviegoers who relish the thought of hearing the imperious Dench pronounce various circumstances as 'delicious' or 'intolerable' are most likely to enjoy this film.
Eschewing the shock contrivances and sitcom silliness of such recent predecessors as 'Crash' and 'Guess Who,' the movie examines interracial relationships with heartening optimism.

Not really a return to form but an advance: a stylish work of gliding camera movements, cunningly framed shots and seamless edits that marks one of the few times Allen's interest in pictures has equaled his facility with words.

Pierce Brosnan's 'facilitator of fatalities' is a great character, but the story that houses him is as ersatz as the recording of 'In the Wee Small Hours' the assassin plays on the businessman's turntable (that's not Sinatra singing).
Begins as a cult 'transgender' film, then undergoes emergency reassignment surgery to become a mainstream adventure in parent-child 'closure.'
An impressive bat-winged vampire king, Kate Beckinsale in skintight pleather, complicated but simpleminded plotting, death by helicopter blade, etc.
Tedious, mesmerizing and ultimately quite moving...

As Brooks tries to take the pulse of 'the Muslim world' with absurdist routines that have no more than cult appeal even in his own culture, the movie becomes more a timeless satire of U.S. government inefficiency than a commentary on the post-9/11 era.
movie_title: Looking for Comedy in the Muslim World (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Not entirely successful, but it's as twisted as a James Ellroy novel, and it may please genre fans who don't require the transubstantiation of spilled blood into the holy water of redemption.
It's quite 'agreeable,' as the fatuous Mr. Collins would say, but there's something disturbing about a Jane Austen adaptation that uses an ampersand as an official part of its title.
Gaghan asks us to piece together the story from the evidence onscreen, making the film almost an exercise in participatory investigative journalism.
The producers may be right to bemoan Hollywood's myopia; but it's the movie's execution, not its vision of an alternative African-American cinema, that delayed its release.
The movie twinkles sardonically, like the eyes of the Grinch when Chuck Jones animates the character's most cunning, twisted smile.

Intriguingly, it can be viewed as a thrill-less update of a Val Lewton thriller... It asks the viewer to decide whether its characters are crazy, cursed or blessed as they encourage the incursion of the supernatural into their lives.
Wong composes shots as if he were squeezing drops of liquid narcotic into the viewer's eyes.
Among the startling revelations: Math is precise but life is sloppy.
Almost every scene contains something surprising, even startling -- we feel as if Park is searching for a new way of seeing...
Another of the sensitive adolescent males who infest recent American independent cinema like so many epicene dust mites...
The film has the literal hands-on, homemade appearance of the whimsical gizmos that Wallace invents for his own cottage industries.
movie_title: Wallace & Gromit: The Curse of the Were-Rabbit (2005)

movie_review_blurb: A marvelous showcase for all three leads...
The film's haunting final freeze-frame offers a visual paradox: Laura is suspended in time yet finally free.
Ingenious and disturbing, it's not really about the past but the present -- a witty successor to 'Fahrenheit 9/11.'
movie_title: CSA: The Confederate States of America (2005)

movie_review_blurb: A reminder that conventional action filmmakers are as untrustworthy as politicians who won't allow citizens to see the body bags produced by a war.
Demonstrates that the best pop storytellers if not the best 'artists' in filmed entertainment these days are working in television.
Newcomer Sophie Traub is a natural charmer who hovers above the confusion like an angel even as her co-stars are sucked into the muck.
The Corpse Bride's hypnotic orbs suggest a Kim Carnes hit for Eurohorror fans: She's got Barbara Steele eyes.
Dialogue allusions to the Cosby Kids and 'What's Happening!!' are played for laughs, but they're apt: This is family-friendly youth fare
Matches the glossy, calculated kinkiness of a pay-cable television series to a story that unfolds like a Young Adult author's stab at a Bret Easton Ellis novel.
Glib as its protagonist, it wants to talk its way into the pantheon alongside 'Dr. Strangelove'; still, it's a worthy addition to a movie culture that fetishizes firearms...
This supposedly progressive movie unintentionally delivers a sexist message as old as the garden of Eden: Don't let a woman get involved, because she'll mess things up.
A 'Mad About Gramps' episode that requires Falk to line-dance to Travis Tritt and otherwise demonstrate that old people sure are funny and cute and flatulent.
Whatever power Keith Beauchamp's film possesses as a work of art has been superseded by its political impact...
movie_title: Untold Story of Emmett Louis Till (2005)

movie_review_blurb: The soulful Bruni-Tedeschi gives the impression that her beautiful face is bruised, even though it is blemish free; it's one of the best performances of the year.
A sort of 'CSI: Antwerp' episode from a director who seems to be auditioning for the next Jason Bourne adventure.
movie_title: De zaak Alzheimer (The Memory of a Killer) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Today's assignment: Watch 'Paradise Now.' Discuss.
A sort of stealth musical that tells its story of heartache, longing, passion and fated love more effectively through song than script.
Suggests rather moralistically that Capote's cold-blooded behavior contributed to his artistic and physical decline, as if he could have been saved by Dr. Phil or a hug.
Like Chris Columbus, Newell delivers what is essentially an illustrated condensation of Rowling's novel.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (2005)

movie_review_blurb: No matter how accurate its rap-gangland narrative, there's little here that couldn't have been imagined by a screenwriter from suburban Des Moines...
Arriving only weeks after 'A History of Violence,' the film's agenda seems especially spurious.
A wonder of imaginative design and a failure of imaginative storytelling; after 101 minutes of this, you feel like a starving man being taunted with a Faberge egg.
We may recognize that the film is something of a nicotine-stained hagiography; but such recognition doesn't dilute the power of the ideas that Clooney has chosen to champion.
Veni vidi vomit. That's Latin for: I came, I saw, I saw 'Saw II.'
If twisted noir novelist Jim Thompson had scripted the Jerry Lewis vehicle 'Who's Minding the Store?,' the result might have been something like this...
movie_title: The Perfect Crime (El Crimen Perfecto)(Crimen ferpecto) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: The way Zorro eludes his foes is nothing compared with the slipperiness of the film itself as it tries to be politically 'relevant' yet inoffensive to all consituencies.
At times, the cinema verite style suggests the 'psychic disarray, intimately observed' (Almereyda's words) of Eggleston's own 1970s video project, 'Stranded in Canton'...
movie_title: William Eggleston in the Real World (2005)

movie_review_blurb: 'Rock 'n' Roll High School' rejiggered for idealists, with the youngsters mobilizing for gay rights and freedom of speech instead of sneaking off to the Ramones.
As with many road trips, the destination isn't as rewarding as the journey...
Sincere, affecting and simple in its direct emotional appeal if not in the overlapping chronologies of its three narratives...
By the time Elton John sings, 'Soon as this is over, we'll go home,' moviegoers will be way ahead of him.
When a woman complains that her boss has 'the attention span of a ferret on crystal meth,' she could be talking about Tony Scott or stating Scott's opinion of his audience.
'Rent' has come to the screen too late to have any real impact...
The story's brain-snatching aliens must have attacked the filmmakers before they invaded the rest of Los Angeles.
An exhausting walk down a very long and garish plank.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A violent, smart return from Disney-land to a lethal landscape better suited for a man with 'guns' for arms and a head shaped like a bullet.
'Third Person' takes place in New York, Paris and Rome, but what it offers moviegoers is a trip to Dullsville.

The best thing about 'Begin Again' is what it's not. It's not a love story, or at least not a conventional love story; it's more of a friendship story between a man and a woman, which is something we almost never see in movies.

Polanski seems to revel in defeating the limitations imposed by this stagey project, which may be among the most personal of his career -- a movie that laughs at pain and sex and the absurdity of life even as it acknowledges life's terror and wonder.
Ebert once said: 'For me, the movies are like a machine that generates empathy.' This documentary might be Exhibit A in an argument in support of Ebert's definition.
Besson's most ambitious realization of his peculiarly exuberant notion of girl power.

The effect is uncanny and heartbreaking, yet exhilarating, not depressing. Mom sums it up, when Mason celebrates his 15th birthday: 'I'm so glad you were born.' We'd like to think she's speaking to all of us.
An unexpected charmer about friendship, identity and the liberating power of making a racket.
I left 'Obvious Child' thinking not of Donna, the story's heroine, but of Jenny Slate, an intriguing screen presence who deserves better material.

A largely successful attempt to present the life story of the impenetrable and eccentric genius of funk in a way that respects Brown's memory and experiments with the biopic formula while also entertaining a mainstream audience.

Eastwood jettisons the 'jukebox musical' approach of his source material to transform the story of Frankie Valli and The Four Seasons into another of his inquisitions into the hopeful myths and dark realities of American history and celebrity.
'Sinister' director Scott Derrickson again delivers the (modest) goods in this old-school street-cop mystery-thriller in 'Exorcist' drag.

Every frame is some kind of digital marvel, yet the most impressive sights are old school: the blunt-instrument fearsomeness of Mickey Rourke's Frankensteinian prosthetic face and the dangerous curves of femme fatale Eva Green's often undraped body.
movie_title: Frank Miller's Sin City: A Dame to Kill For (2014)

movie_review_blurb: It's overstuffed with effects and incident, but it looks great, it feels fresh and it's sometimes laugh-out-loud funny.

For all its digital spectacle and redundant action-violence it understands the power of the fraught gesture, the soft word, the shadowed expressionistic closeup: Jolie is photographed as lovingly and spookily here as Simone Simon in "Cat People."

The rat sequences are rather potent if you can overlook the fact that the ravenous rodents are often DACHSHUNDS, dressed in little rat outfits and little rat masks. But you can't overlook this, which is what makes this movie great entertainment.
Pfister seems afraid to recognize the humor inherent in a story that requires Johnny Depp to become a grim sort of Max Headroom...
Transformers have souls, this movie repeatedly tells us, but does Michael Bay?

The post-millennium indie film equivalent of an epistolary short story, the movie is not just a video-letter conversation but a calling card for its debuting co-directors, who demostrate a knack for crowd-pleasing instincts even on a micro-budget.
What develops inside this Petri dish is a pretentious and fatally self-conscious piece of work -- the most wearying example to date of a new subgenre we might label 'Sundance Science Fiction.'

As it circumnavigates the frozen globe of the climatic post-apocalypse, 'Snowpiercer' sometimes seems loaded with more allegorical freight than even a futuristic bullet train can carry. Yet it remains one of the year's more impressive films.
For all the cornball Canadian comedy that interrupts the horror, the cry of 'Coo-loo-coo-coo-coo-coo-coo-coo' is less relevant here than 'Goo goo goo joob.'
A cunningly calculated pulp thriller that coincidentally arrives at a moment when outrage over violence against women has become impossible for even the NFL to ignore.
The movie could use more of its surprising if intermittent wit and less of its unsurprising if efficiently staged sword-and-sandal violence.

Apparently designed as a Michael Bayhem gateway drug to hook the few kids considered too young for 'Transformers' movies, this grim and charmless update is about the last thing the culture needs: The 'Dark Knight' of Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtle movies.
Et tu, Koba?
movie_title: Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The rotating funnel clouds are almost spectacular enough to make up for the rote drama (a strict dad butts heads with his teenage son, yawn) and routine characterization (redneck comic relief, yee-haw).
Can a movie be rife with profanity, nudity, vulgarity and sexual content, yet ultimately be as corny and wholesome as an Ozzie and Harriet episode? Unfortunately, yes.

The odd compositions imply the camera is respectfully aware of the presence of something hovering above the characters, something invisible and mysterious that perhaps affirms the nun's faith, even in this awful world of Nazi murders and Communist purges.
Belongs to a newly active subgenre that we might dub the celebrity bio-episode, to distinguish it from the more conventional biopic...
A convincing crime thriller and a worthy final feature for the late James Gandolfini...

Is it inappropriate to laugh in the presence of a petrified victim of the volcanic eruption at Pompeii, even if that 'presence' is footage on a movie screen? If you think the answer is 'Yes,' then please avoid 'The Trip to Italy.'
A particularly flavorless serving of flaccid beef jerky and brine-cured ham.

Scarlett -- a pretty young archeologist who favors allowing her sweater to slip coyly off one shoulder to expose a fashionable bra strap while she's vandalizing ancient relics -- may be the year's most absurd movie character.
Love means never having to say you're wormy.

Long a subject of fascination for certain Elvis fans and scholars of American popular culture, the connection between the King of Rock and Roll and the King of Kings finds its most elaborate expression yet in 'The Identical.'

This violent survival saga wears its angry politics on its bloody sleeve: Government conspiracies, black revolutionaries, 'the redistribution of wealth' and the 'worship' of firearms are among the topics broached (and sometimes bludgeoned).
Not so much a traditional documentary as a musical celebration of Memphis' status as what host Terrence Howard calls one of the 'special places on this Earth'...

Filled with wonderful examples of her art, alongside interviews with her former employers and the now-grown children once in her charge, the movie is a testimony to the value of Maier's work and to the unending strangeness of human personality.
The notion of Vietnam as quagmire is literalized in this stunning 1981 action-suspense film.

Part heist film, part action thriller, part murder mystery, the movie is punishingly violent (in one scene, the camera lingers over squashed body parts after a drug agent is hit by a train). The ugliness is so pervasive it becomes perversely fascinating.
With references to Vietnam and with President Nixon as a key supporting character, the film continues the X-Men tradition of being politically and sociologically conscious...

It was Hawks' genius to recognize a kinship between his leads, and to understand that the 'naturalism' of the Wayne persona was as deep and complex as the more intellectualized approach of the neurotic young New York stage actor, Clift.

Advances an interesting pro-diversity agenda: The 'nerds' aren't just brainy geeks but outcasts, including a flamboyant gay black man. (When big block letters that spell NERDS are set on fire outside the nerd house, you're reminded of burning crosses.)

'He was licking me!' That plaintive, disgusted wail is pretty unforgettable once you've seen this one-of-a-kind tongue-in-cheek/blood-in-mouth historical horror movie that has garnered an appreciative cult audience...
Inspired in part by the McCarthy hearings, the movie has lost none of its timeliness: The morality of surveillance technology is among its many themes.
The quintessential film noir -- acid and snappy, and shockingly cold-blooded.

Colorful, cartoonish fun, with an improved Toho Kong who eventually battles a 'robot Kong' created by evil Dr. Who (Hideyo Amamoto), variously described as 'an Oriental skeleton,' 'an international Judas' and 'a devil who lies like a gutter rat.' Ouch.
Gray is a specialist in studies of people struggling to retain their dignity in desperate, morally compromising situations.

Lacks tension, focus and -- most damaging -- seems entirely unnecessary and redundant in the wake of the four documentary features that not only exhaustively examined the case but altered the lives of everyone involved in it.
From the set-up, we expect a story we've seen many times before, but 'Cold in July' is smart and supple.
It would have been nice if the movie had allowed voices less fannish than those of King's peers and childhood friends to make the case for the signficance of 'The King of the Blues.'
movie_title: BB King: The Life of Riley (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Continues the idea, seen in Cronenberg's 'Cosmopolis,' that the car is no longer a refuge and a symbol of freedom but an extension of the home and office -- a mobile space that through technology remains connected to the pressures of work and family.
The movie suggests that in this corseted era, women of all races and backgrounds were traded like commodities. Arguably, this feminist slant de-emphasizes the peculiar horror of slavery...
If you think being a CIA assassin is tough, try making sense of a teenage girl!
I've said it before, I'll say it again: Clint Howard + satanic pigs = MOVIE GOLD.

Wanda Jackson's 'Funnel of Love' introduces us to Jarmusch's stylish vampires, his pale lovers, his connoisseurs of art and oenophiles of blood, swanning and swooning through eternity, together forever even if continents apart.
Not a particularly precocious debut, in the context of the Coppola dynasty, but nevertheless feels much like the work of a very young if talented person who has yet to discover a unique voice.
Demonstrates that Jerry Lewis is the absolute master of screen space: There's not a single indifferent shot in the film.
Keeps the pace and dialogue snappy enough for a classic screwball comedy, at least until the inevitable overkill of the boom-bastic finale, centered on an alien-infested Louvre.
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The movie always circles back to Thompson, as if Steadman were a tetherball attached to the writer. In this way, Paul doesn't quite justify the need for a feature film about his subject (as opposed to, say, a profile segment on '60 Minutes').

The film was somewhat radically reworked for a TCM special edition; the original is like an old-school monster movie that teases the audience before finally giving fans the spectacle they crave -- Elvis, tearing down the house in all his jumpsuited glory.
movie_title: Elvis: That's the Way It Is (1970)

movie_review_blurb: Justly celebrated as the rare Elvis movie in which Presley is not just complemented but also challenged by a song-and-dance co-star of comparable sexual energy and anatomical expressiveness.

The film has a ticking time-bomb quality that pays off in the accelerating violence of the breathless final act, which is more grim than gory, with the high body count one would expect from a movie inspired by Jonestown.

'Maybe we thought the world would end,' Mitchum muses, during a short-lived spell of happiness in Mexico. 'Maybe we thought it was a dream.' A dream? In his trench coat and fedora, he's clearly not a man destined to die quietly in his bed.

With its climactic assassination attempt of a lovely songstress, this sardonic skewering of the music industry-as-America may be nothing less than a more rollicking, less sniffy predecessor to Altman's 'Nashville.'
A sexy and often comical road trip that demonstrates how personal agendas and insecurities sabotage and corrupt not just personal but political ideals.
The last-act revelation is a let-down and even somewhat silly, but this remains a top-tier ghost movie, thanks mostly to director John Hough, who privileges atmosphere over logic.

Any thought that Al Pacino overacts in 'Dog Day Afternoon' is instantly banished by the screen presence of the gleefully crude and unrepentant real-life Wojtowicz, a leering and self-promoting Priapus.
Earth to Echo won't wallop young viewers, but I wouldn't be surprised if kids who catch this at the right age are utterly captivated.
Strong, sordid stuff.
A movie about, essentially, the perils of revenge sex (for women, at least).

Contains what may be the first instance of the 'If it doesn't fit you must acquit' defense: Barrymore wins Gable's freedom by having the accused man place on top of his head the too-small hat that was found at the scene of the crime.

The Chatterton character's appetite for sex is large: She cherry-picks the men in her factory and invites them to her spectacular home for business meetings that turn into seductions. When she's ready, she tosses a pillow onto a fur rug on the floor.
Begins with a clip of a professor discussing the meaning of yin and yang, and that symbol of apparently opposing but in fact complementary forces becomes a kind of theme.
The moral ambiguity more than the exposed skin and spilled booze is what stamps 'Night Nurse' as a definitive pre-code masterwork.

Staggering in its efficiency, admirable in its insistence that the women deserve as much screen time as the men, and awe-inspiring as a vehicle of romantic and even career reassurance for moviegoers...
As much a modern existential Western as a science-fiction drama in the manner of 'Mad Max.'

'I created this,' Beal says early in the film. 'I imagined it into existence.' The words could be a manifesto for filmmakers, an articulation of the director's mission, particularly in the case of as singular a work as 'Memphis.'

A genuine American nightmare that is not only uncompromisingly ferocious but truly original, and as much an art film in its way as another fact-inspired murder movie shot a year earlier by another Texas-connected filmmaker, Terrence Malick's 'Badlands.'

'I'm rooting for the crocodile,' announces Betty White. The line is funny and revealing: The film is smart enough to admit the monsters are usually the most interesting characters in these movies, but it's also smart enough to make the people interesting.
Hasn't Africa suffered enough?
Without minimizing Monroe's crime, the movie becomes a de facto argument in favor of justice tempered with mercy and understanding rather than mandatory and draconian sentencing.

Operating out of a crummy lifelong bachelor's apartment, this prolific art forger is an unassuming and even sympathetic mastermind. With his tall, thin frame and baldish head, he resembles an El Greco Eisenhower, accessorized with Alfred E. Neuman ears.
The story's resolution suggests that the curse of trivial self-absorption is harder to shake off than any ancient bloodlust.

Josephine Decker's dreamlike quasi-thriller of primitive psychology and goatish sexuality offers a setup that suggests 'The Postman Always Rings Twice' as filtered through Terrence Malick, but then proceeds at its own off-step pace.

It's like a lo-fi version of 'Charade' or a hangdog hipster update of 'The Thin Man,' with the frustrated Levine as an amateur sleuth who unearths mysteries of the heart that -- unlike tidy criminal conspiracies -- resist explanation.

Leah Meyerhoff's earnest debut is more notable for the integrity of its female point of view and the consistency of its raw yet dreamy visual scheme -- which includes stop-motion fantasy interludes -- than for its familiar coming-of-age scenario.
High school cheerleading as a competitive team sport is the subject of this traditionally structured, extremely entertaining and ultimately even moving documentary...
The film becomes somewhat overwrought during its busy finale, but it's clever enough to be a candidate for cult status among genre aficionados who prize the pleasures of traditional storytelling.

Stylized almost to abstraction (and sometimes to distraction -- such flourishes as fancifully designed subtitles diminish the intensity), this superior revenge film presents life as a series of pitiless, brutal and lethal negotiations...
Operates on the theory that audiences will find more value in Hawking's expressions of Oprah-level sentiment ('Where there is life, there is hope') than in his mind-blowing science.

Dido in 'Belle' and Noni here wouldn't seem to have a lot in common, but both roles present Mbatha-Raw as a woman searching for her authentic self within a cultural context that prefers compromised or cartoonish representations of black identity.
The wild life, risky art and radical politics of an African revolutionary receive generally entertaining if inappropriately conventional treatment in this documentary...
The movie struck me as unreal and vaguely ridiculous; I found it easy to imagine Will Ferrell in the role of Fletcher, a switch that would require no decrease in tantrums and no change in dialogue.
The sentimentality and Hollywoodized convenience of the storytelling prevent this mostly admirable film from achieving the escape velocities of Kubrick or Tarkovsky.
A showcase for Culkin's hatchet-faced and eventually knife-wielding intensity...
An ambiguously motivated and almost surreal revenge film so open to interpretation it could be the '2001' of Westerns.

If the plot and colorful teen heroes are familiar, the setting -- the near-future metropolis of San Fransokyo (imagine a benign 'Blade Runner') -- is intriguing, and the animation -- as always these days -- is dazzling.
A thirtysomething single mother in Oregon transforms herself into a champion mixed martial arts cage fighter in this bruises-and-all documentary...

Like the team's earlier 'Horns and Halos,' which involved the George W. Bush presidency, this documentary suggests that the conventional world that most of us operate within is a phony if comforting illusion that hides a realm of privilege and horror.

Wirkola finds room for at least one good sight gag (a zombie commandant becomes frustrated when he is unable to return a 'Sieg heil!' salute due to his chopped-off right arm) before he succumbs to the hee-haw bloodbath of the battle royale finale.
movie_title: Dead Snow 2: Red vs. Dead (Død snø 2) (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Has the added benefit of giving 92-year-old Christopher Lee one last (perhaps) chance to be a bad-ass onscreen...
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies (2014)

movie_review_blurb: One song is performed by Annie and Stacks while they are strapped into seats in a helicopter, not a promising scenario for those who remember when even the most routine movie musicals were vehicles for choreography, athleticism and physical expression.
The film overall is tough and physical, thanks in large part to Witherspoon's convincing work as a woman scuffing calluses from her heart with each step of her blistered and bloody feet.
A treasure trove of content for Presleyologists who interpret Elvis as a repository and reflector of America's conflicted and evolving attitudes toward youth, class, race and sex.

This harrowing documentary might be described as 'Grey Gardens' on the highway to hell -- it's a portrait of an ornery rockabilly old-timer-on-the-edge that is as funny as it is frightening and as compassionate as it is shocking.

Scream Factory has issued 'Vault' uncut in America for the first time, on Blu-ray; the transfer restores several gruesome visual punch lines, including one involving Glynis Johns, gap-toothed Terry Thomas, and a hammer.
movie_title: The Vault of Horror (Tales from the Crypt, Part II) (1973)

movie_review_blurb: The first killer Claus may be the 'homicidal maniac' in a Santa suit who menaces Christmas Eve murderess Joan Collins in this British anthology horror movie inspired by the EC horror comics of the 1950s.
Two-year-old Jude Swanberg -- a ham as chubby as a sausage -- deserves at least a few Best Supporting Actor votes.
Something of a forced march, but worth seeing for its old-school studio vibrancy and for Curtiz's ability to compose for depth as well as breadth within the widescreen frame.
Suggests the pressures faced by working women can be more harrowing than any horror movie...
Barely there Morgan Freeman and Kris Kristofferson pick up the easiest paychecks of their careers, while top acting honors go to Mavis the sea turtle and Rufus the comic-relief pelican.
The Christmas-morning thrill of discovery is appropriately evoked in this warm and spirited if scattershot documentary...
Like many modern documentaries with aspirations to theatrical distribution, the film confuses a lack of clarity with cinema verite integrity.

A thoughtful Western that suggests insanity may be as logical a form of refuge, rebellion and self-expression as any for desperate women -- now as well as then? -- condemned to emotional isolation, unpaid hard labor and sexual servitude by loutish men.
Working the space between the De Niros of 'Taxi Driver' and 'The King of Comedy,' Gyllenhaal is memorably creepy and almost cadaverous...

In transforming Katniss from victim/champion to icon and expanding the stakes from personal survival to political revolution, this third film sacrifices some of the metaphorical power of its teen-centric predecessors...
In its merger of deadpan arrested-development comedy and mentally disturbed menace, it suggests an unholy recombination of Napoleon Dynamite and Freddy Krueger.
A portrait of life in all its ' dirty, rotten, gallin' ' unfairness and uncertainty.
A superior monster movie that unfortunately devalues Godzilla's status as an anti-war metaphor and a caution against the abuse of science and power.

With its allusions to Baudelaire, Beardsley and Wilde himself, this motion 'Picture' was meant for an adult audience that could sense the youth-runs-Wilde wickedness perpetrated by the title character offscreen, in the spaces between the frames...

Most notable for a cast that includes Soleil Moon Frye, the former Punky Brewster, as a spooky teenager ('This stuff is way beyond Ouija boards, you guys'), and Roger Clinton, half-brother of then-President Bill Clinton, as 'Mayor Bubba.'

The opening scenes are filled with stop-motion animation, a mouse blowing soap bubbles and other delights; later episodes are dark and ashen. The effect is that of Pee-wee's Playhouse slowly sinking into the dank tarn that claimed Poe's House of Usher.
Fincher's compositions offer the characters no exit; the widescreen keeps them in view, no matter how extreme their deceits and disguises.
Laika's oddest feature yet, a film that adds a faceful of leeches and a Monty Python/Mr. Creosote homage to an already eccentric story.
With Alfre Woodard as yet another of those hardworking and self-sacrificing movie black women who takes one for the team, 'the team' being affluent, elegant white folks.

This Vlad is not just an impaler but a hugger, at least when his young son is around. He is 'endearing,' according to his beautiful wife, citing a quality rarely if ever attributed to Bela Lugosi or Christopher Lee.
