An affecting drama made more poignant by honest-feeling autobiographical elements, Erik Poppe's A Thousand Times Goodnight examines the choice between family and career when that career represents work of real social importance.
Entertaining doc is sweeter than expected and will be an eye-opener for young fans.
More warm-hearted than funny, Schwarz's feature debut benefits from an intelligent script and sympathetic lead performance by Griffin Dunne.
The picture's sour notes are balanced by fine performances and clear historical appeal.

However tired one may be of the mockumentary format, the shtick is well suited for this material; in fact, it's easy to imagine a straighter storytelling approach falling flat or playing like an Addams Family rip-off.
movie_title: What We Do In The Shadows (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A sincere, psychologically savvy take on YA supernatural fare.
Sometimes tender, sometimes frantic, and always funny, the film's surprising coherence is exemplified in a climactic scene that pairs credible heartbreak with pure slapstick.
Achieves in an hour and a half something Republicans wanted desperately to do throughout 2012: It makes Mitt Romney human. Lovable, even.
True second-chance story doesn't come to life onscreen.
Involving story of scientific discovery and petty politics.
Keogan and Green's resolution, which underplays melodrama and avoids sentimentality, is unusually (and, given the characters' natures, appropriately) restrained.
Blah Britpic offers scenery but little else.
Formulaic but likeable.
A women-in-prison flick hawking its exploitation wares more to sadists than sex fiends.
The hourlong experiment is mainly for queer-theory students and Francomaniacs.
Eye-popping photography should draw viewers to this thoughtful, revealing doc.
"Raging Bull" it ain't -- it's not even "Rocky IV."
One of the most involving works of cinematic misanthropy in years.
The film's reason for being, though, is the sound of Page's voice -- a worldly, aged Southern drawl -- as she recounts her life story from childhood through retirement.
Dark, violent thriller stands on its own despite its revered predecessor.
Doc offers revelations alongside an invigorating recap of Hanna's influential career.
Occasional laughs don't outweigh an incoherent tone in gay-forward teen comedy.
An almost entirely hand-drawn, animated film that was clearly a labor of love for the director and has enough charm to reach a wider audience than his other recent docs.
movie_title: Is the Man Who Is Tall Happy?: An Animated Conversation with Noam Chomsky (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Jia offers a stark presentation (no music, few edits) that discourages vicarious thrills; the violence is startling, not cool.
Laughs outweigh pathos in likable movie about a woman's need to have a baby.
Home-movie-like document of a disastrous film production offers a few laughs.
Heavily dependent on Wes Anderson's aesthetic but charming nonetheless.
Observational doc offers an intimate view of a huge Pakistan charity.
Basketball fans who already know Cooke failed to make the cut will learn little here; viewers hoping for broader insights will find even less.
Wood makes Birdie approachable enough that Sam's continuing treatment of her as a fantasy-girl, who could only like a fictionalized version of him, grows tiresome as the film progresses.
The affecting, well-conceived story explores collectively repressed Holocaust guilt.
Sometimes feels like a beautiful illustration, rather than an adaptation, of Kerouac's prose.
This mainstream theatrical release is inferior to its shorter educational-film cousin.
Formulaic but effective comedy survives a performance that first threatens to overwhelm it.
A tense drama with well drawn characters and only as much action as its story requires.
This outing will please Swanberg's followers but lacks the polish required to attract a broader genre audience.
Very polished doc has more on its mind than action in the ring.
Motivated by an earnest need to inspire, Schmidt's debut suffers from stiffness but improves as it goes, the tension of its plot overcoming many dramatic failings.
Atmosphere and nostalgia trump all in Pushkin-loving romance.
Action takes a backseat to local color in well-acted drama.
movie_title: Stand Clear Of The Closing Doors (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The easygoing comedy keeps a familiar story going despite minor plot hiccups.
Enjoyable ghost story makes good use of clashing perspectives.
A numbingly unfunny sex farce
Thomas Haden Church bridges the credibility gap in snowed-in fugitive tale.
Affectations trump substance in self-conscious art film.
Funny and self-effacing doc says more about its maker's insecurities than the rock tour it chronicles.

Grimy and sad but not sensationalistic, the debut feature is like Drugstore Cowboy drained of its hipness and sex appeal -- not a bad thing, certainly, but also not something that ensures strong commercial prospects beyond a limited arthouse run.
Funny quasi-horror pic keeps viewers guessing.
An uproarious and hugely commercial vision of intergenerational warfare.
Intriguing non-pro actors are badly served by a half-baked film.
A chilly allegory whose antihero is both compelling and repulsive.
Each actor fills his role nicely, and they have enough chemistry to animate the routine pitfalls this road trip has in store for them.
Grown-up romance and disturbing psychology make a satisfying match.
Enjoyable doc celebrates theater pros who rarely see the spotlight.
High-energy chase pic makes the most of a novel setting.
Cast and crew generate an enjoyable sense of community in Odd's hometown. Odd Thomas just doesn't leave us with much desire to return there.
The end result satisfies both our vicarious greed and the desire some viewers will have to see a priceless work of art wind up in the hands of someone who couldn't care less about its price.
Less exploitative and a bit smarter than its seedy adult-film setting would suggest.
Funny and sympathetic memoir goes easy on the tale's dark side.

From production values to performances to the script, everything here is more polished than we've come to expect from Shelton's lovably loose films. Yet the finished product still feels of a piece with that body of work.
Emotionally involving doc captures the highs and lows of an idealistic schooling experiment.
Eye-opener introduces a glam rocker who should be a better known part of pop history.
Icily beautiful story of loss-fueled floundering is long on mood and sense of place.
Entrancing images will awe some viewers and leave others scratching their heads.
A convincing tale of a too-early coming of age gets strong performances from a cast of newcomers.
A fairy tale about parenting that stays kid-friendly without completely glossing over the darker themes of its premise.
movie_title: The Odd Life of Timothy Green (2012)

movie_review_blurb: An alien invasion flick that evidently expects dramatic shots of a depopulated Red Square to make up for a flatlining screenplay and the absence of even a single compelling character.
Underdogs stand their ground in Anthony Baxter's modest but revealing doc.
Doc provides plenty of laughs while proving there's more to Rivers than plastic surgery jokes and red-carpet chatter.
movie_title: Joan Rivers: A Piece Of Work (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Genre-savvy monster movie approaches Midnight Movie zone without abandoning the mainstream.
A jerry-rigged contraption whose rubber-bands-and-baking-soda construction is lucky to work once and then fall apart.
Beautiful scenery and a cute premise can't camouflage a stale plot in bland romance.
Funny, unexpectedly violent romp lets a regular kid play superhero for a while.
Moviegoers will have to admit the movie is true to itself.
A clever DIY comedy that could be this year's Humpday for art house audiences in search of characters they recognize from their own lives.
Directing debut for Mark Ruffalo presents supernatural premise in an unexpectedly unironic way.
Good-looking but not very effective.
Gutierrez's script can't supply female characters as believable as Almodovar's, but in the director's chair he gives his cast room to compensate with funny, self-aware performances.
A 'true story' of ghosts and illness suffers in comparison to the director's attention-getting short Ward 13.
Partly but not completely thanks to Rogen's committed performance, Observe manages the funny-pathetic arc of its story line vastly better than Hill's debut film The Foot Fist Way.
A broad but satisfying multiplex comedy.
Guy Maddin docu about his hometown gives fans everything they'd expect, plus a few moments of unexpected sincerity.
Solid rom com finds another Judd Apatow acolyte moving into the spotlight.
Filmmaker Brett Morgen returns with another livelier-than-usual entry in the nonfiction field, a portrait of '60s activism that mixes vintage footage with cartoon-animated re-enactments.
Real-life rags-to-riches Vegas scheme makes for glossy if lightweight fun.
Political awareness doesn't spell preachiness in slice-of-life directing debut for actor Mark Webber.
Stop-Loss has painted itself into a dramatic corner, which might be the most honest expression of the filmmaker's empathy for the men and women serving in Iraq.
Excellent concert docu revisits a neglected chapter in Reed's back catalog.
an involving film with fresh perspectives that should ensure appeal on the activist and festival circuits.
Lacks the fresh charm that made their first such an unexpected (if guilty) pleasure.
movie_title: Harold & Kumar Escape from Guantanamo Bay (2008)

movie_review_blurb: An entertaining pic that will fascinate admirers but is wide-ranging and unpretentious enough to engage those intimidated by Glass' aesthetic.
movie_title: Glass: A Portrait of Philip in Twelve Parts (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Daniel Day-Lewis stuns in Paul Thomas Anderson's saga of a soul-dead oil man.
Initially intriguing but ultimately saddled with more quirks than it can handle.
movie_title: With Your Permission (Til døden os skiller) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: With subtle laughs but solid emotional thrust, it will play very well with older audiences.
Short on sensational elements but involving, it won't set multiplexes on fire but should make a decent showing thanks to cast and plot.
Davis Guggenheim tells some inconvenient truths about public education in compelling new doc.
Grim backwoods tale takes its time building momentum.
In-depth account of Army deployment in an Afghanistan hotspot shows soldiering at its most rugged.
Harrowing Nazi footage of the Warsaw ghetto is made to reveal more than its makers intended in this historically invaluable doc.
Offers a certain mild slacker charm.
Micro-budgeted sequel improves on its obscure predecessor while giving ample screen time to actresses who don't get enough elsewhere.
Seminal hip-hop act gets due praise in solid bio-doc.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Tedious horror experiment steals gimmicks from actual avant-garde works and makes them look dull.
Silly cat-and-mouse comedy doesn't make much of its evangelist-mocking premise.
Debut by writer/director Elgin James offers a sensitive but not fragile look at young friends in a crisis.

Ian Cheney's The Search for General Tso is as much an immigration history as a culinary one, observing how a people who were demonized as low-wage laborers found entrepreneurial success in small and large towns across the country.
Laugh-laced dark drama of family angst overcomes the hurdle of its wedding-weekend setting.
Wales-set coming-of-age film is stylish, very funny debut for writer/director Richard Ayoade.
Performances are strong across the board, and the movie offers a solid sense of place. But the mysteries, once explained, don't make a lot of sense.
Horror and cold humor commingle in Dogtooth.
This movie really doesn't think much of its hero.
Deeply felt first-love tale offers convincing performances and a fine-tuned storytelling sensibility.
The film's final act is unbelievable, even if we ascribe hidden motivations to uncharacteristic behavior.
Documentary peeking into a high-stakes French competition will fascinate foodies.
Incoherent parable about sexual immaturity offers strung-together cliches and a few remarkably bad performances.

An amateurish comedy that sets up straw-man playboys to knock them over with the power of love, Speed-Dating seems designed to exploit the black indie theatrical circuit but hardly merits even a DVD release.
Although tailor-made for genre fans, it benefits from flavors of humor and romance that keep its appeal from being fanboy-only.
Exploitation remake delivers sadism and gore but little else.
Unpretentious swords-and-sandals film crafts a tight survival drama out of Roman Empire lore.
A joy to watch despite the abject poverty it contains.
Steve Carell finds a character more clueless than Michael Scott in broad laffer redeemed by occasional quirks.
Lively and touching doc combines insider view of its art-star subject with smart present-day interviews.
Informative and fannish burlesque doc is shapeless compared to its curvy subjects.
Well put-together doc reminds viewers there's plenty to fear on the nuclear-weapons front.
Chadha and her team, with their TV-sitcom color palette and quick comic pacing, clearly aren't shooting for plausibility, and audiences in search of a few easy laughs won't be disappointed.
Twisty tale of social-media intrigue makes for crowd-pleasing doc.
Almost comically overconvinced of the importance of its subject, Vidal Sassoon: The Movie is nonetheless entertaining and comprehensive in its account of the man's career.
Amateurish storytelling threatens urban-naturalist doc, but doesn't quite kill it.
Director [Juan Antonio] Bayona employs the visual language of horror films...with restraint and good taste.
Lars might at first sound like a movie you wouldn't want your kids to see, but it has a heart of gold.
A solid, well presented history of the band's brief career, Joy Division has appeal for music buffs but could get mileage in theaters from a smart coordination with the feature film's release.
Polish take on generic crime material is dull, except for a self-parodic soundtrack.
Stand-up tour doc offers laughs and amusing surprises, but doesn't justify a runtime as long as its title.
movie_title: Vince Vaughn's Wild West Comedy Show: 30 Days & 30 Nights - Hollywood to the Heartland (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Impending history and potent music energize this Apartheid-era suspense film.
Tarsem and his screenwriting collaborators aren't able to come up with enough interesting justifications for their sudden shifts, and soon the shape-shifting yarn just feels like lazy storytelling.
Viewers who don't loathe it immediately may find it the guilty pleasure of the season.
An across-the-board stunner.
The picture pleases while remaining unchallenging to a broad audience.
For a subject that plays such a large part in America's foreign policy and is so little understood, Shadow Company is an excellent and engaging primer.
In Clean, Assayas returns to his comfort zone -- the world of appealing young people with interestingly chaotic lives -- and views it through the eyes of a woman who doesn't belong there anymore.
First-time filmmaker Josh Gilbert, whose skills behind the camera are rudimentary, might be a bit too close to his subject to do disinterested viewers justice.
Heavens Fall tells its story with some interesting stylistic flourishes (a brisk montage of lawyers' closing arguments, for example) and without emotional manipulation.
Lifeless and irredeemably sour.
That the movie holds viewers' attention despite its contrivances is a testament to the script and acting.
Not every admirer of the first film will enjoy it, but it values its subjects too much to mold their rhythms to an outsider's attention span.

There's very little that Romano does in this behind-the-scenes feature by first-timer Tom Caltabiano that isn't stupefyingly dull. It's no crime for a comedian to be a dud offstage; releasing a movie to prove this isn't the wisest career move.
Andy Dick plays a very familiar role in his funny if thin feature-directing debut.
Shouldn't an overwrought drama about the life-shattering effects of gambling addiction make some effort, before delivering its moral, to show why people gamble in the first place?
The movie provides a good time but isn't wholly satisfying in the end.
Entertaining and solidly crafted.
A comedy so unfunny that its biggest laugh comes when an actor (for the second time) takes a tennis ball to the groin.
The film never convinces us that its main characters really belong in this seamy world.
Favreau again delivers that rare beast -- a family film that even childless adults can enjoy.
Never completely finds its balance.
It's an engrossing and often very funny tale.

Filmmakers Garrett Scott and Ian Olds spent many weeks with their subjects. As a result, soldiers opened up more for their cameras about reasons for enlisting and concerns about the job they were sent to do.
If its aspirations are modest, The Wendell Baker Story does embody the dry wit and easy charm that has (along with Luke's looks) won the Wilsons so many fans.
Viewers hoping to understand the senseless phenomenon of football hooliganism would do better to rent Alan Clarke's nearly 20-year-old The Firm.
The most interesting English-language film [Li] has made yet -- an action picture with the emotional simplicity of a bedtime story, painted in the grimy colors of the London underworld.
A film with none of the heart that has characterized Weitz's best work and none of the freshness of his most successful.
Sporadically funny though less effective at selling its melancholy undercurrents.
Icon of bad taste John Waters plays kindly uncle to tomorrow's delinquents in funny one-man show.
Idiosyncratic horror film mixes science and the supernatural.
Warm-hearted and accessible.
An enjoyable enough primer that it may nurture fans to support the rockers in their old age.
movie_title: Amazing Journey: The Story of The Who (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The movie's split-personality frustrates, especially since cast and crew do their jobs perfectly well
...despite lacking marquee stars could do well with the date-night mainstream.
Apatow's gleefully raunchy movies are, in an odd and charming way, extremely family-friendly.
A movie about conscience that flatly refuses the catharsis and redemption a mainstream feature would demand, Great World of Sound is a dirty gem, shining despite the modesty of its production.
A thoroughly winning feature that, despite appearing to be made with the small screen in mind, could hold its own theatrically in the feel-good docu niche.

If the picture secretly hopes to supply viewers with the kind of epiphany its characters seek, it falls short, staying instead on turf tread in many other good-hearted festival films before it. Within that arena though, it holds its own.

The product of restless comic imaginations that would rather bounce to the next idea than milk the previous one for every drop. Some viewers may be exhausted by the barrage, but few will complain of not getting their money's worth.

The prisoner's journalistic tendencies served him well in jail: He chronicled details of his captivity, including names and serial numbers of fellow prisoners, in places guards wouldn't notice (like the inside of his boxer shorts).
movie_title: The Prisoner Or: How I Planned to Kill Tony Blair (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Smart, fair primer on Michael Moore's divisive career offers a couple of eye-opening moments.
[A] deeply heartfelt film.
A pure, mostly dumb comedy, it's the tale of one impossibly out-of-it girl, Anna Faris' Jane F., who spends her day stumbling from mishap to mishap in an effort to avoid her drug dealer's wrath.
Solidly made, timely and spotlighting a fine performance by Paddy Considine.
Out of Sight scribes slides nicely into director's chair with darker crime tale.
Documentarians Chris Bradley and Kyle Labrache keep things moving at a nice pace while indulging Gurwitch's possibly too frequent attempts to tie the expanding film in to the event that inspired it.
It won't enter the quirktastic-voyage hall of fame, but it's a refreshing ride nonetheless.
If American moviegoers have plenty of reasons to feel icky about government-sponsored kidnappings and hidden prisons, Chronicle of an Escape gives them another good one.
[It] isn't as fresh or weird as the short films that made Tenacious D cult heroes but does capture enough of their spirit to please fans.
movie_title: Tenacious D in The Pick of Destiny (2006)

movie_review_blurb: ...A likable romantic comedy that delivers enough laughs and star appeal to fare reasonably well in the date-movie department, even if it doesn't entirely live up to its ambitions.
The whole fear-of-obese-hillbillies device is starting to smell as stale as Leatherface's playroom.
movie_title: The Texas Chainsaw Massacre: The Beginning (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A highly unusual viewing experience that stimulates the senses and the conscience simultaneously.
Smart, visually appealing, and consistently engaging.
Sarah Polley's directing debut is an assured, moving look at coping with Alzheimer's.
The inimitable Guy Maddin outdoes himself with psyche-probing silent film.
The action isn't nearly sufficient to carry all the mumbo-jumbo, and the cast doesn't have enough charisma to keep the script afloat on their own.
An artful experiment that's imposingly cryptic but comes from a respected filmmaker, it should appeal to its art house niche.
Kim brings more warmth and humor into Time than he has in some of his best-known work.
Rear Window meets the iTunes era in fun, slick suspense pic.
Well-crafted doc offers a scholarly account of the birth of Herzl's Zionist movement.
movie_title: It Is No Dream: The Life of Theodor Herzl (2012)

movie_review_blurb: The result is a largely entertaining picture with too few (and late-arriving) scares to satisfy the multiplex crowd, but one that will please many die-hard genre aficionados.
Less nutty and more moving than its premise suggests, Jodie Foster's on-target dramedy transcends its real-world baggage.
Amateurish vampire/musical mashup begs for a wooden stake.

A portrait of defiant optimism as a last-chance means of survival, Jon Shenk's The Island President offers not only a Mandela-like tale of political heroism but a much-needed perspective on climate change.
A delightful romp whose varied pleasures should please kids all along the age spectrum.
Science-themed rom-com isn't ready for clinical trials.
Modest road-film comedy goes to extremes to liberate its middle-aged heroine from an ultra-conservative household.
Neither the script's conspiracies nor Nicolas Cage's performance is weird enough to trump the film's generic feel...
Fly fishing is offered as a path to peace in rom-com whose ample charms are threatened by unnecessary buzz-kills.
A thriller so fixated on red herrings that viewers may stop caring if anyone's really in danger.
Seann William Scott plays against type in surprisingly funny, unsurprisingly lowbrow hockey flick.

If the ensuing plot beats are easy to chart in advance, they're sold by a good-natured cast and filmmakers who understand they'll get plenty of laughs even without digging too deep in the bag of tricks displayed in outings like The Ten.
Ghost Rider: Spirit of Vengeance nudges its obscure hero's mythology forward a bit without seeming to care much how it gets there.
LCD Soundsystem's die-hard fanbase will appreciate this concert documentary, but few others are likely to think it demands big-screen viewing.
movie_title: Shut Up and Play the Hits (2012)

movie_review_blurb: A big win for everyone involved, Safety Not Guaranteed is especially exciting for fans of Aubrey Plaza, who proves she's good for more than snarky scene-stealing and can actually carry a film.
Experimental debut is an engaging essay film about (probably) unrequited love.
The search for a missing dog leads to weird discoveries in surreal semi-comedy.
Powerful doc argues that the War on Drugs needs a dramatic rethinking.
Doc about dissident artist is long on political friction, short on art.
Challenging art is made accessible in doc about performance-art sensation Marina Abramović.
movie_title: Marina Abramovic: The Artist Is Present (2012)

movie_review_blurb: As fun as the movie occasionally is, it can't make its own drama convincing, much less give Reynolds the nudge he needs toward Matt Damon-ville.
Sincerely tries to pay homage to the likes of Jules Verne and Robert Louis Stevenson but is too contaminated by today's tame sensibilities to make it fly.
Up until near the end ... you could mistake it for a low-key haunted-house comedy.
Doc borne of an abandoned daughter's indignation is made watchable but not compelling by flamenco backdrop.
Horror-comedy from Phantasm director starts with a bang but quickly loses speed.
Doc about photographing glaciers makes a compelling environmental case without sacrificing beauty.
A stillborn May-November seduction makes for sexual tension and fascinating dialogue.
Doc about Detroit's state of abandonment offers snapshots and sounds but little new information.
Female buddy comedy makes the most of its phone-sex premise.

Being pantsless in the kitchen isn't quite as endearing for a thirtysomething dad, and kicking the joke up a notch with frontal nudity -- updating it for the Apatow age -- just emphasizes how old this franchise is.
Haunting doc about deaf-blind man handles heartbreaking subject with restraint.
Heartfelt interpretations of Seventies rock are only part of the appeal of nostalgia-drenched high school drama.

The Five-Year Engagement originates with a pre-mythologized meet-cute and ends with Hollywood whimsy but insists on making the hurdles between as little like rom-com contrivance as the filmmakers can get away with.
It isn't all bad news in a doc suggesting sustainability and culinary pleasure aren't mutually exclusive.

Viewers may suspect the filmmakers have no clue about the actual operation of fertility clinics and sperm banks (the plot depends on some pretty dubious practices, particularly involving donor anonymity), but most will be laughing too hard to care.
Story of a man's ill-concieved attempt to prove his merit as a father benefits from Frank Hvam's dry comic performance.
Class-consciousness is the strongest suit of a drug-world yarn that could have been much more energizing.
Poli-sci students may roll their eyes at true story of an upstart campaign for Seattle City Council.
Poignant and personal doc brings filmmaker's mental illness into focus.
movie_title: OC87: The Obsessive Compulsive, Major Depression, Bipolar, Asperger's Movie (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Opportunities for sentimentality are everywhere, of course, but a comically oversized group hug is about as syrupy as things get.
On the whole this is a routine mystery tale existing mainly to introduce new characters to the Wallander universe and allow for future installments.

Rising well above the typical making-of feature, the doc will fascinate buffs when shown alongside the operas themselves and should stand on its own... as a from-the-inside look at one institution's attempt to remain vital as its popularity fades.
Brandon Harris wears his Cassavetes influence on his sleeve for directorial debut.
It's hard to imagine it won't be a hit, and hard to begrudge that success, no matter how saturated we are with comic-book properties and sequels.
A satire in which pathos competes with light comedy and neither quite flourishes.
Semi-comic fantasia of violence against vapid pop culture can't do justice to its own ideas.
A pure-bliss celebration of Paul Simon's landmark album Graceland coupled with an interesting if not unbiased look at the controversy surrounding its release...
Involving account of legal wrangling over a stolen Egon Schiele painting.
We immediately understand why Cusack is not known for playing men who lived before 1984.
Its solitude-is-okay message is hardly novel, but Wein's comfortable way of reaching that point will resonate with viewers still trying to achieve that particular brand of enlightenment.
Rediscovered historical footage plants the seed for a moving, beautifully crafted Civil Rights doc.
Full-tilt French crime film weaves multiple threads of cat-and-mouse through the labyrinthine innards of a big nightclub.
Painter Wayne White emerges as an unsung force of nature in Neil Berkeley's zippy, delightful Beauty is Embarrassing.
Powerful sense of place roots film about the uneasy friendship between a 21 year old and an octogenarian.
A pre-Cyrus film by the Duplass Brothers bolsters their rep as distinctive low-budget auteurs.
Finely crafted English period piece works best for those who like their love stories romantically doomed.
K.L. Going's celebrated young-adult novel gets sensitive adaptation by actor-turned-director Matthew Lillard.
Colorful, loud doc digs into the peculiar life of one of rock's most bombastic drummers.
Achieving an almost trance-like intimacy by paring its array of voices down to the essentials, Chris James Thompson's Jeff stands apart from the true-crime pack.
Though riddled with credibility-straining coincidences and over-the-top humiliation, Jordan Roberts' Frankie Go Boom plays out with more charm than desperation.
A romance whose anodyne find-your-bliss theme is likeable but underwhelming, Lee Kirk's The Giant Mechanical Man doesn't fully exploit its premise's charms.
Tale of romantic obsession trades nail-biting suspense for credible realism.
Robot & Frank reminds quirk-hardened veterans that an odd premise and big heart don't have to add up to too-precious awards bait.
Nothing about the plot is novel, but the film easily maintains a low simmer that picks up in the final act, as Miller has to fight to keep his sinking ship staffed.
Borrows tropes from the rom-com playbook, and has enough laughs to be mistaken for one, but ultimately doesn't want to be pigeonholed.
While "Warrior" does offer enough jaw-snapping action to sate any 'roid-ragers in the audience, it works on deeper levels as well.
The Debt roots itself in reality more plausibly than most contemporary spy films without sacrificing the genre's tense thrills.
Flimsy dramatization of Russia/Georgia conflict fails both as historical re-enactment and as action-flick thrill ride.
Steve James' arresting documentary could benefit even more from a multi-part television treatment.
"Attack the Block" demands to be seen simply because it is a thrill - a pulse-raiser whose perfect construction and pointed wit make it one of the year's most exciting films.
Harlin's roots show throughout the picture, as he films real-life horrors with a bombast better suited to summer entertainment.
Momoa ... speaks in one of those trying-too-hard baritones heard in young jocks whose greatest fear is being called gay.
The script and acting satisfy the genre's requirements by being thoroughly forgettable.
"Point Blank" keeps the adrenaline flowing well past the point at which viewers stop hoping for twists they can't predict.
The next chapter in Laura's story might be something worth rooting for, but here's hoping she has a different writer penning her lines.
Unconvincing rock-biz melodrama feels even thinner when invoking legendary musicians.
movie_title: The Perfect Age of Rock 'n' Roll (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Evan Glodell's uncategorizable debut mixes messy romance and ill-advised D.I.Y. obsessions into a knotty but compelling vision of pop culture-damaged youth.
Absurd premise and weak script doom this comedy about haute-preschool angst.
Fleshing out now-familiar tales of misconduct and bad judgment, Palin investigation is entertaining but holds no dramatic discoveries.
You don't have to be a horse nut to fall for "Buck," one of those rare documentaries whose subject is so inherently fascinating that a fictional character could hardly compete.
Having decided not to risk offending us, it could at least work a little harder to earn our affection.
A film promising to take us behind the scenes of the Times for a year should show us more of the rationale behind the paper's big choices instead of viewing them from the remove of reporters.
movie_title: Page One: Inside the New York Times (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Doc about the real-life Horse Whisperer holds fascination both inside and out of the corral.
Downbeat vision of a small-time crook's final days offers a plum role for Dennis Farina.
movie_title: The Last Rites of Joe May (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Funny if less outrageous than expected given the boundary-pushing comedies that have found acceptance in recent years, A Good Old Fashioned Orgy earns its R but may leave audiences wanting more.
Drama about the small-town aftermath of a child's accidental death can't match its sincerity with dramatic heft.
Mildly nutty comedy about a teen prodigy suffers from an underwritten script and overstylized gags.
Sensitive doc manages to show Once duo as both blissed-out lovers and post-romance partners without overdramatizing the transition.
A portrait of the short-lived artist that will move fans while letting the uninitiated witness enough onstage highlights to leave them wanting more.
Conan O'Brien should take some satisfaction in the thought that Jay Leno will never earn as much laughter in half an hour as he and his crew does in the first third of Conan O'Brien Can't Stop.
A surprising number of these gotcha moments have the desired effect, and the picture's first hour strings them along through a familiar tale.
ADHD take on the teen comedy incorporates slasher comedy and pop-culture obsession, and will entertain those it doesn't alienate.
Gerwig handles her character's extreme mood swings with finesse.
Dull diary-film shoots for life/art profundity but misses by miles.
Yelling to the Sky drips with a strange but sometimes moving nostalgia for environs its characters clearly want to escape.
A home-invasion flick that grabs viewers by the throat and only stops squeezing long enough to wipe sweat from its palms...

A too-rare instance in which a gifted young actor signs on for a fright flick without coming away tainted, The Awakening places Rebecca Hall in a convincing historical setting and gives her more to do than widen her eyes in fear.
Adult Swim's cult series makes awkward stab at the big screen.
movie_title: Tim and Eric's Billion Dollar Movie (2012)

movie_review_blurb: A deceptively slight film that strikes the right balance between realist family drama and earnestness...
Thorny, blood-boiling and finely made, it deserves a theatrical push.
The Queen of Versailles will prompt loathing not only among the so-called 99 Percent, but among those in the top 1 percent who would like someone more sane to represent them on camera.
A man's-man of a genre pic that will satisfy the action audience while reminding more discerning viewers what they saw in director Joe Carnahan's decade-old breakthrough, Narc.
Making romance a big part of the mix dooms a movie already saddled with one of the worst titles in recent memory.
Dennis Quaid goes Psycho in dull Texas-set thriller.
First-timer Dee Rees offers a fresh take on the overfamiliar coming-out genre.
Sciamma pictures the story in dappled sunlight and wooded fields that, though not far from dull apartment blocks, have an out-of-time seductiveness.
Jonah Hill bites off more than he can chew in this '80s up-all-night comedy.
Failing to find deeper meaning in their protagonist's crises, they tell the story in a way that will only hold the interest of those who already know it fairly well.
Doc's incredible tale of WWII espionage would likely work better as a feature film.
Unconvincing tale of self-empowerment has attitude and anxiety but nothing underneath.
If the movie's sweetly earnest resolution scene plays a bit too easily, we like the characters too much to object.
Adaptation of an esteemed New Yorker story lightens the tone successfully while capturing the ugliness of a panic-inspired misstep.
The portrait is dispiriting overall, inspiring little affection from viewers, but feels authentic and fair.
Highbrow pedigree is mostly window dressing for a commercial period romance about Germany's literary giant.
A dinner of week-old turkey legs and stale mead would be more fun than this Ren Faire-set rom-com disaster.
The mock-doc approach is more stale than usual in TV vet Rob Schiller's racetrack comedy.
Géla Babluani's English-language remake of his French debut loses the source's gritty, mysterious gloom.
Arguably, the current generation of funk and soul revivalists owes a debt to musicians who forged their astonishing sound in between Algebra study sessions.
Crime doc about a dubious arson case is made more interesting by the involvement of Rick Perry.
We see a script and some underexposed actors who were lucky to find each other.

"Dee" doesn't shoot for the gravitas of Zhang Yimou's "Hero." It doesn't approach that film's magnificent sensory impact, either, or the artistic romanticism that made "Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon" such a success here.
movie_title: Detective Dee and the Mystery of the Phantom Flame (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Sharply focused and superbly put together.

The pace of these scenes can be trying -- and would be torture for viewers who came expecting a more conventional Asian crime film -- but it suits the movie's concern with family histories, rural isolation, and the inevitability of development.
The extremity of the film's slice-and-dice approach is invigorating at the outset but may also prompt viewers to suspect they're being challenged for no good reason.
Segel's performance is the heart of the film, his naive faith making other characters' bolder gestures believable...
Despite a few genuinely poignant moments (try not to be moved as Red Hot Chili Peppers bassist Flea talks of righting his parents' wrongs) and a bit of humor, F Word feels shallow and a little stale.
A small-town tragedy leads to moral crises on all sides in Sara Colangelo's Little Accidents, a sober drama that makes class central to the story without ever sounding like it has an agenda.
An enveloping look at a community whose centuries-old way of life may be ending.
Lynskey's performance is sympathetic, but the movie doesn't fully convince us in its dramatization of her responses to Quinn's large and small blunders.
The TV series version surely makes a lot more sense.
A routine teen thriller with some deeply dumb plot points.
The picture feels far more generic than its A-list cast would suggest.
This truck never gets into gear, and will have a very hard time tempting moviegoers on either large or small screens.
Intends to introduce novelty to its overfamiliar setup, but uneven casting and a very thin script get in the way.
Ian MacAllister McDonald's Some Freaks captures high school/college agony without transmuting it into thank-God-we-survived-it nostalgia.

A captivating feature debut despite some missteps, it flashes back to a time when every other filmmaking newcomer wanted to be Quentin Tarantino; surprisingly, it does not provoke the weary eye-rolling that greeted so many of those films.
People start dying, friends turn against each other and the dialogue is almost bad enough to make you keep watching.

Heaven knows, the books offer more invention than could fit in one feature film, but in their effort to introduce newcomers to this world, the filmmakers make the saga's contents look not archetypal but generic and cobbled together.
Mourns a centuries-old genocide through the torment of three young protagonists.
[An] enjoyable doc, which touches on everything from flamenco to Blade Runner and leaves us wanting more.
Begins as unpersuasive horror, then segues into annoyance-based comedy before veering in stranger directions.
Has value to all connoisseurs of punk culture, who will recognize the trials faced by a community attempting to put high-minded values into action.
movie_title: Turn It Around: The Story of East Bay Punk (2017)

movie_review_blurb: If only this smartphone-centric dud, so happy to hawk real-world apps to its audience, could have done the same in its release strategy - coming out via Snapchat, where it would vanish shortly after arrival. But even that wouldn't be fast enough.
Even those with a strong tolerance for monster-movie gore are far from guaranteed to accept its warm, clumpy bath of repugnant ickiness.
Far too broad to be deep in any respect, the lightweight documentary benefits from access to plenty of top-shelf interviewees but plays like a back-patting muddle.
This friendly doc is one more small chapter in the ongoing oral history of Downtown Manhattan around the turn of the Eighties, and will be appreciated by those who just can't hear enough.
movie_title: Who The F**k Is That Guy? The Fabulous Journey of Michael Alago (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Jason Zeldes, an editor on Twenty Feet from Stardom, makes an accomplished debut as director here, delivering a film whose polished aesthetic matches its social import and potent emotions.

Despite occasionally shaky storytelling, the doc sticks to its mission even as the most fundamental obstacles arise, producing a dramatic account that will make all do-gooders think twice about how they spend their charitable dollars.
Illuminating and enraging but marred by heavy-handed aesthetics.
Rather than speak to the camera about working with his hero, Homme reads from a journal of the experience, leaching much of the impact out of this once-in-a-lifetime opportunity.
It will be warmly welcomed by lovers of music that hasn't had its rough edges sanded away.

It demonstrates enough sincerity and openness to challenging ideas - letting representatives of this problematic movement make their case clearly and convincingly - that one wishes it were able to look at multiple sides of this debate at the same time.

Where many performance films suffer from being too attached to their present-tense anchoring event, Nierenberg's is expansive, letting its subjects range freely in interviews conducted in rehearsal rooms and on the street.
Though it does latch onto some engaging complications midway through, the feature still feels like it would play better as a half-hour short ...
Gooi's lush cinematography enlivens the chef's calm narration, making an umami-loving viewer consider braving an Arizona summer - if only for one evening - to taste all this.
movie_title: Kakehashi: A Portrait of Chef Nobuo Fukuda (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Lightweight but enjoyable doc targeting fans of stage and screen musicals.
Unimaginative and sensorily monotonous.
Gory and offensive, but lacking in the scare department.
Cho fares surprisingly well as the story pushes into themes of guilt, revenge and forgiveness, finding a resolution that is both unexpected and poignant.
An of-its-moment showcase for three up-and-coming performers.
Much "who's doublecrossing who?" ensues, and if the dialogue flags occasionally, there's always background action to contend with.

A perfectly adequate family film for kids who love watching things they've seen many times before (which is to say, most kids), it offers plenty of chuckles for their parents but nothing approaching the glee of that first Lego Movie.
A love story whose resolution remains tough to predict, Outside In respects all its characters by not pretending their choices are easily made.
Smart but perhaps a bit too restrained for its own good.
On the whole, sharp dramatization and direct performances suffice to put the story's themes across more urgently than expected.
Scary enough to please most genre buffs, it would also play well in art houses: If you were to go through and remove every hint of ghosts, you'd still have a drama well worth seeing.
An infuriating tale of stocks and fraud, but one that's easy for non-traders to understand.
A dazzling array of talent presented in a very modestly-made doc.
A rock-doc less vibrant than most.
movie_title: Eric Clapton: A Life in 12 Bars (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The most roundly satisfying fiction feature Wenders has made since, well, that first one about the angel so in love he gives up immortality.
An excellent blend of musical behind-the-scenes, open-hearted interviews, and performance.
movie_title: May It Last: A Portrait of the Avett Brothers (2017)

movie_review_blurb: However much its sentimentalized innocence stretches credulity, the overall production remains polished, and young dreamers who come across it in limited release may well embrace it.
It will more than satisfy Iannucci's fans at arthouses; here's hoping we don't have to wait another eight years to see the director's next film.
The film arguably gets to its midpoint before eliciting a single laugh.
Funny, bitter, and sometimes bleak, the picture draws much of its appeal from a deadpan performance by star Matti Onnismaa.
A treasure for those interested in Downtown New York's heyday and a demythologized Basquiat.
movie_title: Boom for Real: The Late Teenage Years of Jean-Michel Basquiat (2018)

movie_review_blurb: I, Tonya spins a convincing yarn despite, or maybe because of, its surfeit of unreliable narrators.
The solid ticking-clock biopic should perform respectably among serious-minded moviegoers, but lacks the oomph of a must-see.
movie_title: Mark Felt: The Man Who Brought Down the White House (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Though it never justifies the overblown Andre Agassi quote used as its preface ("every match is a life in miniature"), the picture certainly shows how a single match can be made to feel like the world depends on it.
... witless dialogue and a plot that has no idea where it's going or why - and certainly isn't capable of making us want to go with it.
It is a solid thriller that works best when it is most involved in its adolescent heroes' non-monster-related concerns.
Though occasionally lopsided, the mix works well, and should play best to teens raised on Japanese 'toons.
movie_title: Napping Princess (Hirune-hime: Shiranai watashi no monogatari) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Infuriating and, sadly, not at all surprising.
A polished portrait that should play very well to those with eye disease and to those who support them.
Of interest to Ronson or Bowie fans but hardly enlightening.
movie_title: Beside Bowie: The Mick Ronson Story (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Its run-of-the-mill standoff may appease some hardcore horror buffs, but it offers nothing to the rest of us and will likely be forgotten before the blood on the ground dries.
Though not as fresh or funny as its predecessor, this feature directing debut for actor Jay Baruchel stays true to its spirit and will please its most enthusiastic fans.
This trio's quest has something of a Luke/Han/Leia flavor to it, but the cast isn't charismatic enough to overcome the generic dialogue and plotting.
movie_title: Legend Of The Naga Pearls (Jiao Zhu Chuan) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A sometimes grating but earnest attempt to provoke "the conversation" about the world's inequalities.
Hang in there, True Believers: Maybe it'll get better the second time around.
Scattershot, introducing instrumentalists who've played everything from heavy metal to Disney kid-pop, and rarely doing much to capture its subjects' individual quirks.
The movie keeps bouncing around in time and space for reasons that aren't apparent, doing little to get us invested in the backstory to the event we've come to see discussed.
An assured, laid-back debut and a good next move for Zosia Mamet.
A thoroughly engaging, eye-opening showbiz doc.
Diminishing returns, but funny and lovely to look at.
An enjoyable doc overflowing with stunning pieces of clothing, both on models and on its star.

Adair, best known as Richard Linklater's go-to editor (and a co-producer on Boyhood) makes a confident debut as director here, offering a doc with appeal even for art lovers who don't yet know this regionally celebrated collagist.
movie_title: The Secret Life Of Lance Letscher (2017)

movie_review_blurb: As the story develops, the film seems more wishy-washy than pointedly ambiguous.
A lively look at a character who doesn't mind if you think he's destroying America.
I Am Heath Ledger offers intimacy but little sense of discovery.
Thanks in part to excellent editing and a subtly gripping score by Danny Bensi and Saunder Jurriaans, the doc never lags during its nearly two-hour running time.
Really, seeing these likable oldsters talk at length is just about the entire point of this picture.
movie_title: Mission Control: The Unsung Heroes of Apollo (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Amiable but underwhelming.

A sometimes laughable game-of-death drama that has been beaten to the punch by many other (much better) similar flicks, it is likely to vanish unseen, despite the pull of some established names in its cast.
An aesthetically uninspired but informative primer on the path this wardrobe staple has taken from the Old West to haute couture.
Certain plot points might seem far-fetched, but only until you think of similar things that have already happened, similar liberties that have been happily surrendered by users of popular networks.
Fate delivers exactly what fans have come to expect, for better and for worse, and it would be a shock to see it disappoint producers at the box office.
Respectably put together but inert ...
Though its cinematography is nothing to write home about, the action Alive and Kicking captures is so transfixing, one marvels that dancers can keep it up for five years, much less five decades.
Engaging and lively.
Looks like a holding pattern in a career that often threatens to attract attention beyond the festival circuit but hasn't yet managed to do so.
[An] informative but overserious documentary, which will find an audience on video but (in more ways than one) is less revealing than expected.
movie_title: Pornocracy: The New Sex Multinationals (Pornocratie, les nouvelles multinationales du sexe) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Insatiable genre fans who do buy a ticket will likely send lukewarm responses back to the wait-and-see crowd.
Vicious, mostly satisfying action.
A satisfying, stale-beer crime flick ...
The most convincing of the three features Joe Swanberg has made with star and co-writer Jake Johnson (each of which has represented a highlight in his filmography) ...
Comfortable with sleaze but a far cry from being Italy's answer to Deadpool, the pic isn't funny or daring enough to make much of an entry into a spandex-saturated American market.
movie_title: They Call Me Jeeg (Lo chiamavano Jeeg Robot) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: At its heart, it remains a quiet elegy for a woman who needn't have died so soon, or so alone.
As enjoyable as Atomic Blonde can be at times, its main utility may be its demonstration that Theron deserves better than this.
A sweet and speed-crazed crime film you can dance to.

One of the more action-packed features to come from the current crop of John Carpenter-inspired filmmakers, The Void finds collaborators Jeremy Gillespie and Steven Kostanski going much further than many of their peers.
The film is not lurid in its scares, and instead depicts its protagonist's suffering mostly as a slow rot.
Nevsky is also the pic's director and came up with the plot, evidently hoping to follow in the footsteps of Stallone, Schwarzenegger, et al. Judging from this effort, he hasn't got a chance.
Another Evil relies almost entirely on the subtle comic gifts of its two leads, finding little in the way of plot to kick its characters into laugh-generating action.
A polished and provocative call for activists to be as scientifically minded as they believe they are.
Has a hard time getting beyond its ostentatious quirks and getting to the point; for some viewers who catch what will likely be a very short run, though, that aimlessness will be its main virtue
An enjoyable, if slow-moving, tale of decades-long sibling conflict.
A slow-starting but effective lament.
Uneven but quietly true to its odd premise.
Very obviously the product of personal experience, the picture shares some of its protagonist's awkwardness and unsure footing.
A cheeky and provocative experimental look at a largely unknown subculture.
It's hard to muster anything like desire for another Dark Universe flick after seeing this limp, thrill-free debut.
An option of last resort for sci-fi-hounds who simply will watch anything with a spaceship or talking robot in it.
Genre fans should respect the picture if not embrace it wholeheartedly, but history buffs will find something to appreciate as well in this 16th-century tale.
Competent on all fronts but never dazzling, it should please genre devotees but won't cross over to a broader audience.

Emile Hirsch and Zoe Kravitz, as strangers thrown together by a violent incident, enjoy an easy chemistry here, encouraging viewers to forget the menace that starts the story and, with startling violence, will end it.
After Adios, many longtime fans will want to chase the taste away with a stiff shot of the old stuff.

Newcomers who can avoid feeling burned by occasional dishonesty should join longtime admirers in enjoying this account of a career Cattelan claims ended with his splashy Guggenheim retrospective in 2011.

Depp remains wholeheartedly the focus of this fifth Pirates film, and saying the character's loopy novelty has faded is like complaining that there are maggots in the below-decks gruel: You knew what you were getting when you came aboard.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Most likely to frighten viewers who begin nodding off and fear they'll be unable to rouse themselves to leave the theater.

Often suffers from hazy storytelling, but its real difficulty for many viewers will be its protagonist, who isn't the most sympathetic proxy for Americans curious about the plant extract's suitability to treat depression.
A post-apocalyptic drama as stripped-down as its title suggests, The Survivalist envisions end times in which each encounter with a new human entails a hard calculus of risk versus advantage.
A deeply peculiar folklore-informed picture in which unrequited love is more troubling than the plague, the Devil and a forest full of ghosts.
An irony-laced view of the Reagan years and the birth of made-for-TV governing.
Rarely lingers on any subject for long and even more rarely inquires about the beliefs behind the ceremonies it observes.
Viewers who'd prefer a bit more psychological probing may be left unsatisfied, but most will appreciate this chance to hang out with the legendary whistle-blower.
An enjoyable look at a tremendously influential broadcasting underdog.
A rich and enjoyable look at an easily caricatured artist.

Healy knows exactly the mix of comical bumbling and psychological tension he wants here, executing the premise in a way sure to please fans of his distinctive body of work ... and impress a few new ones along the way.
A no-frills primer on the history and prospects of a troubled nation.
movie_title: Angkor Awakens: A Portrait of Cambodia (2017)

movie_review_blurb: An unpredictably funny showcase for two very deserving actors.
A fawning but informative primer for music lovers with, er, very broad tastes.
movie_title: Clive Davis: The Soundtrack of Our Lives (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A rich and satisfying sensory experience, even without the sad real-world backstory.
An always-engaging look at a rarely explored piece of urban street life.
Few will argue ... with the effectiveness of its trapped-in-the-woods tension and the potency of its simmering ethnic hatred.
Oplev turns the conceit into just another excuse for rote haunting, making this Flatliners often indistinguishable from its 2017 thriller peers.
A slow-to-start but delightful tale of ancient magic and clueless men.
Devolves into an extremely familiar escape-the-monsters affair, with all the compounding dumbness usually involved when our fleeing heroes are forced to keep filming the action.
A thorough and well-assembled piece of dietary evangelism.
A very enjoyable middle-of-the-road adventure, especially for moviegoers willing to see just about anything starring Rudd.
Tyrel observes how wounds can fester, doing damage long after unaffected parties would have assumed everything was fine.
More powerful than its filmed-play format might suggest.
Likable moments are scattered throughout, even if (like a how-to-hitchhike nod to It Happened One Night) they aren't exactly fresh.

Cosmatos' ability to put us in Red's head - overwhelmed at first with pain and fury, then saturated by the strange drugs he for some reason feels compelled to try - make this much more than the usual exercise in vicarious bloodshed.
The film balances revulsion with allure and all its action against the question of who knows what, when.
A stylish and enjoyable fight flick with just enough tongue-in-cheek content to keep us smiling.

Packed with more than a couple of possible feminist readings as regards the parenting/career/life question, the often very funny picture entertains while affording its characters their share of no-laughing-matter concerns.
Rises above the pack in a few ways - ranging from its ambitious style to the out-of-whack humanity of its two lead performances.
A blood-boiling eco-doc whose story is far from over.
An entertaining if not comprehensive look at the bubble in blue-chip art.
A sincere, occasionally touching family dramedy with a music backdrop.
The Food Network crowd will go nuts for the doc, but beyond the shots of luscious dishes, there's a pretty interesting character study here, as well.
A period political thriller whose motivations remain timely.
An enjoyable ride that captures both the excitement of the party and the shameful details of its aftermath.
A safe but enjoyable take on the author's anything-but-safe early career.
All this would probably play better with the assistance of some weed, but it would be irresponsible to review a film while intoxicated.
movie_title: An Evening with Beverly Luff Linn (2018)

movie_review_blurb: Though hardly inattentive to the gender-specific themes here, Moselle and her cast never come down hard on them.
Blaze is more affecting than most other live-hard/die-ugly music biopics.
Smart, stylish doc exposes must-discuss issues regarding the companies who dominate the internet.
A compelling look at the toll activism takes.
A film that doesn't shy from the well-known darkness in the star's life but prefers to remind us how funny he could be.
movie_title: Robin Williams: Come Inside My Mind (2018)

movie_review_blurb: They're such interesting people, and the person telling their story cares enough to make them real.
An idiosyncratic, engaging look at a turning point in architecture's history.
movie_title: Tall: The American Skyscraper and Louis Sullivan (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A trainwreck of a sci-fi flick bent on extending a franchise that should have died a peaceful death almost exactly one decade ago.
Fake Blood hardly distinguishes itself from the glut of mock-docs; it may be a refreshing break for the filmmakers, but viewers might prefer another zombie flick.
An empathetic drama ready to put straight-laced audiences in the shoes of a maligned subculture.
Those ready for a quick time out from fight-the-power indignation may well roll with the picture, which relies on the charms of Purdy, an off-screen musician known as Koreatown Oddity.
While it offers some provocative moral quandaries, it serves mostly as a showcase for Patrick Stewart, playing a Juilliard dance teacher whose past has come back to haunt him.
However well or poorly it matches the truth of Dickinson's life, the film's vision of her long relationship with Susan is warmly funny.
The movie is unprepared for the crime-flick beats it tries to hit, and if Jonny's plan is a head-scratcher, the multiple twists that follow are even tougher to accept.
A modest but refreshing love story that takes its autistic protagonists on their own terms.
Quite enjoyable, but not essential for those who know Ali's story.
movie_title: Ali & Cavett: The Tale of the Tapes (2018)

movie_review_blurb: Putting a deliberately unromantic spin on its wish-fulfillment scenario, the film scratches a genre itch without using it as an excuse ... for vicarious sadism.
A Gotham-set charmer about the pleasures of wandering.
An affecting and, despite present circumstances, hopeful doc.

Despite finding some engaging experts to follow around in the field, the doc digs less deeply than it could have, offering little on the education side and at times feeling slightly like a well-produced promo film.

A rollicking adventure through worlds both bleak and fantastic, Steven Spielberg's Ready Player One makes big changes to the specifics and structure of Ernest Cline's best-selling novel but keeps the spirit and level-up thrills intact.
A character-driven take on today's battles over racism.
The presumed message - get off the couch and live for yourselves, young Americans! - might be a little more persuasive if our onscreen stand-in were not so revolting.
A seedy but sincere and strikingly attractive picture adapted from the novel by Nic Pizzolatto.
Suspenseful and funny, occasionally poignant and often nearly unbelievable, it captures a certain sociological flavor while remaining universally accessible.
Blockers imagines a world in which teens, left to their own devices, are competent to make their own choices, and in which girls stand a fair chance of not regretting their first sexual experiences.
The spirited performances are dampened by Edgerton's direction and the cutting of three credited editors. The picture feels much longer than its 110 minutes ...

A truly moving meditation on identity, family and (as the title of his previous short immodestly put it) the meaning of life, Hertzfeldt's magnum opus is more cosmically satisfying than The Tree of Life.
A doc packing much more charm than its esoteric-sounding subject might suggest.

Though armed with enough gore and pandering violence to enjoy some success with moviegoers who haven't yet been burned by star Bruce Willis' many recent flops, this generic attempt at a franchise reboot deserves to be killed.
The artwork is achingly delicate, but there's nothing subtle about Belladonna of Sadness.
Moments that hint at a psychedelic revelation to come never add up to much. Only in the last scene does the film seem to make good on the promise of its title.
An always colorful look at a short but exuberant career of avant-garde Utopianism.
Righteous themes don't keep this low-budget pic from playing like a drama class exercise.
Familiar but important points about our broken justice system, packaged for viewers who don't usually watch documentaries.
Insider details don't compensate for clumsy storytelling in a portrait of teen disillusionment.
movie_title: Confessions of a Teenage Jesus Jerk (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Striking a sometimes uneasy balance between trust-no-one espionage and sensationalism, Sparrow seems likely to attract a fairly large audience but leave few moviegoers fully satisfied.
Earnest and serious-minded but never really approaching the level of the story-dense dramas that clearly inspired it, the picture proves stiffly unconvincing ...
A diverting if unimaginatively named little doc.
Even moviegoers who don't accept the metaphor are going to have the pants scared off them.
In the end, Kangaroo is the kind of advocacy film that's most likely to convince you if you already believe.

Gutierrez Alea blends documentary and feature devices, steals street scenes that put fictional characters in real situations, and offers New Wave-influenced insights into a man who resents what's around him but can't bring himself to leave it.

The lyrics of that song may urge Proud Mary to keep on, but all evidence here says she should call it a day - letting the actress who plays her find some more worthy franchise if she really wants to be an action hero.
A hilarious and surprisingly warm look at the real life behind the abrasive persona.
Hawke delivers a workmanlike performance, but can't redeem the third act's macho baloney ...
Though this anecdote-stuffed doc leaves us wanting more of her songs-and-gags routine, it has just enough clips for us to wish she could return to the stage as well.
... Match clearly only aspires to be a thriller with a surprise or two up its sleeve. On that front, it's adequate.
Glossy alt-medicine doc will play well with the already convinced, but isn't as persuasive as some similar efforts.

Viktor Jakovleski's sometimes rapturous Brimstone & Glory takes us to Tultepec for two annual rituals that celebrate this livelihood, reveling in their spectacle and observing the days leading up to them.
Modest but funny, it makes a fine calling card for a performer deserving of bigger things.
Very effective follow-up offers more laughs and new kinds of awkwardness.
Big, dumb and boring, it finds the co-writer of Independence Day hoping to start a directing career with the same playbook - but forgetting several rules of the game.
Andrew "King Bach" Bachelor is amiable but hardly star material here, playing a young man whose hunt for buried treasure forces him to infiltrate a college fraternity.
In the end, the scariest thing about Boo 2! is the idea that A Madea Easter might be next.
movie_title: Tyler Perry's Boo 2! A Madea Halloween (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A welcome opportunity for Garrel's most fervent fans, but not an entry point for newbies.
An amusing hybrid venture that feels pretty thin at feature length.
A brisk and upbeat introduction to the creator of decades' worth of eye-dazzling art.

Though its pile-up of poverty, humiliation and bitterness threatens to make it a miserablist moral crusade, the film finds forward momentum in its protagonist, who is not yet ready to be destroyed by what the world has saddled her with.
Though slow to get rolling, it eventually builds into a worthy showcase for Pullman, who himself has too rarely stepped out of support roles.
Less a pulse-pounding thriller than a conversation starter about injustice and vigilantism.
The pic works well within its modest means, wringing life-or-death drama out of, basically, a debate over the accuracy of one man's gaydar.
Inverts the usual eco-doc formula, spending only enough time on problems to establish their importance, then traveling around the world to prove how satisfying the solutions can be.
movie_title: Wasted! The Story of Food Waste (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Architects of Denial has done, in some ways, the very thing it is rightly angry at others for doing: It has opened the door to doubt.
Dementia 13 proves to be not nearly demented enough.
A sensitive and attractive, if not wholly convincing, pairing of fantasy with real-life turmoil.
Shannon's contemplative but engaged performance is a good companion to 1980 Dylan, who in these concerts is far from standoffish.
A boosterish tone makes the doc feel like a sneaky infomercial or a Denver Visitors' Bureau film. But maybe anybody who thinks that just needs to lighten up and take a hit.
An earnest film whose arguments are best suited to the small screen.
An involving sports-rivalry doc with an AI twist.
Though we care for those who lost loved ones, and root for them as they pursue a decades-long hunt for the killers, No Stone Unturned plays like a very well made piece of true-crime television.
Justin Long, whose career was built on mild likeability, suffers for that mildness here, in a film that flounders right along with him.
A broadly appealing bad-behavior comedy relying on the winning chemistry of its two leads.
Even it weren't arriving immediately after his death at the age of 91, this effortlessly moving portrait would be a milestone in Stanton's career ...
Underexploring its less sympathetic aspects in favor of a feel-good senior citizen narrative, the doc lacks the psychological depth and sensitivity of many other recent trans-oriented films.
However mediocre the first film was, this sequel not only makes it seem charming by comparison but gives viewers the dubious gift of a full-on sappy Christmas movie two weeks before Thanksgiving.
Thought-provoking conversations filmed with minimal production value.
Though the FX and photography are competent for a film of this scale, the screenwriters appear to have put much less effort into dialogue and pacing.
Where Damien Chazelle observed lovers filled with a desire to make it in entertainment, [Julia] Murat's picture revolves around the need to make art, with career an afterthought.

The hour-long experiment entertainingly answers a question nobody thought to ask: What if Guy Maddin made a Christian Marclay-style assemblage evoking the ghosts of pre-tech San Francisco and Alfred Hitchcock's Vertigo?

As has been the case since the first film, this one centers on shock cuts and sudden appearances of figures in the shadows. While the franchise's technical overkill may have mellowed over time, the delivery of the boos remains cheap and arbitrary.
A thought-provoking doc for adventurous foodies and environmentalists alike.

An exceptional program that starts off strong and only gets better as it goes, the 19th Annual Animation Show of Shows overflows with charm while containing more provocative observations about the nature of existence.
movie_title: The 19th Annual Animation Show of Shows (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Who's your daddy? Who cares.
A feel-good treat for Frisell's legion of fans.
Stars Will Smith and Joel Edgerton play it mostly straight here, doing their part to sell the dopey premise, but the screenplay offers viewers little reward for our own suspension of disbelief.
Viewers with a high tolerance for computer-generated fantasy are the target this time, and may well enjoy the ride.
Moore, who wears blue sunglasses through almost the whole film, comes across as a child of privilege who never got around to doing anything with the advantages life handed him.
Strong on-a-budget FX help compensate for lousy writing in for-the-geeks programmer.
Del Monte offers a warm portrait of a thoroughly winning subject.
Soul of Success does little to capture the eureka moments Canfield evidently produces for his followers. Maybe the doc is worried about giving the goods away for free.
movie_title: The Soul of Success: The Jack Canfield Story (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A lively tale bent on deepening our understanding of its sensationalism-ready subject.

Though it is overshadowed by many foodie and eco-themed docs before it, the film's tight focus may make it a hit with earth-loving athletes who need to convince teammates and family members they aren't crazy to give up meat.
The doc delivers enough arresting Neapolitan moments that many viewers will consider tracking down the source material - still in print, nearly four decades after Lewis published it in 1978.

Respectable period production values and some recognizable castmembers are no substitute for imagination in this flat crime flick, which steals freely from its predecessors but offers none of their guilty-pleasure thrills.
movie_title: Gangster Land (In the Absence of Good Men) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Effective despite some storytelling flaws, the documentary is nonetheless unlikely to draw too much attention on the national stage, with fresher outrages never hard to come by.
A solemn reminder of the humanity of those society chooses not to see.
An imperfect but moving argument that communities share blame for the abuse they fail to stop.
An allegory of sexual inequality in the guise of a relationship drama.
Cook Off piles some better-than-this comedians into a culinary competition whose dishes look as unpalatable as the film itself.
Its dedicated interviewees make the subject's seriousness undeniable, and with luck, their cause will attract attention as the film tours theatrically.
Friendly but matter-of-fact doc will play best with the troupe's existing fans.
A good-hearted but overly broad and underwhelming debut.
Though it's not particularly inventive, the film has a fine time pitting office-dwellers against each other.
The film's main appeal is in watching familiar actors pretend to be ordinary kids grappling with their new selves.
New look at well-charted territory adds just enough to justify its existence.
Despite multiple onscreen timestamps, the film doesn't generate ticking-clock tension so much as it paints a picture of dead ends and foreordained poverty.
Suffice to say that Song to Song is not designed to win back onetime admirers who felt Malick's To the Wonder and Knight of Cups drowned in their own navels.
In its account of the many ways corporations shield their dough, the film lacks specifics that would be useful to many viewers.
Despite its apparently sincere identification with its protagonist, Entertainment feels like a sick joke.

A fairly specialized picture in a sea of Holocaust material, Legacy is novel and professionally made enough... [and] it also offers psychological insights of interest to those who have no interest in another WWII-related doc.
movie_title: What Our Fathers Did: A Nazi Legacy (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Ayat Najafi's No Land's Song stands out among other recent fest-circuit films about attempts to revive forgotten or suppressed music.
A biopic that feels more like a ride-along on an exploration of human nature.
The directorial debut of cinematographer Reed Morano, it is tightly in sync with protagonists who find it impossible to move on despite distractions that might be catalytic in other films.

The movie keeps suspense alive, as we try to guess how this all will play out -- building to a final tableau that, silently, says nearly as much about human nature as does all the talk leading up to it.
Beautiful and sensitive to character but gripping when it needs to be.
The result is a film whose exploration of responsibility and addiction will interest viewers who've never heard of Smith.
A film that flirts and flirts with explanations for its action without ever delivering.
A surprising level of gravitas marks this picture as one that isn't content with a B-movie base hit.
An out-of-left-field nerdy delight.
That's a fairly delicious scenario, but even so, the film never really catches fire

If the narrative proceeds at a relatively by-the-numbers pace, with few revelations and considerably less excitement than attended a memoir Hunter penned with Eddie Muller a decade ago, it at least has a heartwarming finale.
Energetic, laugh-stuffed and very colorful.
movie_title: Drunk Stoned Brilliant Dead: The Story of the National Lampoon (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Devotees of the group will embrace it on video and perhaps in special-event-style theatrical bookings, but those with a casual interest will tire of it quickly.
A winning film about reconciling one's self-image with reality.

Jeremy Coon and Tim Skousen get a lot of mileage out of its audacity. Their documentary is modest and sometimes clumsy, as if made with the expectation that only the geek community would ever want to watch it.
movie_title: Raiders!: The Story of the Greatest Fan Film Ever Made (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A powerful and important film about policing tactics that have crept into everyday use with little scrutiny, Peace Officer makes its case effectively enough to move even the staunchest law-and-order civilians.
Bruce McDonald's latest is a genre-freak-only affair that even at 81 minutes feels like a joke that takes much too long reaching its punch line.
While this performance gives the drama psychological weight, efforts of those on the ground to get the girl out of harm's way introduce very satisfying action elements.
The doc merits seeing it on its terms and should generate plenty of buzz in this Apple-obsessed world, but word-of-mouth may not be kind.
movie_title: Steve Jobs: Man in the Machine (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Moviegoers may expect something sexier than what they get here, but Neil LaBute's focus on just-talk between Broderick and co-star Alice Eve, funny but never uproarious, provides its own modest rewards.
Easygoing and always likeable but hardly packed with laughs.

Joining some other recent histories about black Americans fighting powers that are too rarely held accountable to them, the film continues a discussion whose present-day relevance is painfully, increasingly obvious.
movie_title: The Black Panthers: Vanguard Of The Revolution (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Funny and modestly charming.
A straightforward encomium for a leading champion of gay rights.
This crudely crafted film will be one of the least effective voices.
Likeable if not especially vibrant.
However polished the doc's tech and score, it simply doesn't find drama in this familiar template.
Buzzing attentively but not exclusively around cartoon editor Bob Mankoff, director Leah Wolchok strikes a pleasing balance between office minutiae and comic greatest hits.
Ti West's In a Valley of Violence plays like a grim, Eastwood-style genre revival before some conspicuous Tarantino-influenced humor infects its climactic showdown.
Neistat stays true to his subject's oddball sensibility, right down to the hand-lettered credits that crank slowly across the screen after the mission's end.
Expanding on the behind-the-curtain Sleepwalk With Me, which focused on the personal life of a stand-up comic, Birbiglia displays a feel for his troupe-minded brethren here.
It will delight the show's fans while winning over others unlucky enough never to have seen [Key & Peele].
The specifics of its conceit are so well suited to the winners-vs.-losers realities of our economic moment viewers may be disinclined to poke holes in its logic.
It's as honest and clear-eyed about the past as its predecessor, another in a filmography of unpredictable gems.
The banter has its high points, and some supporting players more than carry their weight. But the second half groans under too many dumb contrivances

The point of Boom Bust Boom, a friendly little pic hosted by Monty Python's Terry Jones, is that the world is little closer to acknowledging the causes of that trauma, and until we digest its lessons, something similar is bound to happen again.
By the time the film gets where it's going, viewers may identify more than they expect with those who've been controlled by others with hidden agendas.

Galland's film plays more like a cable-ready mystery than a cult film in the making, offering just enough chuckles to stay afloat... Still, it's a nice alternative to yet another self-serious Exorcist wannabe.
Stripped-down thriller benefits from its setting.
A lackluster cat-and-mouse game.
Those patches eventually get unsmoothable in a climactic sequence that more than pays off on the sometimes iffy buildup.
A highly enjoyable look at a career spent duping the art world.
For viewers who can embrace this fizzy blend of mystic-assassin worship and cutesy at-first-sight romance, though, Paco Cabezas' action rom-com will be the best thing since Grosse Pointe Blank.
More stylishly compelling and seamlessly produced than it is imaginative.
Casts a compelling retro-futuristic spell and stays true to this atmosphere to the end.

Old conventional wisdom about genius and madness resurfaces in Mania Days, a drama that identifies so closely with its two bipolar protagonists that many viewers will feel it promotes even their most flawed beliefs.
