A young widow must decide if it's time to stop grieving in Tumbledown, a sweet and gently comic tale set in small-town Maine.
What starts out as a familiar kind of portrait eventually grows a layer or two more complex, offering narrative appeal even to those who don't know their Henry Dargers from their Howard Finsters.
An important account of shifts in policing tactics and the problematic interaction between law enforcement and private companies.
movie_title: Killing Them Safely (Tom Swift And His Electric Rifle) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Though Whelan's debut filmmaking effort wears some of its homemade characteristics proudly, it wrangles more than enough credible interviewees to make its points.
[Doglegs] raises plenty of unanswered questions but refuses to force its subjects into tidy boxes.

Both actors stay sharp through some pretty degrading moments, and if Palmer and screenwriter Tess Morris are bent on serious button-pushing in the closing scenes, at least they garnish it with playfulness and wit.
A doc by Lisa Immordino Vreeland so stuffed with connections and allusions to fabled eras it's hard to imagine any modern art lover being bored.
Both accessible to those with little background on the subject and privileged enough to be of value to students of the country's history.
While He Never Died is hardly a comedy -- it's bloody and reflective, with a gloomy side that sometimes threatens to sink it -- these wry moments are central to its appeal.
A scattered but often hilarious stocking-stuffer.

Suffice to say that Jensen strings along clues and revelations that nicely balance laughs with revulsion, and that he feels for these grotesque characters far more than one would expect from an American film with a similar concept.
A melodrama benefitting from excellent performances but suffering from a too-obvious script.
A convincing and refreshingly indirect examination of handed-down emotional flaws.
A hazy portrait of an odd character whose backstory offers multiple attention-getting hooks.
A terminal-illness family drama in which the ailment happens to be zombieism, Henry Hobson's Maggie does the genre mashup thing without an ounce of tongue-in-cheek attitude.
Likable but slight.
An enjoyable but unenlightening encomium.
Despite the obvious sadness at its heart, the doc benefits from an unforced optimism.
As she flails through a few dubious choices, the character may be on the kind of self-discovery path we've seen in countless other films; but Winstead makes the outcome seem far from preordained.
True Story is involving but surprisingly calm, going for stretches without seeming to care whether what he's reporting is an exposé or a cover-up.
In the end one would rather be back at one's own computer, tending to the tedious details of digital life, than watching this clique get pinged to death.
[Jason Schwartzman] smarms his way through Bob Byington's very funny 7 Chinese Brothers as if the pic had been drawn up especially for him.
Frederic Tcheng's Dior and I is a fashion doc with both a sense of history and a feel for the energy of a work in progress.
It already seems more dated than Trading Places - not to mention less savvy about all the subjects it pretends to be addressing while it tries to make us laugh.

A pitch-perfect pastiche that never mocks its inspirations, the picture is silly fun to warm the hearts of aging fanboys and delight hipsters who weren't yet born the first time Mel Gibson donned Max's leathers.
Of interest to Police fans but hardly a rock-doc for the ages.
Stupendously stupid and stupidly diverting.
Few films are better titled than The Wannabe, a portrait of a Bronx kid who would have done anything to be part of the mob world he knew from the movies.
Melissa McCarthy comes into her own as a comic star in Spy, stepping out from recent supporting- and co-headlining roles to become the big screen A-lister she promised to be in 2011's Bridesmaids.
Likeable but ordinary.
A film that starts off as a quiet exploration of grief but soon becomes a trapped-in-your-home thriller.
California teenager Regina Nicholson leaves an affecting cinematic testament in Farewell to Hollywood, which she worked on with documentarian Henry Corra during the last two years of her life.
Despite an appealing cast, though, neither comedy nor suspense really takes flight until very near the end, largely due to a script that isn't equal to the filmmakers' enthusiasm.

A flop-sweaty cash grab that gives a bad name to sequels in which key talent has jumped ship, Steve Pink's Hot Tub Time Machine 2 leaps forward rather than backward in time and sort of makes one wish the world had ended while it was en route.
Big, broad political satire is hard to pull off in the best of cases.
Other Man reminds us how much there is to marvel at in the country's transition from minority white to black rule.
movie_title: The Other Man: F.W. de Klerk and the End of Apartheid (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Long-in-coming doc offers an intensely personal look behind the headlines.
movie_title: Matt Shepard is a Friend of Mine (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Sumptuous and romantic in an attractively old-fashioned way despite a hitch designed to give some contemporary American idealists pause... the film satisfies in a wholly commercial way.
Smart, sensitive, and accessible to both young and middle-aged viewers
Along the way Almanac is forced to cheat so much with its ostensibly self-shot material that one has to ask why the format was chosen.
An important addition to the filmography of dissent-oriented political docs.
A movie that handles race, class and militarism with a light touch, Sean Mullin's Sam & Amira is at bottom a romance whose protagonists don't quite fit in the worlds that raised them.
An irrepressible pioneer of BASE jumping contributes greatly to his own encomium in Sunshine Superman, Marah Strauch's very fine look at the legacy of Carl Boenish.
A trapped-in-a-house thriller pitting thieves against an unexpectedly resourceful victim, the lean and mean pic offers scares aplenty and at least a couple of game-changing twists.
Funny, dark, and riding a very fine line in its depiction of mental illness, it may be the best thing we could hope would emerge from the side of Wiig that gave us Gilly.
[It's] constructed exactly like a middlebrow studio comedy but lacking the directorial verve that might make it play like one.
An enjoyable entry into the swelling ranks of corrupt-the-youth comedies.
More lightweight than its ample talk of weighty subjects suggests, the film is nevertheless enjoyable and may reach Swanberg's widest audience yet.
Beni's story -- a scripted narrative inspired by real events -- proves quite engaging.
It does for the most part fulfill its mission, breathing life into the origin story of a group whose influence is still being felt.
Keith Miller's Five Star makes its nonactors look like trained thesps and (in a good way) vice versa.
A good-looking debut offering more atmosphere than action.

Chipper and fun if occasionally superficial, the doc finds its subject too large to address in a way that satisfies the most curious outsider or devoted fan. Everyone else will have a good time, though.
Though it may amuse hardcore devotees of kaiju film on video, the film hardly threatens to make Murakami the next Julian Schnabel.
Schumer has never had anything like a leading film role, but self-revealing stand-up and a TV series have limbered her up for the job.
Tender but unsentimental.
Offbeat in the ways one expects and hopes for in a Blank film.
movie_title: A Poem Is A Naked Person (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Featuring intricate, non-linear storytelling and an uncommon emotional pungency, 7 Minutes is a taut, tightly controlled exercise that should spell bigger and better things for its tyro director/screenwriter.
Often hilarious and even a tiny bit moving.

The world of In Country may sound like a joke to outsiders, and may well be a misguided hobby for some of its subjects. But the film suggests we'd make a big mistake to write it all off as foolish fantasy.
By the time Wecht declares that this is a death that simply has to be reinvestigated, even a viewer with no special attachment to Cobain's legacy is likely to agree.
Mann, shaggy and insecure and unhandsome enough to get away with it when he complains of having an animal's face, makes an excellent Everyguy here, and his funniness is unforced.
movie_title: Me and Earl and the Dying Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: As it progresses, watching Mike raise children, move off to Scotland, and grow less involved in planning satirical performance art, the film presupposes a bit more interest in the pair's friendship and personal lives than many viewers will have.
A sober look at accusations that lend themselves to sensationalism.
The theatrical performances don't come close to matching Duvall's 1997 directing breakthrough The Apostle.
Neither as frightening as a good horror flick nor as enlightening as a straight documentary.
A perfectly chosen cast sells this unhurried comedy, which flows unconventionally but is still, by a long stretch, the most mainstream-friendly picture Bujalski has made.
Like a TED talk augmented by scads of testimonials from ordinary folks who've been caught in the act, Yael Melamede's doc is more lively than one might expect.
[An] accessible and handsome film.
A wholly enjoyable buddy Western punctuated by occasional shocks of black humor.
Digging around in the crannies of his highly unusual home but never becoming intrusive, the doc feels like it was made by a friend, in a good way.
Bradley King's Time Lapse turns run-of-the-mill roommate friction into a heated mystery with the aid of a machine that takes snapshots of the near future.
This polished, comprehensive-feeling film makes clear how much of the work was done by our neighbors to the north.
Lovely at times but something of a bore as a whole, the film's wisdom is too adult for kids and its story too simple for grown-ups.

Scratching the surface of a story one suspects is a good deal thornier than what's explicitly shown here, Crystal Moselle's The Wolfpack introduces a gang of siblings who have been raised in near-complete isolation in downtown Manhattan.

The laughs barely let up after that first scene, in fact, in a film that proves to be not just more than a boundary-stretching exercise but one of the funniest arguments for the non-existence of God in some time.
A thoroughly entertaining doc that serves also as a primer on Brand's shockingly successful comedy career and an introduction to his singular personality.

Master Cleanse isn't the easiest film to open up to. But Miller knows exactly how the third act should play, and he manages (thanks in part to the increasingly intriguing creature work) to reach an emotionally satisfying conclusion.
An enjoyable throwback to a vintage mode of urban ensemble comedy.
The movie... can hardly hope to create the sensation of its Oscar-winning predecessor. But it finds plenty to add, both in cementing the urgency of Gore's message and in finding cause for hope.
movie_title: An Inconvenient Sequel: Truth To Power (2017)

movie_review_blurb: One suspects most viewers will respond with a shrug, if they sit through it at all.
Viewers expecting a garden-variety horror flick will likely recoil, but those seeking new voices in Mexican cinema may well hail Minter's effort.
movie_title: We Are the Flesh (Tenemos la carne) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: More true to its title than viewers may expect, the doc cares more about underlying principles than the details of any one controversy.
Day's debut succeeds in part thanks to its modest scope, viewing the street-art phenomenon through an attempt to rescue one of its highly perishable creations for the public good ...

Several respectable actors offer dicey performances here, but Rappaport's screenplay is the real villain, expecting thin references to real-world financial peril to paper over gaping holes in credibility and plain-old drama.
A quiet breakthrough for star Betsy Brandt, best known for playing Walter White's sister-in-law on Breaking Bad.
This debut feature plays like a glum after-school special whose jealousies and painful secrets project little heat.
A promising if not quite audacious debut by Robin Pront, the film benefits from a solidly envisioned family dynamic but doesn't really generate much heat until its final act.
Only a middling example of its genre ...

Though seemingly sympathetic to those crossing into this country, it displays little understanding of them as human beings, and its moral point is as muddy as the Rio Grande-cum-River Styx its hero crosses daily.
Goodnight Brooklyn: The Story of Death by Audio emphasizes the family-like bonds and sense of belonging generated by the best DIY venues.
movie_title: Goodnight Brooklyn: The Story of Death by Audio (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A handsome period piece that plays more like a scant-clues mystery than like the psychological thriller it intends to be.
While Bousman's climax is a not terribly original effects-laden haunted house, the house's builder, and his motives, have enough of their own flavor to please a hardened horror fan.
A very hard-to-believe premise sinks an overserious drama.
A sincere, half-cute love story weighted down by narrative contrivances.
Bobby Sands: 66 Days offers something both for those who've never heard of Sands and those who have his youthful smile etched forever in memory.
Videophilia casts a singular spell.
movie_title: Videofilia (and Other Viral Syndromes) (Videofilia: y otros síndromes virales) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Fans of Mr. Robot won't be disappointed in the least by this vehicle for Emmy-winning series star Rami Malek, which both fits in with Mr. Robot's delusion-prone paranoia and lets the charismatic actor stretch out in his first feature lead.
With any luck, Hollywood will take note and someday present an Erin Brockovich-like adaptation of this tale, drawing more casual moviegoers into this ire-stoking story ...
A deeply sensitive interpretation of the subject's reflective testament on disability.
An eye-opening and ire-raising doc that follows pesticides around the world to see the damage they do.
Emotionally engrossing if not 100% persuasive in its last act, it balances techno-alienation and warmth in ways that will resonate with art-house audiences.

Likely to draw in just about everyone who followed the Potter series and to please most of them, the picture also has things to offer for fantasy-friendly moviegoers who only casually observed that phenomenon.
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Production elements are as solid as the film's acting.

Though no apologist for the Al Qaeda faction that kidnapped him in Syria in 2012, Padnos's rueful and sympathetic storytelling exhibits the kind of cultural understanding that drew him to the region in the first place.
A funny and tender drawn-from-life love story.
A winning ensemble brings present-day attitude to Boccaccio's irreverent sex comedy.
There's too much moral ambiguity here for one doc to make sense of it all, but Trophy certainly offers much to think about.
Gook rises above message-movie mediocrity, enjoying its characters too much to use them as political mouthpieces.
This modest but enjoyable doc could be an eye-opener for viewers who are befuddled by current debates over sexual expression ...
An uncertain drama full of attitude it can't back up with action.
Represents a missed opportunity, given the talents of this charismatic and game cast.
Even for viewers who know much more about Burden than that thing with the rifle, it's almost certain to trigger a hunger for more.

None of these topics have escaped the notice of journalists covering the climate-change beat in recent years. But Scott packages these concerns and others in a smart way, and includes the occasional bit of eye-opening history.
A likeable enough group, in which the expected contenders (why hello there, Pixar) sit alongside unknowns whose styles are just varied enough to avoid monotony.
A varied and satisfying lineup with an emphasis on culture clashes.
A concluding installment is already en route; expect diminishing returns every Valentine's Day.

Amateurish on many levels and at some point seeming to have been made up on the spot (which would be quite a feat for animation) ... a strong contender for the year's worst film, and not in a fun way.

The writing/directing debut of Minhal Baig enlists experienced actors but has little idea what to do with them, making a hash of its intended meditation on the compromises required by long-term relationships.
In piecing these elements into a narrative, Dorff and co-screenwriter Ross forgot that satisfying stories tend to place some disappointment and conflict between their heroes and success.
Josh Wiggins makes an excellent and restrained stand-in for moviegoers who, more than likely, will have no idea what they'd do in his shoes.
A crowd-friendly immigrant's tale painted with a thick coat of '70s nostalgia.

Sealey's direction and dialogue aim for the believable strangeness of real human relationships instead of the schematics of melodrama. With the exception of a brief moment or two, the film definitely hits the mark.
Unlikely to fire up the faithful and almost sure not to attract new fans to this J-horror-derived property.
Unsatisfying in the pulpy sense suggested by its Midnight-section booking at Sundance, the pic's presumed political agenda never crystallizes sufficiently ...
A deeply unpromising debut horror flick by visual-effects veteran Robert Legato.
[An] easygoing, slice-of-life film ...
A charming, surprisingly underplayed paean to pop-culture obsession.

As a sympathetic look at two likeable lovers who don't know what's good for them, it's enough to give us a rooting interest - even if we're rooting for the two protagonists to accept the consequences of their mistakes and move on.
This will not enjoy the critical support given to George's Hotel Rwanda; compared to that flawed but affecting picture, this one looks like it was stamped by a cookie cutter.
A good-looking mystery whose sci-fi elements take a back seat to meditations on guilt and deception.
Does nothing to fill the need for thoughtful, probing docs about the threats facing our democracy.
movie_title: Trumped: Inside the Greatest Political Upset of All Time (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Strong ... draws connections between life and art in ways many others have, but finds it hard to conjure his subject's passion for writing.
Ruskin continually requires wounded earnestness from his lead, and shows little of whatever spark of inner life must have been required for Warner to survive these years without losing his mind.

One of the most satisfying thrillers in several years, Get Out proves that its first-time director, Key and Peele costar Jordan Peele, has plenty of career options if he should grow tired of doing comedy in front of the camera.
Using her own experience with the syndrome as a springboard, Brea offers an affecting film that, when made available on video, will be embraced by the millions suffering CFS worldwide.
Inspires some sympathy for its protagonist but not enough to carry the film.

Kung-Fu Yoga scratches fans' itch for no-nonsense, no-pretense Chan fare - in which he isn't second-banana to a Western star, or married to a director who thinks VFX are required to make Chan's stunts more impressive.
While we fret over a situation offering no easy solutions, Irving alternates between colorful anecdotes from McCollum's illicit career and examples of the way the courts have failed him.
Even those with no interest in the wrestling star's sex life will find it eye-opening.
movie_title: Nobody Speak: Trials of the Free Press (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Lynskey gives a winning performance here as a New Agey peacemaker straining to be tolerant of Shonzi's quirks and perhaps too optimistic about the prospects of making him more sensitive.
Even 'Cat Fancy' subscribers will hate it.
It is a joy-filled reminder of the high points of a career we hope is just hitting its stride.
There's no way for all this to resolve that isn't fairly absurd. But Morelli's light touch generally keeps the goofiness from becoming tiresome.
Having followed [Gleason] from the start, we can't help but see the active mind inside that body, one full of love for his family and determination to stay with them as long as he can.

If something is lost in the transition from live spectacle to film - in person, there was pleasure in figuring out which performer's thoughts we were hearing at any given moment; here, the camera tells us - an intimacy is gained in compensation.
Minimalist in terms of action and scope but attentive to the texture of what is onscreen.
If the pic's creepy-crawly photography and colorful subjects weren't enough -- and they are -- a sharp score by Pierre Takal keeps us slightly agitated without ever becoming intrusive.

Setting out to show the range of expression found in a field of craft it feels is too often dismissed as a trivial women's pastime, Una Lorenzen's Yarn showcases four artists doing things with crochet your spinster great-aunt probably never imagined.
Neither the movie nor its heroine ever confuse understanding his past with excusing what he became.
A first-rate music film capturing a restless desire to communicate beyond the boundaries of any single idiom.
movie_title: The Music of Strangers: Yo-Yo Ma and the Silk Road Ensemble (2016)

If Tobey did in real life what he does in 'Need for Speed,' most Americans would desire to drag him out of his car and open up a serious can of road rage.
Hardly a Spellbound-ing narrative, 'Bad Words' does have its charms. There are some intelligent observations, as well as a soupcon of funny fecal, flatulent and fornication jokes.
'The Railway Man' deals with some of the uglier aspects of war, namely how torture can be justified by the upper echelons of government through twisted language...
This isn't a conventional documentary, but it's a damn adventurous film.
In the end, It Could Happen to You is a lot like the cop and the waitress: sweet, naive, not too smart, but likable.
On the whole Once Around is strangely enervating, proof that family problems -- even those of fictional families -- are often best kept behind closed doors.
Softley is able to enliven a familiar story and famous characters. His cast helps him.
Writer/director Mark Herman does a nice job of setting up the misadventure and then sitting back and letting it play itself out.
Despite these cliches, director and co-screenwriter Rick Stevenson has created some original moments.
So, how does movie differ from TV show? The answer is, thankfully, not a lot.
We may not need as many Austin Powers movies as there are James Bond pictures, but one or two more might be nice.
movie_title: Austin Powers: International Man of Mystery (1997)

movie_review_blurb: Disney has created a movie that, like Quasimodo himself, is half formed.
The opening and closing credits alone are almost worth the price of admission.
movie_title: The Naked Gun 2 1/2: The Smell of Fear (1991)

movie_review_blurb: It spends too much time as a small war movie instead of a big-question movie.

Ford is fine as the innocent surgeon who is wrongfully convicted of the murder of his wife and sets off to find the real killer. But the movie is stolen from under his nose by Tommy Lee Jones, who gives an Oscar-winning performance.
It's a delight from start to finish that will captivate children and melt the heart of even the grumpiest adult.
Macchio rises above the trite script to deliver a sympathetic and believable performance. Morita is equally good value and look out, too, for Elisabeth Shue in an early role.

Spielberg is less assured in the department of character development and some of the actors give worse performances than the computer-generated creatures, but, with a landmark spectacle like this, who cares?
As usual, the action is on an epic scale and delivered with breathless enthusiasm and much panache by director Steven Spielberg.
movie_title: Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade (1989)

movie_review_blurb: This feel-good family ensemble piece from director Ron Howard manages to avoid being oversentimental, and the result is an affectionate, leisurely comedy about the joys (and otherwise) of bringing up children.
[A] delightful, gentle satire on the Washington political scene.
There's hardly a second that passes without an assault by a wickedly accurate spoof, cringe-inducing pun or inspired sight gag, and the years have not diminished the film's dumb appeal.
It was always going to be hard to better Don Siegel's 1956 classic, and if director Philip Kaufman doesn't quite succeed, he does manage to summon up an equally chilling air of paranoia.
The torture-porn genre gets a Day-Glo makeover in this hilariously deranged Ocker shocker.
An old hand at this kind of heart-warming fare, Benton doesn't swamp it with sentimentality, allowing the crumpled charisma of Newman to effortlessly carry the drama.
The animation is lovingly rendered and there's a pedigree cast (Dom DeLuise, Derek Jacobi, John Carradine) providing voices.
It doesn't take itself too seriously and benefits from a good cast that includes Ralph Richardson and John Hallam. The effects aren't bad either.
Even though fans of the 1960s TV show may reject its brooding atmosphere, this is still impressive stuff.
This charming romantic comedy touched a chord with audiences around the world and propelled its stars Tom Hanks and Daryl Hannah, along with director Ron Howard, to Hollywood's front rank.

The sting itself is as audacious as it is elaborate, but the real pleasure comes from the chemistry between the two leads, the lovingly created 1930s settings and Marvin Hamlisch's inspired reworking of Scott Joplin's music.
Vaguely interesting for causing controversy at the time, this tacky tale of illicit teenage romance hasn't aged particularly well.
[An] agreeably eccentric comedy crime drama.
This appealing children's adventure has just enough quirky touches to keep adults involved as well.
Writer/director Ron Shelton is that rare beast: someone who can make movies with wit, warmth and perception about American sports.
This stylish, poignant drama is probably the closest director David Lynch has got to the mainstream outside of the disastrous Dune.
The real star, however, is John Toll's Oscar-winning cinematography, which is equally at home with the stunning beauty of the mountainous terrain and the killing fields of war-torn France.
Cannon co-executive produced so he has to accept some of the blame for the lack of laughs and thrills, leaving Hugh Bonneville to ham it up for all he's worth as the school's snobbish headmaster.
The story is a touch simplistic, but Petersen's direction is assured and children will be dazzled by the imaginative effects and stunning sets.
The blockbuster action thriller genre is ripe for sending up, but this lazy effort has to go down as a miss despite the presence of spoofmeister Leslie Nielsen.
Reeves and Winter are once again cheerfully inept, and British director Peter Hewitt stages the spectacular set pieces with some panache. Mostly excellent.

Kickboxer 2 explores much the same territory as its predecessor, although this time there's no Jean-Claude Van Damme, who by the time this sequel was made had moved on to bigger (though not necessarily better) things.
Broderick is remarkably likeable as the arrogant, spoilt brat, Ruck is excellent as his melancholy friend and Jones almost steals the show.
Sequels are usually a case of diminishing returns, but this third installment of the Star Wars saga is still essential viewing.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VI - Return of the Jedi (1983)

movie_review_blurb: The humour is largely knockabout stuff, but director Michael Ritchie slips in some sly satiric jabs at the commercialisation of American sport.
Although it helps to be a car nut to watch this, Bana's unpretentious passion is infectious.
This irresistible combination of dazzling effects and sly comedy propelled Michael J Fox to stardom and Robert Zemeckis to the front rank of Hollywood directors.
As with Paris, Je T'Aime (it's from the same producer, Emmanuel Benbihy), the sheer diversity of this portmanteau movie is both a curse and a blessing.
This tale of two outsiders is lovingly rendered in traditional claymation and Elliot's expressive creations are wonderfully brought to life by the talented voice cast...
Although directors Gustave Kervern and Benoît Delépine strive a little too hard at times for outrage, it's still wickedly funny, and Moreau and Lanners are terrific as the grotesque anti-heroes.
[Beattie] knows his way around a thrilling action set piece, but he also draws believable performances from his young and largely unknown cast.
Kwanten makes for a likeable hero, although Steve Bisley steals the show as the hard-bitten police chief Old Bill.
The bustling helter-skelter of Scorsese's Mean Streets gives way to a measured, chilly calm, and cinematographer Michael Chapman ensures the Big Apple glistens with barely concealed menace.

Howard Deutch is a proficient enough second division director, but here he allows sentimentality to run riot, and the awkwardly ageing Culkin (approaching adolescence) no longer possesses the mischievous charm of old.
Although a tad too long for its own good, there's enough intrigue - both political and romantic - and dashing swordplay to keep everyone happy.
movie_title: La princesse de Montpensier (The Princess of Montpensier) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Director Gilles Paquet-Brenner subtly contrasts Scott Thomas's modern-day investigation with the tragic wartime experiences of Mayance's title character, to show how one innocent mistake can resonate across time.
The superb acting - the youngsters are particularly good - and Bier's sympathetic direction help overcome the occasional lapse into melodrama.
The often dazzling, special effects-driven slapstick tends to overshadow the fact that there are some slyer, more sophisticated laughs on offer in this blockbusting family comedy.
Even hardened blokes will struggle not to choke back a few tears at the end.
A largely unfunny blend of frantic farce and gross-out humour.
Phoebe Cates's admirably straight-faced Christmas speech should be compulsory viewing during the festive season.

This multi-Oscar-winning classic, adapted from Thomas Harris's bestseller, was responsible for giving cinematic serial killers a better image, thanks to Anthony Hopkins's enthralling portrayal of Hannibal Lecter.
This is American mainstream movie-making at its best.
Although it's probably the biggest movie yet to emerge from rapper 50 Cent's production outfit, this damp squib still has "straight to DVD" stamped all over it.
An unexpected delight for all the family.

Joe Eszterhas shamelessly reworks ideas and themes he had earlier exploited in films such as Jagged Edge and Music Box, but the sheer overheated nature of Verhoeven's direction makes this extremely watchable.
[It] was not the cinema event it promised to be. Yet there is still much to treasure in this exuberant tribute to the Moulin Rouge.
The ultimate rebel Jack Nicholson has a ball playing the ultimate establishment figure in this star-laden, rather old-fashioned courtroom drama.
This delightful follow-up to The Addams Family is blessed with an even blacker vein of humour than the original.
Cosby mugs away for all he's worth, but good gags are few and far between.
Bruce Willis wonders aloud how it could happen to him again, but dons the white singlet anyway for this second hugely entertaining slice of action hokum.

Lee's direction is wonderfully fluid and, as in most of his movies, he is superbly served by the striking cinematography of Ernest Dickerson and strong lead performances. However, there is a glibness to his script.
Miller doesn't take his foot off the accelerator for a second, and the ingeniously designed and staged road action is stunning.
The third in Mel Gibson's sci-fi series is the weakest, but it remains a hugely entertaining futuristic spectacular.
It's ironic that this sequel to the blockbuster that initiated the disaster movie cycle should effectively finish off the genre and the career of its king, Irwin Allen.
Despite the presence of comic veterans such as John Astin, juvenile slapstick is the order of the day and Bateman shows little early sign of his now-proven comic timing.
Although original stars Eddie Murphy and Nick Nolte are reunited with director Walter Hill, all three seem to be going through the motions here.
The effects are even better than in the first film, and the actors certainly enjoy themselves in a baffling array of roles.
movie_title: Back to the Future Part II (1989)

movie_review_blurb: It's imaginatively shot and features some nifty special effects.
This bid by the National Lampoon team to cash in with some Naked Gun-style spoofery lacks the brainless invention of the latter films, but still manages to score quite a few laughs.
This comedy is unusually dark for a Disney production and it makes for patchy entertainment.
Kiwi star Cliff Curtis makes a triumphant return to his homeland with this multi-award-winning true story after Whale Rider propelled him to a career in Hollywood in 2002.
There is a theory that every Hollywood star has a turkey or two in their closet, so today, step forward Anthony Edwards, star of the hit TV series ER.
Cassel's subtle and quietly menacing performance helps compensate for a story that drifts along rather aimlessly at times, while Kleiman's dreamy visuals mark him out as a talent to watch.
The less said about the lead performances the better, although Morris Day eclipses the star with a charismatic turn, but Prince and the Revolution were at the height of their powers.
As a film director, Prince remains a brilliant musician.
While director Darren Ashton doesn't bring anything particularly new to the genre, his direction is suitably deadpan and he is rewarded with superb performances from his leads.
movie_title: Razzle Dazzle: A Journey Into Dance (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Albert Pyun is a competent director of sci-fi and martial arts action movies, but this tough, brooding comic-book fantasy suffers in comparison to other big-budget superhero adventures, and Salinger lacks charisma as the hero.
Waters tones down his usual excesses, but his mischievous black sense of humour is still very much to the fore in this affectionate salute to Z-grade teen movies.
This rip-roaring slice of sci-fi excess remains Arnold Schwarzenegger's most satisfying film since his breakthrough hit, The Terminator.
At times it is both overly sentimental and unintentionally funny.
Amiable but predictable.
The fight sequences are staged with such élan that it is easy to ignore the hackneyed script - Van Damme had a hand in that as well - and rather wooden performances.
This is the one where the big rubber shark gets to attack an aircraft, but that's far from being the only silly thing about this preposterous fourth entry in the series.
This 12th entry in the 007 series provides no real surprises, with the exception perhaps of Roger Moore, who gets the chance to show a little more grit than usual.
A muddled mish-mash.

While director Kim Farrant superbly captures the haunting, parched beauty of the Aussie interior in her debut feature, she stumbles when it comes to the emotional landscape, with the movie flickering uncertainly in tone.
While there is plenty of rude banter and are a few good laughs, Mark Hammer's script is neither witty nor insightful enough to carry the load.
This all-singing, all-belching western spoof remains one of Mel Brooks's finest creations.
It's a beguiling, eccentric blend of romantic drama and political thriller, and at its centre is a charismatic performance from Stephen Rea.
Director Ralph Bakshi looked set to produce an adult version of Who Framed Roger Rabbit with this mix of animation and live action, but somewhere down the line it ran out of steam.
Tthe enthusiastic hamming can't hide the clunking direction by Sidney J Furie and the sub-standard special effects.
movie_title: Superman IV: The Quest for Peace (1987)

movie_review_blurb: The determinedly juvenile gags never stop flowing.
movie_title: The Naked Gun: From the Files of Police Squad! (1988)

movie_review_blurb: Neither as cartoonish as Con Air, nor as sentimental as Armageddon, this most satisfying of blockbuster movies deserves further kudos for establishing Nicolas Cage as one of Hollywood's unlikeliest action heroes.
This gentle, warm-hearted comedy drama about a group of young men in 1950s Baltimore was director Barry Levinson's debut feature and it remains among his finest work.
The result is great, brainless fun.
Schumacher piles on the action, but this is still the least satisfying entry in the series.

On paper, this genre flick looks like an attempt to do for Kevin Costner what Taken did for Liam Neeson. Unfortunately, it doesn't have Taken's pace and energy, despite the writing presence of Luc Besson in both movies.
Director Lewis Teague lets off the requisite number of explosions, but the script is riddled with clichés and Sheen is hardly a charismatic lead.
It's amiably played, but Alan Cohn's direction lacks bite.
An intriguing, if not completely successful, spin on the rock movie.
Ultimately this is a kids-only affair.
The talented supporting cast gives a pleasing sheen to the material, while John McTiernan's no-frills direction ensures that the tension rarely slips below pressure-cooker level.
Farley is as energetically crude as ever, but both Perry and director Christopher Guest, who was behind the classic This Is Spinal Tap, seem uncomfortable with the material.
Once experienced here, listening to Roy Orbison's In Dreams will never be the same again.

McNaughton's rough, non-judgemental direction gives the film a stylishly chilling documentary feel, while the killer's use of a camcorder asks some challengingly uncomfortable questions about voyeurism and the nature of screen violence.
movie_title: Henry: Portrait of a Serial Killer (1986)

movie_review_blurb: Seagal the director shows that he has picked up the odd trick or two from the action specialists who made his name, but his impassioned green speeches will have viewers reaching for the remote control.

Writer/director Stuart Gillard tries to inject some life into the project by including some tongue-in-cheek scenes in 17th-century Japan, but it quickly degenerates into half-hearted cartoonish action.
There's only slightly more plot than appeared in the original computer game, and the result is undemanding fun.
Even Anjelica Huston as a rival cosmetics magnate struggles to inject any venom into the proceedings.
Even Williams's quick-fire routines fail to raise many laughs.
The performances of both adults and youngsters are uniformly strong and, despite the occasional invasion of sentimentality, this makes for thoughtful entertainment.
Not quite a career low for John Travolta -- Two of a Kind was still to come -- but one he nevertheless would probably love to forget.

Perhaps we can view this in 30 years as a lightweight text mirroring some of Occupy Wall Street, and perhaps the rise of Elizabeth Warren, although I'm quite sure it will be forgotten about well before then.
While the subject matter remains intriguing, The Yes Men deserve a better and more intimate documentary than they have made about themselves.
Somewhat lucid at times with flourishes of comedy, as enjoyable as individual moments are, it unfolds rather predictably.
A credible, engaging and beautiful moral drama that is unusually smart for a Hollywood studio picture.
Feeling a bit more like sketch comedy than cinema, The Little Death is not without laughs, but the tone is all over the map.
Part Todd Solondz, John Waters, Nicole Holofcener, and Bridesmaids, the bitter and cynical Preggoland is a unique comedy.
The quintessential midnight experience, Kevin Smith's next outing as he transitions from slacker comedy to dark horror is, like most of his films, for the fans.
While mostly delightful, yet not terribly insightful, Cantinflas is a warm and nostalgic look at the business of show.
The reassuring note that comes at the end of the journey isn't quite its thesis and, like the film, offers up no easy answers in spite of its search.
movie_title: The Expedition to the End of the World (2014)

movie_review_blurb: While it's not a dull time, working within a fictional construct it lacks the depth to really make this come alive.
A Space Program offers a vision of what The Martian might look like as directed by the heroes of Michel Gondry's Be Kind Rewind.
Riveting entertainment, Dinosaur 13 is one of those happy accidents of documentary filmmaking.
Haemoo is an effective moral thriller that immediately mirrors the best work of its co-writer and producer Bong Joon-ho.
Step Up: All In has a few dazzling sequences, including the final dance-off, that are effective as minor spectacle, but there's never reason to care.
A confidently directed version of an underdog story that we've seen before.
Pleasant enough, if not paper-thin and featherweight, The Perfect Match is a bland picture starring attractive people that never quite seems to connect the dots.
Watchable scene-to-scene as an old-fashioned character study.

Reducing the production of this work to political artifacts of each piece of art as a means of gaining a deeper self-understanding is a smart approach to exploring a contemporary subject we know little about.
An incompetent comedy that must have either gone horribly wrong or simply started with a low bar.
Often hilarious, poignant and fascinating, The Dog is as entertaining as movies (in any genre or form) get, telling a true story that is far stranger anything a screenwriter could cook up.
An effective, family-friendly film with a message that provides a valuable introduction to the issues surrounding immigration reform for the next generation of voters.
Complex, rich and often very funny, the feature is also a love letter to film, and, at the same time, a complete cop-out.
Taken 3 isn't a bad time; it's often laughable without veering totally into self-parody.
With a kind of quiet reserve, Big Eyes is a rare effort from the Tim Burton that plays it straight.
A bold exploration of religion wrapped in a sci-fi drama with several moments of broad comedy thrown in to lighten the mood -- after all, it is Bollywood.
Observant, quiet and authentic.
Needy and broad, Take Care is an exhausting experience for all the wrong reasons.
Functioning as light satire, Dr. Cabbie never quite digs deep enough.
Nothing more than a slick-looking TV ad, where its placement behind the "pay wall" of your local AMC, Regal or Cinemark seems rather silly.
Brief, informative and direct, the historical details post-Illmatic grow less interesting, yet the film's first half is electric and engaging.
Directed with tremendous energy for much of its first half, as Cannon starts to wear out is welcome, so does this documentary.
movie_title: Electric Boogaloo: The Wild, Untold Story of Cannon Films (2012)

movie_review_blurb: A character study above all, Bronx Obama is entertaining and straightforward while playing it safe, the sort of thing Ortiz, Cote and Watters are expected to do on stage.
While certain gags bomb, the ones that succeed do so with big laughs and all kinds of bodily fluids.
The Frontier is one of those films we watch on the edge of our seat. Sometimes it edges towards something rather complex which requires an elegant and original resolution.
Here's a film that's so predictable as the scares and reveals come right on time that it almost feels like a parody of the genre, right down to our "villain" screaming out the title of the film.
A comedy that plays like a cross between Henry Jaglom, Kevin Smith and the Duplass brothers with droll rambling humor and emotional honesty.
If I didn't chuckle once or twice, I'd be filing a complaint against Sony with the Better Business Bureau for marketing Sex Tape as a comedy.
The Ticket is the equivalent of wandering around a house stripped to its support beams: every painstakingly obvious detail of its construction can be seen from virtually any vantage point.
As adorkable as it is, Adult Life Skills, like its lead Anna, never quite takes off.
Frothy and brief, with a few big laughs.
Lavender is often an effective and haunting atmospheric thriller that doesn't compound its twists with ADD-style turns that mimic a Billy Mays' sale pitch ("but wait, there's more!").
There's nothing worse than a film that's laughing at itself while the auditorium is silent, and while Mortdecai inspires a few chuckles, it never fully delivers.
Ma Ma is a well-crafted and acted film that somewhat falls short of the emotional gravity it should have.
A piercingly original and very funny debut feature, the picture takes no prisoners as it constantly changes shapes and form.
An authentic portrait with only a few false notes, Slash ought to be essential viewing for every awkward 15-year-old kid trying to figure themselves out.
Derivative of much better mob and boxing movies, it's not bad, but one can argue the former might be worse.
Engaging and challenging in moments, it stumbles to the challenge.
movie_title: Gore Vidal: The United States Of Amnesia (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The problem is we've seen this all before and then some; to call this trite would be an understatement.
Smart, insightful and full of lively, authentic New York City atmosphere that could never be faked on a sound stage in Atlanta, Chinese Puzzle is the real deal.
While Cyber-Seniors is less than cinematic, like the web videos the seniors produce later in the film, it's often entertaining, inspirational and instructive.
Moms' Night Out seems, despite the technology, curiously dated and a leap backwards for moms.
Well-told and engaging, 1971 effectively build a portrait of the times and what follows without leaning too heavily on the recreations.
Check It is a fascinating and comprehensive ethnographic portrait of inner-city youth that may inspire conversation and action without offering easy answers or artificial sentiments.
Keep Quiet is a chilling and comprehensive documentary following the path to redemption - or a calculated political act.
Mixing talking heads and on-the-ground footage, National Bird is a vital film about the true cost of war, well-reported by Kennebeck.
An almost biting commentary on Hollywood that would appear to be more at home on the small screen.
There's plenty of white people problems, lots of anxiety, and a few stereotypes, but My America mostly plays it safe.
Some elements work, others we have seen a thousand times before.
Imperfect, yet energetic and complete with big laughs and heart, if you're nostalgic for the American Pie flicks, Premature will do the trick.
A timely New York story for any orientation, Love is Strange is Ira Sachs' most accessible film, until its frustrating ending.
This one, like its characters, takes too few risks.
An essential documentary given the dominance of headlines chronicling a new heroin epidemic, Laura Naylor's The Fix is a simple and powerful recovery narrative.
Calm, cool and collected, [it's] a black and white German indie thats as much French New Wave as it is early Richard Linklater.
Iglesias is a likable guy, but as far as concert experiences go, this one does little to break away from the pack.
Lullaby is the kind of film that's best described as a having been cobbled together from an indie scrapyard.
Elizabeth Wood has made a film that feels fresh even if it offers little introspection and commentary on the fire that it plays with.
Far too disjointed for its own good, All This Panic is a clumsy tapestry hindered by what appears to be the randomness of its production.
The film simultaneously offers us too much information while lacking real heart.
Throw Boogie Nights, Shooting Porn, Downloading Nancy, and Party Monster in a blender, add some cocaine, a scope of whey protein and squirt of lube and you've got the unexpectedly fun King Cobra.
Unfortunately, the interest of immediacy of the conversation seems to trump thorough journalism.
A powerfully subversive picture, My Scientology Movie pushes back against the church's attempt to control the narrative.
Women Who Kill is a smart comedy about the fear of finding oneself vulnerable.
A documentary reminiscent of The Big Short on a smaller and less-successful scale.
Aloft keeps us at a distance -- a problem for a film about spirituality that gives little critique or insight into the mythical healing process it is about.
Masterfully crafted, personal and engaging, many of these stories strike a deep emotional cord as each passenger is on a journey of their own
movie_title: Transit Authority: A Tribute To Chicago (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A kind of counter-narrative, free from partisan political commentary, Amira & Sam takes the smart high ground
Sembene! finds its own rhythm: part-retrospective, part-academic study in the spirit of the director's work.
Attempting a complex tone combining melodrama and quirk, it's moderately successful on a few fronts.
The film delivers the kind of entertainment fit for a certain maturity level; your inner seventeen-year-old may enjoy this more than you'd care to admit, and against your better judgement.
movie_title: Scouts Guide to the Zombie Apocalypse (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Rock the Kasbah is a piece of head-scratching bad, ugly business.
A playful look at the man behind the costumes worn by Marilyn Monroe, Betty Davis, Humphrey Bogart, Rosalind Russell, and Errol Flynn, amongst other legends.
Thank You For Bombing is uncompromising as it hits targets both easy and abstract.
Bateman has crafted an effective portrait of a dysfunctional family that's not entirely unlike the Bluth Family.
A strong, quiet and confident debut feature.
Born To Dance offers the same old story with a slight cultural twist. If only it was actually more than what it appears to be on the surface.
Big Significant Things is a minor triumph even if the measure of the things as either big or significant is relative.
Colorful and beautifully shot, Mala Mala is occasionally as tender and provocative as some of Pedro Almodóvar's best work.
Warm, personal, and direct in its approach.
A brave, personal, introspective exploration of a phenomenon that has no easy solution.
Welcome to Leith delivers a psychological horror film, one more compelling and politically relevant than your average fiction offering in the genre.
A rich and complex tapestry chronicling Simone from her early years struggling to break in.
Sanitized for Hollywood, a harrowing, real-life story does not always make a good film.
With strong performances and unique insight that above all feels emotionally and artistically honest, [this] is a bittersweet triumph with a lot of pain along the way.
It may take more risks than your standard Hallmark Channel Christmas movie, but for a holiday film, there's such little faith placed in our characters to live and breath.
It doesn't quite take itself or its audience all that seriously to try something new.
Open and honest, much like Richards, All About Ann may not quite deliver one-hundred percent on its title, but it's certainly an engaging biography.
movie_title: All About Ann: Governor Richards of the Lone Star State (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Absurdity turns quickly to boredom.
Nuts! gleefully lives up to its title.
Author: The JT LeRoy Story is wildly entertaining and truly stranger than fiction, even perhaps the fiction Albert wrote as LeRoy.
Despite being energetic even if it wears out its welcome and fascinating even as it frustrates, it never quite commits to a tone in true punk rock spirit.
Life, Animated, like Owen, is optimistic and should provide a measure of comfort for the many families affected by a complex disorder.
Sky Ladder  offers some dazzling imagery and fascinating art as it challenges geopolitical and social bounds for a critique of our history and our future.
movie_title: Sky Ladder: The Art of Cai Guo-Qiang (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Fearless, explicit and over the top, [the film] doesn't short change us in the "WTF" department, occasionally delivering tenderness in its father-son conflict.
Tender and haunting, So Yong Kim's Lovesong is a carefully observed, nuanced character study beautifully written, directed and edited.
Yoga Hosers isn't a bad time at the movies, but it's painful when the gags fall flat.
Surreal and dark in passages, even Moller's direction doesn't quite know what to do when it gets to certain pivotal moments.
As humble and folksy as Linklater, chronicling his work as programmer, collaborator, and filmmaker.
Film Hawk is strongest when living in the past, exploring Bob's early interest in underground cinema as it evolved into "independent" film and eventually a business.
An exploration of movement, motion, liminality, childhood and racial politics, The Fits is a fascinating psychological study.
In the cinematic wasteland of January, Dirty Grandpa is a minor bright spot: perverse and subversive, if not somewhat predictable.
Secret In Their Eyes is lacking a certain instinctive energy and heart that ought to pull the piece together.
Playing like an explosion at the Cannon Films factory, [it's] part Mad Max, part Nintendo movie classic, and part The Wizard with a sinister midnight madness sense of humor.
Becoming Mike Nichols may very well become a required text in an introduction to narrative filmmaking course.
Even at 82 minutes, the film overstays its welcome.
movie_title: Thought Crimes: The Case of the Cannibal Cop (2015)

movie_review_blurb: 1915 suffers from simplifying the complex and opaque.
Under The Shadow is an inspired psychological thriller from Iranian filmmaker Babak Anvari that effectively delivers the thrills expected, and more.
A minor entry into the canon of Harvey Weinstein auteur theory, a film that has particularly strong moments undercut by uneven character development as the story loses focus.
The film is a harrowing one, yet incomplete and one-sided, as is the nature of any film in which a secretive organization seeks to control the narrative.
movie_title: Going Clear: Scientology and the Prison of Belief (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Like a young kid channeling all of the rage that comes from growing up in poverty without a mentor, Champs suffers from throwing a bunch of stuff at the wall.
It's a form of comfort food that delights even if it lacks surprises.
movie_title: The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel (2015)

movie_review_blurb: While not without big laughs, Unfinished Business never quite connects; it's just shy of the finish line, despite some very funny surprises along the way.
A vanity project that is, above all, a mixed bag.
A useful picture that should be required viewing at freshman orientation.
I admire some of Old Fashioned, but it's one that should have been a tad more accessible.
Boy Meets Girl feels fresh and direct even if it's full of explanations that should have happened years earlier.
Delightful and funny in a cheesy, silly way, [the film] is a kind of cinematic sugar rush.
movie_title: The SpongeBob Movie: Sponge Out of Water (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Dense and lacking the playful quality of his more straightforward work, this represents a new multi-narrative direction for Maddin.
A somewhat insightful if not one-sided look into the election of Michel Martelly.
As far as legal procedurals and family dramas go, Black or White is a minor success.
Nielsson's film is a brave and important one.
An unexpectedly compelling political thriller.

movie_title: Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A generally bad time at the movies, and the only significant payoff is a reinforced feeling that Eli Roth is terrified of anyone who isn't an upper-middle-class millennial.
We're starved for adult horror that's this mature and sure-footed, and when it does come along, we have to sing its praises out loud. This is a wonderful, riveting, unsettling film.
An authentic approach to outrageous material doesn't just sell the film as actual found footage, it also shows remarkable intuition by first-timers Lee and Prouse.

For all the good Alan Taylor does in making sure that the sequel stays sure-footed, there's still a nagging feeling left behind that we haven't really seen a Thor film from a director who truly loves the world he's being paid to bring to life.
Really exemplary documentary filmmaking...I went from completely ignorant of Streb and her 'action heroes' (the name she applies to her dancers) to becoming a big fan. Born to Fly is a must.
This movie might not have worked at all without the performance of Juri, who is just a magnetic, impish powerhouse of an actress.
This is how Cage became a movie star in the first damned place -- by being a remarkable actor.
By being about a competition, even an unusual one, Wicker Kittens gets a big injection of sports movie vigor.
The Heart Machine frustrated me in the best possible way.
It's a case of lightning-in-a-bottle casting and there's no way of telling if anyone else as Dracula would've become the model for every single Dracula that followed.
Patrick's attempts at terror are more noisy than chilling, but its story is unique and engaging, even if the hairs on your neck never raise to full-mast.
It's not only an amazing piece of animation, but an incredible work of science-fiction as well.
movie_title: Nausicaä of the Valley of the Wind (Kaze no tani no Naushika) (1985)

movie_review_blurb: I'm shocked no one else has tried 'sex zombies' as a horror film device since this one -- they're terrifying.
movie_title: Shivers (They Came from Within) (The Parasite Murders) (1975)

movie_review_blurb: It's a spectacularly violent move into Bourne territory, with enhanced super-soldiers kicking the ever-livin' daylights out of each other over what freedom really means.
It feels like somebody's dopey idea of what comic books are, without actually reading them.
It's the rare brand name cash-in that manages to feel like artists actually cared.
It's a solid installment. But it would've been a killer curtain call.
Edge of Tomorrow will get the easy comparisons to Groundhog Day but it's also exactly the kind of punchy sci-fi adventure that goes best with salty popcorn and a willing audience.
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: [Honeymoon] delivers real unease despite a well-tread plot.
There's some real food for thought in the film from a topic we'd assume had been bled dry.

It's a little like Room 237 for Freddie Prinze Jr. flicks. There's not much upside in presenting the surface qualities of She's All That as deeper profound truths about adolescence, but [director] Lyne goes there anyway.

The pay-off is logical (if convoluted), and has real consequences to the relationship between the two, which deserves its own special recognition, seeing as how so many tiny indies think that the journey is its own reward.
There's nothing particularly remarkable about it, and it plays out almost exactly how you expect it to, but as a monster matinee, you could do a lot worse.

While the likes of 'Oh You Pretty Things' and 'All the Young Dudes' still raise a smile, the presiding image is of those flesh-crawling glam-rock costumes and stage antics. Go for the music, or not at all.
movie_title: Ziggy Stardust and the Spiders from Mars (1973)

movie_review_blurb: Silkwood's "ordinariness" protects her from being labelled a wild-eyed Trot, but that should not be allowed to obscure her courage or the whitewash ladled onto her story after her death.
Spielberg includes a strand of populist heroism, yet even this fails to dent the awful message. And the budget makes itself seen, as does Bale's superlative Jim.
Laughs aplenty for people who use drugs as a pose, but most will be left wondering if half a pint of Bass doesn't qualify as a revolutionary action.
The basic fault can be traced to a script which attempts an examination of French criminal procedure brought face to face with the confused habits of the younger generation.
It's a curious piece that doesn't necessarily support the title, but show is worth a look.
movie_title: Fallen Champ: The Untold Story of Mike Tyson (1993)

movie_review_blurb: True-life-based teen murder story out of California's San Fernando Valley gets TV movie treatment-it's already been fodder for tabloid TV outlets-and fares well with couple of finely layered central performances.
Performances are uniformly solid, with Tucker holding focal point with energy.
Smart, funny, sophisticated and full of self-referential digs.

Spider-Man 3 is better than most comic book-based superhero action epics, but not as satisfying as the first two installments of this multi-billion dollar franchise. I guess familiarity breeds disrespect.
Do we really need another Hulk, following so closely on the very large heels of Ang Lee's 2003 action adventure with the conflicted Marvel comic book superhero. As it turns out, yes, we do.
It's worth hanging on for where Greco goes with this.

movie_title: Celine: Through The Eyes Of The World (2010)

movie_review_blurb: It's the first summer movie of 2010. Let the expensive silliness begin.

Those who consider Hefner a man who made fortunes by exploiting women in his magazine should find no reason to change their minds after watching this fascinating, illuminating document of America during a time of profound change.
movie_title: Hugh Hefner: Playboy, Activist and Rebel (2010)

movie_review_blurb: This is outsider art in its finest, most unsettling expression.
Eileen Yaghoobian's fabulous debut doc is an inclusive look at the renaissance of poster art in the wake of punk and the rebirth of a defiant counterculture.
Famed Irish playwright Martin McDonagh's film debut In Bruges is a ferociously funny, deadly serious character study of two Dublin hitmen holed up in the titular Belgian town.
Since the hero and the villains are equally mechanical, the big, loud battles are as exciting and suspenseful as watching people play Mortal Kombat for 90 minutes.
It is good-natured, lowbrow, backlot, hit-or-miss humor, but with no cumulative effect beyond its succession of hard-worked jokes.
An admirable, responsible production, less emotionally disturbing than its predecessor, but a grand historical epic studying the nature of power in the United States' heritage.
